title: 1 Cemetery lots
summary: Don's 2012 letter to cemetery administrator regarding cemetery lot arrangements in Black River, discussing family burial plans and urn capacity. Personal correspondence documenting his connection to his birthplace.
content_preview:
62 Queen Elizabeth Drive

Charlottetown, PE

C1A 3A9




August 10. 2012




Lee Burnham

30 North Black River Road

Black River Bridge 

N.B.	 E1N 5S4




Dear Lee:

Black River Cemetery Lots




Many years ago, 1977 to be precise, while visiting my sister, Grace, in Boston, she expressed an interest in being buried in Black River.  Shortly thereafter, I “purchased” two 10’x 10’ lots, #143 for Grace and #142 for myself.  




My wife and I plan to be cremated with the ashes buried in urns in our lots.  It was our intention, when a stone is erected, to show the names of our two children.  Recently, however, our son and daughter have raised the idea of also having their ashes, and that of their spouses, interred in the Black River cemetery as well.  This letter comes to seek clarification as to limits, if any, on the actual number of urns that can be buried on our lot  and the size and wording of headstones  and the.  Do you require that all names be registered at this time?




As a matter of interest, what is the cost of opening and closing a lot for burial?




If you need any further information, do not hesitate to let me know.




Regards




Don Glendenning

title: 1- History  -
summary: Comprehensive historical document authored by Don (March 2021, Draft 2) on Black River, New Brunswick, his birthplace (born 1929, Black River Bridge NB per user context). Chronicles settlement from United Empire Loyalists post-1776, Scottish immigration patterns, geographic features (8 miles south of Chatham, tributaries), early economy (logging, fishing, farming), transportation evolution, school/church development. Covers approximately 120 households by 1939, details prominent families (MacDonald, MacNaughton, Godfrey, McGraw, Cameron), includes living costs from 1930s-1940s, sawmill operations, road infrastructure, educational evolution through MRHS establishment (1939), and community institutions. Demonstrates Don's deep genealogical research, personal knowledge, and commitment to preserving local history.
content_preview:
Along the Black River

March 30, 2021

Draft 2




This is not a history of Black River but rather random notes that I have gathered as part of my genealogical research.  While I include some notes on the early years, the focus is really on the period just before WW2.




The Black River

The Black River is about 8 miles south of Chatham, New Brunswick and originates in the forests between Barnaby River and Rogersville.  Like most rivers in the eastern part of the Province, the Black River flows from west to east, then it turns northward near its mouth and empties into Bay du Vin, which is part of the Miramichi River estuary.  From thence it flows into the Gulf of St. Lawrence and on to the Atlantic Ocean.    The Eastern boundary of the Black River was the Victoria Bridge near its mouth although technically the river extends beyond the bridge before melding with the waters of the Bay du Vin.  




The Black River has many tributaries the largest being the Little Black River, better known as Little Branch which joins the Black River not far from its mouth.  The other tributary of note, because it is also settled, is Wells Brook also shown in some early documents as Walls Brook.




A Brief History

The first settlers were United Empire Loyalists who, after the American Revolution of 1776, sailed north along the New England coast and, for the most part, entered the Bay of Fundy landing at Saint John, New Brunswick.  Many moved up the Saint John River with some crossing to the east coast via the upper reaches of the Miramichi; others came directly to the Miramichi.    Loyalists were soon followed by settlers from the old country - most were Scottish and Presbyterian.  After six to eight weeks on the ocean, they set foot in the New World.  Some, after an initial settlement elsewhere in the Maritimes, found their way to the Miramichi to work in shipbuilding.  Once on the Miramichi, exploration and settlement developed on its tributaries including the Black River.

title: 1 Spare Cemetery lot
summary: Don's 2013 letter regarding Black River Cemetery lot arrangements with family member Barbara, discussing lot ownership and potential redistribution. Documents his family connections and commitment to Black River as burial place.
content_preview:
62 Queen Elizabeth Drive

Charlottetown

PEI  C1A 3A9, 	Canada

						

								May 21, 2013




Dear Barbara: 




Good to talk with you last Thursday but sorry to be the bearer of bad news; this seems to happen all too often as we get older. 




We spoke about the lot 143, where your mother is buried, in the Black River Cemetery.  As you know, I bought my lots in 1973. I kept lot 142 for myself, and gave lot 143 to your mother; Norman owns lot144 and 145 on the other side of where your mother is buried.




As we agreed during our telephone conversation, I’ll have the other half of lot 143 changed back into my name.  Since a number of our relatives own lots in the vicinity, I will check to see who, if any of the family is interested.  If no family member wants it, I’ll make it available to someone else.




I’m putting this on paper, and sending a copy to Neil Watling who is a member of the                      Black River Cemetery Committee, just to they can keep their records straight.




As you know, we were over to Verne’s funeral and I was pleased to see the lot had been marked for my convenience; I am planning to have a stone erected later this year.




Say hello to all the family.













Cc:	Neil Watling

title: 100-1 Appendices
summary: Don's autobiographical reflection on formative educational literature including A.S. Neill's "The Free Child" (Summerhill school philosophy); "The Eight Year Study" (high school-college longitudinal research 1933-1941 showing innovative schools matched traditional schools academically while exceeding in non-academic life); Werner Z. Hirsch's "Inventing Education for the Future"; S.R. Laycock's "Teaching and Learning"; John Dewey's "Education and Democracy"; Neal Postman's "Education as a Subversive Activity"; and Mager's "Setting Instructional Objectives." Biographical notes establish Don's birth (Sept 8, 1929, youngest of 10 children, Black River Bridge, NB), childhood on mixed farm, participation in church and youth organizations, marriage to Carol Chesney (1958), two children (Brian and Janet). Chronicles early career: Teachers' College (1947), one-room school teaching (age 17), Miramichi Rural High School principal by age 24, technical teacher education (1949-1951), Lord Beaverbrook Scholarship to University of London (1955-1956), Bradley University B.A. (1957), Indiana University Ph.D. (1962). Federal service with Canada Employment and Immigration included teacher training specialist role. Holland College presidency 1969-1987 established competency-based education, Atlantic Police Academy, Culinary Institute of Canada, Centre for Creativity. Founded Glendenning Associates consulting firm (1987). International development work included CIDA missions to Southeast Asia, Pakistan, Swaziland, China, Kenya, and UNESCO/OECD meetings. Awarded Order of Canada (1986), UPEI Honorary Degree (1988).
content_preview:
Books that Made a Difference 







As a youngster, I was an avid reader.  One Christmas, that of 1938 I believe, I received 8 books as Christmas gifts.  I’ve continued to be an active reader although in later years I read more newspapers and periodicals than books.  I consider a book to be of value even if it only reveals one new idea.  The names and authors quoted in the following paragraphs may not be entirely correct since, at time of writing, I am in the process of disposing of my memorabilia, including books, and no longer have ready reference to correct titles.  




Books are expensive, but the lack of new ideas in our lives, and in our schools, is costly.  Reading is one way to expand idea generation. Any book that sparks even one new idea is a very good investment, 




I found the following to be particularly useful.




The Free Child by A. S. Neill




A. S. Neill, a Scot, was principal of Summerhill, an independent private English boarding school founded in 1921 in Leiston, Suffolk, England.  Summerhill was a residential school serving youngsters who had been turfed out of their regular schools because they were disruptive; it was their last chance school.  (I decided to Google Summerhill and, yes, it is still in operation and still as controversial as ever.)  




Summerhill catered to upwards of 100 students ages five to eighteen, it was run as a democracy, students were not required to attend classes and could do whatever they liked provided it did not impinge upon the rights of other students.  A centerpiece to the school was a daily meeting about school governance in which every student and staff member had an equal vote. Lessons were optional and students decide what they want to do with their time.  Students appeared to waste a lot of time but, once they decided to learn, they soon caught up.




The Eight Year Study. 




This reports the results of an eight-year longitudinal study of students in the USA through four years of high school and f...

title: 11-Jane Watling-
summary: Don's detailed biography of his mother Jane Elizabeth Jardine Watling (b. Feb 28, 1890; d. 1964). Chronicles her birth at the Meadows (Upper Black River), family of eight, move to the Branch, arrival in Portland Maine (Jan 24, 1908), domestic work for families like the Jennisons. Documents her friendships, extensive correspondence and autograph album entries from Maine and Tennessee, and original poetry ("Mothers," Oct 1934) written after her mother's death. Includes genealogy of Watling siblings and detailed reconstruction of her pre-marriage life in the Boston States. Valuable personal and poetic insight into Don's mother's youth.
content_preview:
Glendenning
	Family Memories

JANE ELIZABETH JARDINE WATLING
























Jane Watling was born, presumably at 
home, at the Meadows, Upper Black River, New Brunswick on February
28, 1890. Although her name was Jane, Dad always called her Jean;
this may account for the fact that the Watling side of the family
continued to call her Jane (or Janie as Uncle Ern called her) while
the Glendenning side of the family referred to her as Jean.  I
remember Mum saying that Dad referred to her as "Jeannie with
the light brown hair".  St. Stephen's Presbyterian Church (now
United Church) shows her name as Jane.  









Jane was the second youngest of a
family of eight born to Jubal Watling and Grace MacAskill MacDonald. 
 She was named after Jane Elizabeth Jardine who married Donald
Cameron (Cameron Russell’s grandmother)  A few years ago when
visiting Francis and Phyllis MacNaughton in Vancouver, Phyllis showed
a framed, handmade embroidery (?) made by Jane Elizabeth Jardine.








When Mum was about 10 years old, the
family moved from the Meadows to the Branch.  We know that she went
to school in Upper Black River; it is unlikely that she went or went
for very long to the school at the Branch.  I remember Mum saying
that her mother would take her from school to help Aunt Elspie
MacNaughton who had a young and growing family and needed help.








Portland, Maine








Jane Watling arrived in Portland on
January 24, 1908 just prior to her 18th birthday.  In the same way as
Maritimers now go to Ontario, points west or overseas, in those days
young people went to "the Boston States". Young women
frequently were employed to look after children and to do housework. 









The exact date that of her arrival in
Portland is known only because she arrived there on the day that the
City Hall burned.   I have since confirmed, through a phone call to
the Portland Public Library, that the fire occurred on January 24,
1908.  (I also recalled Mum saying that she could ...

title: 13-A Brief Return
summary: Don's chronological summary of parents' return to New Brunswick (1912-1913). Reconstructs timeline: Grace born Parksville (Sept 23, 1911), Jessie MacDonald dies (April 1912), parents still in Parksville (Nov 1912), Parksville dam completed (Dec 1912), work on Goforth Creek dam (1913), mother returns to Little Branch (summer 1913), father follows (fall/winter 1913), purchase of Jessie MacDonald property (July 21, 1914), Don's father postmaster role (Nov 1914-Aug 1916). Chronicles family's gradual reestablishment in Black River with brief detour to North Hampton Connecticut (1916) where sister Lillian born. Demonstrates Don's meticulous genealogical reconstruction methodology.
content_preview:
REESTABLISHING ROOTS IN NEW BRUNSW3ICK







Back to New Brunswick







We do not know exactly when Mum and Dad returned to New Brunswick but here are a few facts: 




Elmer and Jane set up housekeeping in Parksville, Tennessee on February 11, 1911.

Their first child, Grace, was born in Parksville, Tennessee on September 23, 1911.

Jessie MacDonald died in April, 1912.

A number of entries in Mum’s autograph album, the last on November 13, 1912, show they were still in Parksville at that time.  

Entries in Mum's autograph album by her brother, Ernest, and another from "Hughy", her cousin, “Mac” MacDonald,  dated November 13, 1912, indicates that either she and/or they were about to leave Parksville.

The Parksville dam was completed in December of 1912; a new dam was built up the Ocooe  River near Goforth Creek in 1913.

The second dam had the flume line which we know that Dad worked on.

A reference in Mum’s record book shows them living at Goforth Creek in 1913.

Mum was back in New Brunswick when Walter was born in on September 29, 1913.

Dad purchased the Jessie MacDonald property on July 21, 1914. 

Elmer Glendenning was listed by Canada Post as being Postmaster at Little Branch from November 1, 1914 to August 1, 1916.  

Venetia was born in New Brunswick on May 15, 1915.  

Lillian was born in North Haven, Connecticut on January 8, 1917.




My scenario is that Dad and mother moved from Parksville to Goforth Creek at the end of 1912.  In the summer of 1913, Mum returned with the children to Little Branch.  Dad may or may not have accompanied her but he came sometime that fall or winter.  They stayed at Little Branch until late 1916 and then moved to North Hampton, Connecticut where Lillian was born on January 8, 1917.

Glendenning Family Memories




Don Glendenning                                           		                          TIME \@ "MMMM d, yyyy" June 26, 2005

title: 15-Life at Little Branch
summary: Comprehensive account by Don of family's permanent settlement and farming operation at Little Branch (1919-1938). Details property acquisition (Jessie MacDonald property, $800, 1914), house renovation and barn expansion, acquisition of five properties for his sons, mixed farm operations (animals, crops, products), sheep shearing practices, Model T and Model A Ford automobiles, agricultural society involvement (Secretary-Treasurer 14 years), community roles (church trustee, hall construction, pulp business partnership with John W. MacNaughton). Includes his father's final illness (pernicious anemia/leukemia, diagnosed 1933) and death (1938). Rich detail of rural life, farm management, and family structure. Essential for understanding Don's formative years and his father's legacy.
content_preview:
Glendenning
	Family Memories





















LIFE
AT LITTLE BRANCH
















I
believe that Elmer and Jane Glendenning returned to New Brunswick in
1919 although I do not know the exact date nor even if they travelled
together.  Named and dated photos in Mum’s collection, show that
the family was in Mussel Shoals, Alabama in the earlier part of 1919.
 John was born on December 14, 1919 in Black River; the younger
children would have been there as well.  So the move must have
occurred earlier that year.  One might assume that the family moved
at latest during the summer so that the children, at least Walter and
Grace, could enrol in the Little Branch School by September.  They
already had a house waiting so temporary accommodation following the
move would not have been a major problem.   Discussion with siblings
suggest that their return was in May, 1919.






Dad
had purchased the property at Little Branch, where Norman Glendenning
now lives, from Alexander and Ethyl MacDonald.  Sometime in 1914, the
family took up residence in Black River for a couple of years before
returning to the USA again in late 1916.  Who lived in their property
during their absence, if anyone, we do not know. 







Their
property was known as the Jessie MacDonald property.  "Miss
Jessie", who was a schoolteacher, died in 1912.  This property
was directly across the road from where mother had lived as a child
and where her father and mother still lived.  The western property
line, starting at the Little Branch School, forms the back property
line for many of the properties along Black River.  The rear of the
property was known as Jessie's Corner - probably at the rear of
either the Godfrey or Gibson property.   While I have not completed
my search or county records, I believe that the property passed from
John MacDonald to Jessie and on her death from Jessie to her nephew,
Alexander MacDonald who sold it to my father.






The
original house, owned by Miss Jessie, was a tradit...

title: 16-Jane Glendenning
summary: Don's intimate portrait of his mother Jane Elizabeth (Jardine) Glendenning as widow (1938-1964), post-father's death. Describes wartime changes to Black River (Miramichi Rural High School, airbase, radar station), her church activism (Women's Missionary Society, Presbyterian League, Women's Institute), educational advocacy, knitting practices, bread-making, wool processing at Brown's Woolen Mills (Nelson), hospitality, oil lamp maintenance, food preservation/canning techniques, and community nursing. Recounts her announcement of war's end to Little Branch School (VE Day 1945), continued residence with son Norman and wife Jean, death from pancreatic cancer (March 24, 1964, Miramichi Hospital). Poetry and vignettes illuminate her character, values, and domestic expertise. Final portrait shows her impact on family and community.
content_preview:
Glendenning
	Family Memories






JANE ELIZABETH (JARDINE) GLENDENNING














After
28 years of marriage, Jane Elizabeth Jardine (Watling) became a widow
in 1939; she was 48 at the time.  The two oldest daughters, Grace and
Venetia, were married and living elsewhere; her daughter, Lillian,
was living and working in the Boston area.  Elinor and the five boys,
the youngest being nine years old, were living at home.








The
next decade, the wartime years, brought a number of significant
changes to the community.  The commencement of classes, and the
construction of the Miramichi Rural High School, allowed young people
of the community to continue their schooling to the end of high
school while continuing to live at home; before this, the nearest
high school was in Loggieville, eleven miles away.  The looming war
resulted in the construction of an airbase at Chatham, a radar
station at St. Margaret’s, and a bombing range on the road to
Loggieville.  These developments meant a significant growth of
non-farm jobs for the community.  The outbreak of hostilities also
soon resulted in sons, sons-in-law, neighbours, relatives and friends
entering the armed forces.  The decade also brought improved roads,
regular bus service to Chatham and electric lights.  By the end of
the decade, Black River had moved from a barter to a cash economy.








Although
the sons continued to operate the family farm for the next decade,
the decade also brought significant changes to the family;  Walter
finished building his house on the Dan MacLean property, married and
moved out; Lillian returned to New Brunswick and married; Elinor,
Kenneth, Norman and Don attended the new Miramichi High School;
Walter, Kenneth and Norman served in the armed forces; John, after
operating the farm during the war, married, built a house and moved
to the Bob MacLean property; Elinor married and moved out; Kenneth
returned from military service, married and moved away; Don finished
high school and ent...

title: 2-Dedication
summary: Dedication page for "Glendenning Family Memories" volume book by Don, dated April 3, 2005. Dedicates the work to the memory of his parents: Elmer Alton Glendenning (June 29, 1875 – May 18, 1938) and Jane Elizabeth Jardine (Watling) Glendenning (February 28, 1890 – March 24, 1964). Simple, reverent dedication expressing the purpose of the genealogical research as honoring parental memory. NOTE: Discrepancy in Elmer's birth date (shown as "1975" in transcription, clearly should be 1875 based on all other documents). Reflects Don's deep filial devotion and the emotional motivation behind his substantial research project.

title: 2-General
summary: A draft history of Miramichi Rural High School from which Don was a student. Documents early education in Black River beginning with home-schools in barns and homes (from 1817), then the 1825 petitioned school near Black River, and the district divisions around 1845. This is Don's personal research into his own school's history and the broader Miramichi educational heritage, reflecting his lifelong connection to the region.
content_preview:
Miramichi
Rural High School:

First
in its Class






NOTE:
 A
first draft of a brief history of the Miramichi Rural High School.  



	


	
	
Early
	Education
	



	
	
Soon
	after getting settled in their new community, settler’s thoughts
	turned to education. The first home-school in Black River was held
	in a barn belonging to Archibald Cameron, Sr.; the first school in
	Bay du Vin was operated at the home of James Graham near Buckley’s
	Bridge in Bay du Vin.  The task of teaching usually fell to most
	educated person in the community and classes were usually held in
	homes.  Records show that, at least by 1817, a qualified teacher,
	Hugh MacDougald, had been hired to provide instruction 
	
	



	
	
In
	1825, residents of Black River petitioned successfully for a school
	which, as I understand it, was erected near the lane now leading to
	St. Stephen's Church.   This school appears to have served all of
	Black River and as far east as lower Bay du Vin, and included
	trustees from both communities.
	



	
	
Although
	a closer examination of records may show otherwise, History of Bay
	du Vin (1) reports a school at the mouth of the Bay du Vin  River by
	1830, perhaps the Cameron School and a school in Bay side by 1845,
	and the Little Branch School around 1855.  MacDougall (2) reports
	that the Little Branch School burned shortly after construction but
	was soon replaced. 
	
	



	
	
Each
	District had a one room school handling all grades usually up to
	Grade 8 or perhaps Grade 9.  Very few students in the area went
	beyond the studies available at their local school. Those who were
	lucky, attended high school classes in Loggieville or Chatham and
	boarded with 
	
	



	
	



	
	



	
	



	
	
relatives
	or friends.  At the time it was possible for students, such as my
	sister Venetia Glendenning and Grace Godfrey, to write Normal school
	entrance exams and be admitted directly to Normal school after grade
	9
	



	
	
Winds
	of Change 
	
	
 
	
	
Things
	began to...

title: 2 History
summary: Substantial historical narrative documenting the origins and development of Presbyterian communities in Black River from the 1700s through the 1800s. Traces early settlers including United Empire Loyalists and Highland Scots, describes the first churches (Tucker's Point and St. Stephen's), and details the community's religious and social development. Demonstrates Don's scholarly research into family and local history.
content_preview:
THE
COMMUNITY 












The
name, Black River, is thought to have come from the MicMac word
Matquantigook that probably meant “black river”; the Black River,
with its tributaries principally the Little Black River but better
known as the Little Branch River, flows into Bay due Vin and the
inner Miramichi Bay.  At one time, the community of Black River
appears to have extended as far east as Bayside (Miramichi) and
perhaps as far as the Bay due Vin River.  The mouth of the Black
River, around what I knew as the Victoria Bridge and Hexham area, was
settled before 1800; most if not all the land around the Little
Branch River, except for the Fowlie Grant, and along the south side
of the Black River as far as St. Paul’s Presbyterian Church, was
granted on June 3, 1812.  







The
earliest settlers in the Black River as we know it today were United
Empire Loyalists and Highland Scots; some had settled initially along
the Saint John River, moved north to the Nashwaak and eventually
relocated to the Miramichi.  Settlers in Bay du Vin tended to be
English and followers of the Church of England with Black River being
Scottish and Presbyterian.  From MacDougall’s book we learn that
Loyalists included Major James Macdonald, Farquahar MacRae, Angus
MacDonald, Neil MacGraw, Dougald Campbell, James Gunn, Gregor
McKinnnon, Donald MacVicar, John Bailey Williston, Rev. Samuel Jones
and William Gardiner.  From Scotland came the Cameron brothers, John
MacLean, Hugh MacDougall, the MacNaughton family and William
MacBeath.  To our lists we must add Peter Kelly who came from
Ireland, the MacLeods, Sinclairs, Fraser, etc  and many other early
settlers but not included in MacDougall’s book.  Many residents of
the same name can still be found in the community today






The
land was heavily wooded, winters were long and cold and life was
hard.  But pioneers were hardy folk who were determined to carve out
a new life for themselves, their families and their offspring.  These
settlers br...

title: 2 Publications
summary: Don's comprehensive 2010 publication list documenting his major genealogical and local history works including Glendenning Roots, Family Chronicles (200 newsletters on relatives and ancestors), The Neighbourhood (WW2-era households), and Presbyterians in Black River. Demonstrates his scholarly contributions to family and community history.
content_preview:
March 30, 2010

GENEALOGY







This is the most up-to-date list (prepared in Nov 2011 for my visit to South Miramichi Historical Society. 

	 	LOCAL HISTORY PUBLICATIONS

by 

Don Glendenning

Publications:

1	Glendenning Roots - Background and photos on the life and times of Elmer and Jane (Watling) Glendenning with a focus on their years in the USA.  It also lists ancestors for each as well as their descendants.  (Approximately 200 pages bound.)

Carol Louise (Chesney) Glendenning - Background information and photos of Carol Chesney, her family and friends in Illinois.  (Approximately 100 pp bound

Family Chronicles; Volumes 1 and 2 – Copies of an informal newsletter intended to share with siblings the latest findings about relatives and ancestors.  Later Chronicles morphed into recollections of life and times of the author growing up in Black River, New Brunswick, especially in the period preceding WW2.  Each newsletter was two pages; each volume includes 100 newsletters.  Newsletters are also available on line at   HYPERLINK "http://www.glendenning.net/don" www.glendenning.net/don.  (Approximately 200 pp each volume, bound)  

The Neighbourhood - At the beginning of WW2, there were about 120 households along the Black River in Northumberland County, New Brunswick.  This volume identifies heads of households and their offspring; children are identified even though many had married and left home.  The volume also provides ancestor charts, where known, for many of the heads of households.  (Approximately 325 pages bound)

Presbyterians in Black River – starting with the early church history from the book, Black River and Its Early Settlers by A. W. MacDougall, (used with permission of the family), this book describes the worship of Presbyterians after Church Union in 1925.  (Approximately 60 pages bound)

title: 2003 History
summary: Don's comprehensive 2003 history of Presbyterians in Black River, tracing 200+ years of church history including St. Paul's Presbyterian Church (opened 1930). Demonstrates his scholarly commitment to documenting local religious and community heritage with extensive source citations.
content_preview:
A
BRIEF HISTORY






OF






PRESBYTERIANS
IN BLACK RIVER 







NEW BRUNSWICK



























































































Donald
E. M. Glendenning, C.M.

Charlottetown,
P.E.I.

December
2003




































ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
















The
author grew up in the community of Black River and in St. Paul’s
Presbyterian Church.  St. Paul’s was an integral part of our family
life; my mother and father were among the founders.  This paper is an
informal and brief record of St. Paul’s Church, in the context of
more than two centuries of Presbyterianism along the south shore of
the Miramichi River in New Brunswick, Canada.  It is included as part
of a binder of photos, clippings and other mementoes prepared to mark
the 75th anniversary of the opening of the church.






Much of
the information was gathered during brief visits to the Miramichi;
longer visits would have provided greater access to church records,
newspapers of the day and interviews with church members.  While care
was taken in gathering information, transcription errors are
possible.  This paper relies heavily on the following sources:







	

Black
	River and its First Settlers by A. W. MacDougall
	

A
	number of papers entitled History of St. Paul’s Presbyterian
	Church, Black River, NB  (Dates and authors unknown)
	

Church
	Union in Pictou Presbytery, 1925 by Dr. John R. Cameron, 1969.
	

Memoir
	of Rev. James MacGregor, DD, by Rev. George Patterson
	(Grandson), Philadelphia, 1859.   
	
	

Church
	minutes, clippings, photos and notes from a variety of sources but
	now available in an album put together by St. Paul’s Presbyterian
	Church in 2003.
	

Conversations
	with church members, adherents and friends








The
author would be remiss not to mention the major contribution to Black
River history made by Mr. A. W. MacDougall through his book, Black
River and its First Settlers.  This book has become a major
source of informat...

title: 2005-St. Pauls
summary: Don's speaking notes for St. Paul's Presbyterian Church 75th anniversary (2005), featuring historical context from 1930 and personal recollections of Black River during the Depression era. Personal reflections on community and church significance.
content_preview:
ST PAUL’S PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH

BLACK RIVER BRIDGE, NB




Speaking Notes on the occasion of the75th Anniversary

July 24, 2005







Congratulations - 	members and adherents of this congregation for seventy-five years of dedication and service

Thanks for the invitation to take part - Seventh-five years ago

first regular church service.  

I was here and let me see  

Edith, Marjorie, Ken, Norm, George, Marion, Blanche, others ?




The Chatham Gazette on July 15, 1930 called this church building “a fine and beautiful edifice.  It is a credit to any community.”




The article went on to say:




“In these days when any kind of building may pass for a church, it can be truly said that the structure in Black River reflects the ideal ecclesiastical architecture for a small house of worship.  The church has evoked nothing but praise from all who have seen it.  Great appreciation is expressed to all who have worked to make it what it is – to the building committee, to the carpenters in charge and others who o have laboured without stint.”  




And I would commend all who worked diligently since to maintain it.




First some comments about the year 1930:




Black River, like the rest of Canada, was in recession.  There was little or no cash; it was a barter economy.  

Families spent much effort just putting food on the table, planting, cultivating, harvesting, preserving and storing for the winter.

Telephone service had not yet arrived

Most travel was by horse and wagon or horse and sled;

There were a few cars but many were stored in barns for lack of funds to buy gas

Social gatherings were held at either the church or the school

The community hall was still in the discussion stage

$2.00 was an average wage, Walter received $1.50 a day for shingling, neighbours traded days for cutting wood and threshing, some equipment was owned jointly.

Dad sold 2x4 to the new hall for 25 cents each, a load of gravel cost $1.50 delivered.  Hired men received $.50 to $1.00 p...

title: 2008-Barry-Loperman
summary: Email exchange (January 30-31, 2008) between Don Glendenning and Barry MacKenzie regarding Alexander Watling and Mary Ann Lopemen. Don inquires about Alexander Watling of Chatham (born September 10, 1889), while Barry provides census analysis from 1851-1881 identifying this Alexander as likely the son of William Watling and Mary MacNaughton. Demonstrates Don's systematic genealogical research methods and collaborative correspondence with specialists.
content_preview:
From: "Barry MacKenzie" <barrymack4@hotmail.com>

To: "Don Glendenning" <dglende@pei.sympatico.ca>

Subject: RE: Lopeman

Date: January 31, 2008 12:22 AM










Hello Don!

 

I am afraid that you are overestimating my level of Watling expertise! However, in this case, I believe that I may have figured out who the Alexander who married Mary Ann Lopeman was. The Census of 1881 shows Alex Sr.(26), Mary Ann (23), and two children: Mary M. (3) and William (2m). Alex Jr. was born later, as we know. The family does not appear in the 1891 census.

 

It seems that this Alex Sr. fits the age description for Alexander, a son of William Watling and Mary MacNaughton. Alex (Wm) was 6 in 1851, 15 in 1871, and no longer at home in 1881. The Alex in question is the only Alex Watling in the county in the 1881 census. Let me know if you have other information as to the spouse/progeny of William and Mary's Alex. If not, I don't know where else this Alex Sr. would have come from. I think he's our man!

 

Barry







From: dglende@pei.sympatico.caTo: barrymack4@hotmail.comSubject: LopemanDate: Wed, 30 Jan 2008 22:02:21 -0400










As you know I am trying to update some of my files

 

Quite by accident I found a reference to Alexander Watling of Chatham born September 10, 1889, son of Alexander Watling and Mary Ann Lopemen.

 

I cannot tie this to anything in my database but you have more detail than I.

 

having some computer problems.  whenever I am operational again, i will send you the  source of my most recent information on jubal and Susan Leach

 

Don

_________________________________________________________________

title: 2008-Bsrry-Watling

Includes census data and discussion of John Watling's marriage to Jessie Carruthers (1849), their children, and their movements between New Brunswick and Massachusetts. title: 2008-Erin-Comeau
summary: Extended email correspondence (January 2008) between Don Glendenning and Erin Knighton establishing distant cousinship through Elizabeth J Glendenning (b. 1843, m. Amos Comeau in New Bandon, NB). title: 2008-Hamilton -
summary: Email (January 4, 2008) from Bonnie Hamilton to Don's genealogy group responding to his update on Harley family research. Hamilton discusses Mary Anne Harley Henry's 99th birthday interview, missing family members, the William Harley who moved to Upper Canada, and her own research in Ireland (Courtmacsherry, Rathclarin parishes) connecting Knowles and Harley families. Mentions meetings with William Harley (author of family history) and discoveries about marriage arrangements across Courtmacsherry Bay. Shows Don's role orchestrating multi-person genealogical investigations.
content_preview:
From: "B J Hamilton" <hamilton3049@rogers.com>

To: "Don Glendenning" <dglende@pei.sympatico.ca>; "Kim Nielsen" <chriskim@telusplanet.net>; "Heather Wilson" <callixiuh@yahoo.ca>; "Irma Downing" <dondown@nbnet.nb.ca>; "Kelsie Erskine" <erskinekd@yahoo.co.uk>

Subject: Re: Update

Date: January 4, 2008 10:44 PM




Hello Everyone,




Just a few observations off the top of my head as my notes have been packed away while I have been occupied with other pursuits over the last few months. However, now that winter seems to be setting in in earnest, this would be a good time to get back to my research.




Reading through Don's notes has reminded me that Mary Anne Harley Henry indicated in her 99th birthday interview that she had two brothers and three sisters. Even if we find conclusive evidence that Elizabeth and Margaret were her sisters, we are still missing another sister. If my calculations are correct the one that died on her 94th birthday is not accounted for.




The Harley family members of Miramichi seemed to have been fairly prominent. Therefore, I wonder why the local papers transcribed by Daniel Johnson, didn't give any coverage to the death of Ann Bidders Harley. Perhaps her death predated some of the newspapers. In Ireland I saw a volume of Coshe Mang that listed a marriage for an Ann Bidders at about the right time frame but it was to a Denis Harley. I am hoping that one of the Toronto libraries will have copies of the Coshe Mang volumes so I can explore further.




By one of those strange quirks, I worked in the early 70's with a colleague who is a direct descendant of the William Harley who moved to Upper Canada from Miramichi. One of her relatives (also named William Harley) has compiled a family history in which he suggests a relationship to the Harley's of Harley Street in London.




Incidentally, if anyone has a current contact for Robert Stevens, I would appreciate getting in touch with him. A few years ago he was planning to transcribe a diary of...

title: 2008-Harley notes -1
summary: Don Glendenning's personal notes (January 1, 2008) on his Harley family connections through his Great Grandmother Margaret Harley who married John Glendinning. Notes his lack of direct proof of paternity while acknowledging Margaret's siblings (William, John, Elizabeth, Mary Anne). References his Family Chronicle issues #1, #4, #125, #134, #136, and mentions he is the youngest of nine siblings, with specific issues devoted to each. Notes Burton Glendenning's archival work on Burchills, and speculates on Hurley/Harley surname interchangeability. Reveals Don's systematic approach to publishing family history.
content_preview:
HARLEY NOTES

January 1, 2008




I had a number of queries recently about my Harley connections and information about the Harley Family.  I used the queries as an excuse to review my notes and files.  Here are a few notes that do not seem to fit into the actual family tree but may be of interest:




My connection to the Harleys is through my Great Grandmother, Margaret Harley who married John Glendinning

While all evidence points to my Great Grandmother being a daughter of William and Ann (Bidders) Harley, I do not have, nor have I seen actual proof of, the relationship.  

Margaret’s siblings are William, John, Elizabeth and Mary Anne

The Spring 2004 Issue of Generations, Journal of NB Genealogical Society, carried an item from the obituary of John Harley taken from the Union Advocate of Sept 29, 1875.  I can send it to you if you would like to see it.

According to my information, our Harleys came to Canada in the following order:  William in 1820, Mary Ann in 1822 and John in 1823; I do not know the dates of arrival of Elizabeth and Margaret.

Books of interest:  Louise Manny  “Ships of the Miramichi” and Margaret Hunter “Pioneer Settlers of the Bay Chaleur” in 1978; I have not seen the first one but have a copy of the second.

Burton Glendenning, a descendent of Margaret Harley and John Glendinning, was NB Archivist and wrote a book, perhaps a thesis for a degree, on the Burchills of the Miramichi.  I have not seen the book.

I note the possibility that Hurley and Harley may be the same family; I did not encounter that but understand that they have the same roots.  Interesting to note in Heather’s list of Hurleys, that a John Hurley married Elizabeth Burchill in 1841.  Our John Harley and George Burchill were partners in shipbuilding on the Miramichi; they probably came from the same place.

As some of you know, I publish a Family Chronicle” ( HYPERLINK "http://www.glendenning.net/don" www.glendenning.net/don)  This started as a way to pass along family info...

title: 2008-Irma-Family
summary: Email (January 5, 2008) from Irma Downing to Don seeking information about a Glendenning family in Chatham (1911 census: William, Ethel, Kenneth, Wyona, Marjorie, Lorne, Jean) and mentioning Glendennings in Big River, Bathurst. Irma is a former teacher (1969-1986, Salmon Beach to Caraquet, taught ESL) and discovers connection: her mother Alda Jane Knowles was named after "Alda Jane 'Maud' Glendenning" (Don's aunt), confirming Glendenning-Knowles family connections in the region. Demonstrates Don's role as central researcher fielding inquiries about interconnected New Brunswick families.

I found this family of Glendennings in the Chatham area in the 1911 Census..Do you know anything about them?  Also there were Glendennings in the Big River Area of Bathurst..if fact Elmer Glendenning was married to Joy Glendenning..Joy's father was my father's first cousin..Very small world..




You said you were the youngest of 9 children..On the Chronicle, I have read notes on 3 of your siblings..very well presented.  Are you planning on doing this for all your family?  Is your Watling branch connected to the Watling families in the Bathurst area?




From working on practically all the known families in the New Bandon area, I learned a lot about them..everyone is interconnected..I am sure you have found the same thing in the Black River area..




I, too, taught school for 17 years..I started in Salmon Beach..the green school, in 1969 and ended in Caraquet in 1986.  I began my teaching career teaching grades 4 & 5 , then married and moved to Saint Leolin, near Grande Anse.  I was then accepted to teach English as a Second Language to Grade 10 - 12.  My first year was very difficult as I couldn't speak French and had no close contact with my students..the following year I started picking up the language and as they say the rest is History..I didn't retire from teaching I just stopped...to much paper work and the Government was reforming the education system which...

title: 2008-Twila-1
summary: Email exchange between Don Glendenning and Twila Buttimer regarding genealogical research about the Harley and Glendenning families. Buttimer assists Don in locating geographic place names and historical references in New Brunswick, particularly regarding Vernon, NB, and the Mary Ann Harley burial site. References a Master of Arts thesis on the Burchill mill (1850-1906) by Burt Glendenning at Concordia University. Shows Don's methodical genealogical research methods and collaboration with other family historians.
content_preview:
Hi
Don,

 

I'm
stumped, too.

 

Our
NB Gazetteer shows only a Vernon Island in the Parish of Saint George
in Charlotte County and a Vernons Mountain in the Parish of Simonds
in Saint John County.  I have also checked Alan Rayburn's work
"Geographical Place Names in New Brunswick" (1975) -
because he often includes place names that are no longer used - but
no luck.  There is a Mount Venning near the Miramichi River -
but that is not Vernon.   Sorry!

 

For
Burt Glendenning's thesis (it is a Master of Arts thesis completed at
Concordia University in Montreal in 1978) on the Burchill mill
(1850-1906), you probably could find it at the University of PEI
Library.  It should be there on microfiche.  Burt was
checking at home to see if he had an extra copy that he could send
you -but so far has not been successful.

for the item on Mary Ann Harley which you sent along.  It is
very interesting and I believe it is the item that I was
looking for.

best wishes, Twila

title: 2009-Notes Mum and Dad
summary: Detailed biographical essay by Don about his father Elmer Alton Glendenning (1875-1938) and mother Jane Elizabeth Jardine Watling (1890-1964). Covers Elmer's early years in Canobie, family values regarding education, Portland cartage and lumber business, dam construction work across North America (Tennessee, Virginia, Connecticut, Texas, Alabama), return to Little Branch farming, pulp business, community involvement (church, Agricultural Society, Masonic Lodge), and final illness. Documents Jane's early life in Portland, her devotion to church and community, hospitality to visitors, food preservation, yarn trading, bread-making, and care of oil lamps. Captures wartime community changes and parents' influence on Don's life.
content_preview:
ELMER ALTON GLENDENNING




Elmer was the second child and first son, to Walter and Elizabeth (Peters) Glendenning, was born in Canobie on land that is now a grove of trees directly across the road from the Canobie School, now the Women’s Institute Hall.   




It is likely that he went to the one room school on a corner of his Uncle’s farm next door since the family seems to have valued education; this is not surprising in that his grandmother was a teacher and lived in the home until Elmer was 20.  As further evidence, his brother, Chip took a business course, Guy studied but did not finish dentistry and Margaret trained as a nurse.  It is likely that Dad took some technical courses; I remember some engineering books at home.  His oldest sister, Venetia, provided a home for his sister, Margaret, so that she could finish high school in Portland; I believe that Uncle Guy also completed high school there; maybe others did as well.    




Elmer’s father was a farmer and, judging by the amount of land accumulated, a successful one at that.  Elmer, and all the boys, and maybe even the girls, would be expected to do their share.  The land would have to be cleared of trees, and those who know Canobie, will remember the stony fields; and all the work would be done by hand or with the aid of horses.




At that time he probably knew people, even friends, who went to Maine or New Hampshire during the winter to work in the woods and then return to farm and fish in the summer; he may have even done that himself.  




The Glendennings were well established in Portland in the first decade of the 1900s. Frank moved there in 1898 and Elmer by 1901. Venetia, the oldest child, seems to have played the role of "host" as each new family member moved south.  Venetia lived in Falmouth Foreside which is between Portland and Freeport.  Other siblings known to have lived in Portland, at least for a while, include Margaret, Raymond and Guy.   In addition, Maude and her husband, Jim Cormie...

title: 2009 notes on siblings
summary: Comprehensive family memoir written by Don documenting his parents' siblings: Grace (worked in Boston, married Roy Morrison Smith), Roy, Walter (farmed, worked in Modern Construction, moved to Moncton), Agnes (trained as RNA), Venetia (teacher, Church treasurer, married Cameron Russell), Cameron, Lillian (lived in Boston then married Kenneth Brydone Weeks, recorded early memories), and Brydone (Presbyterian minister, dairy farmer). Contains rich personal anecdotes: Grace's extraordinary eyesight, Walter's hospitality and keen memory, Lillian's 144-page typed memories, family travels to Florida and Europe. Essential autobiographical documentation showing Don's deep engagement with recording family history.
content_preview:
Grace Elizabeth (Glendenning) Smith




Grace was the oldest in the family and was born in Parksville, Tennessee.  Dad and Mum had set up housekeeping there in February 1911 where Dad worked on Ocoee #1, the first of three dams build on the Ocoee River.  Aunt Janet had journeyed to Parksville to be with Mum when Grace was born.  




 When Grace was young, Dad and Mum moved from construction site to construction site in the US and, presumably, Grace attended school wherever she was; one school was the Armstrong School but I am not sure if it was in Connecticut or Virginia.  The family returned to NB in 1919 and, again, presumably Grace attended the Little Branch School.  Later she attended Success Business College in Moncton, NB where she took a business program.  While she made good marks, apparently she did not like the program.  It was when returning from Business College with Grace, that Dad upset the Model T at Gilbert’s Corner, near Shediac.  Grace broke her wrist but even so, went to a dance in the Little Branch School that night.




Like so many other Maritimers, Grace went to Boston to work, probably in 1930 and worked for various families caring for children and likely cooking.  . On her first trip, she traveled with Mrs. F. A. Fowlie and Ernest MacLean who were going to Lowell, Mass to visit relatives.  She may have she stayed for a while with Dad’s cousin, Sam Knowles.  At one time she lived at 1595 Beacon Street, Beverley, Mass. She frequently visited her Uncle Jack Watling in Boston and later when he lived on Swan’s Island near Eastport, Maine.  Grace returned regularly to Little Branch for the summer coming sometimes by steamer from Boston to Saint John, NB.  (I believe that the fare to Saint John was $10.00)  In 1947, when I left home for Teachers’ College in Fredericton, I inherited Grace’s steamer trunk – and it carried my belongings on a number of later trips.




As a young woman in Little Branch and later in Boston, Grace loved to square dance;...

title: 2010-1A Glendinning-All
summary: Comprehensive genealogical compilation authored by Donald E. M. Glendenning (copyright 2010) documenting descendants of John Glendinning. Includes introduction explaining Don's 60+ years of family information gathering, retirement genealogy work, and a database of 6,000 names. Dedicated to Carol, Brian, Janet, and granddaughters Marie, Lisa, Laura. Contains extensive Scottish ancestry research from Dumfriesshire, details on John Glendinning's immigration (1830) from Annan, marriage to Margaret Harley (1833), and explains Don's identity as member of multiple families (Rae, Harley, Bidders, Peters, Sealey, Watling, MacNaughton, MacDonald, Jardine, MacAskill, Jack, Stewart). This document represents the culmination of Don's life work in genealogy and is essential for understanding his values, family connections, and intellectual contributions.

JOHN
	GLENDINNING
	
1807-1877
	



	
	
John
	Glendinning, 1807-1877, the author’s Great Grandfather, was born
	in Callister Hall, Dumfriesshire, Scotland; Callister Hall is still
	occupied but not by Glendinnings.  .
	



	
	
He
	came to Canada in 1830, married Margaret Harley, who came to New
	Brunswick for Ireland,  in 1833 and settled on a piece of property
	at Salmon Beach on the Baie de Chaleur.  John farmed and Margaret
	taught school.  The family later relocated to Canobie.  John and
	Margaret had five children: Mary Ann, John, Margaret, Elizabeth Jain
	and Walter.,
	



	
	
The
	Glendinning/Glendenning name is not as rare as first thought.  A
	number of families, mostly Glendenning rather than Glendinning, came
	to New Brunswick in the early 1800’s and all seem to have come
	from Dumfriesshire.  They settled near Bathurst, Saint John, Rexton,
	Sussex, Woodstock and in the Port Elgin area. Although I expect a
	family linkage exists, I have not found one  to date

title: 2010-1B Elmer&Jane
summary: Published genealogical volume "Descendants of Elmer Glendenning & Jane (Watling) Glendenning" (Family Series 7) by Don, copyright 2010. Mirrors the introduction from File 9 but focuses on his parents' direct descendants. Provides extensive biographical notes on Elmer Alton (1875-1938): Canobie birth, family values on education, Portland business ventures (cartage, lumber, horses), dam construction projects across USA, farming, agricultural society leadership, church activities, pulp business. Detailed account of Jane Elizabeth Jardine Watling (1890-1964): Meadows/Little Branch origins, Portland employment, marriage 1910, community involvement, widowhood 1939, wartime era influence. Emphasizes their nine children and multi-generational family impact.

amily

ELMER
	AND JANE GLENDENNING
	



	
	
Elmer
	Glendenning was born in Canobie, New Brunswick, and moved to
	Portland, Maine about 1900.  Jane Watling was born in Black River,
	New Brunswick and moved to Portland in January, 1908.  Obviously the
	two families knew each other because, two weeks after Jane’s
	arrival,  Jane cared for children during the funeral for Elmer’s
	father.   Elmer and Jane were married in little Branch on October
	18, 1910 and lived for a short while in Portland.
	



	
	
On
	February 11, 1911, they set up housekeeping in Parksville,
	Tennessee.  Elmer worked in heavy construction mostly on 
	hydro-electric dams and, although they returned to New Brunswick in
	1914, by 1916 they were back in the USA working on projects in
	Connecticut, Alabama and Virginia....
	



	
	
In
	1914, they bought a farm in Little Branch, directly across the road
	from where Jane’s parents lived; they  took up full time residence
	there in 1919.  Theirs was a mixed farm of cows, pigs, chickens,
	geese, horses and turkeys along with hay, grain and vegetables.
	Community activities included church, school, community hall,
	agricultural society and raising a family of nine.
	



	
	
Their
	offspring, especially children and grandchildren, will have fond
	memories visits to the farm – a tradition continued by the next
	generation, Norman and Jean.Glendenning

amily

JUBAL
	WATLING
	
Abt
	1790-1845
	



	
	
The
	first Jubal Watling encountered was  the author’s Great Great
	Grandfather.  There were three Watling ancestors named Jubal; the
	first, at least the first in my records was born in Brockdish,
	Norfolk, England about 1790 but, after marriage lived in Suffolk,
	England.  Jubal married Susannah (Susan) Leech and they had nine
	children:  Their children included: Emily, Mary Ann, Emily, William,
	Jubal, Susannah, John, John and George, several of whom die
	
d
	young in England.  Jubal’s wife, Susanna, also died in England and
	was buried on May 5, 1829 in Syleham.  The family moved to Canada in
	1830, perhaps via Pictou, Nova Scoria but ended up in Prince Edward
	Island.  .  
	
	



	
	
On
	July 14, 1831, Jubal Watling and Louisa, a widow, were married in
	St. Paul Anglican Church, Charlottetown and the marriage record says
	that Jubal and his wife were "lately" in Norfolk County,
	England.  Jubal and Louisa also had at least one child, William
	Charles.  After Jubal died, Louisa married a William Smith.
	



	
	
Jubal’s
	sons, William and Jubal moved to the Miramichi in the mid 1800’s
	to work in shipbuilding; they both married MacNaughtons and owned
	land at the Meadows in Black River.

title: 2010-3 FTM Macdonald -8 gen
summary: Genealogical reference document "Descendants of MacDonald Family" (Family Series 3) documenting 8 generations of the MacDonald family relevant to Don's ancestry through his maternal grandmother. Traces MacDonald origins to Parish of Assynt, Rosshire, Scotland; documents Alexander MacDonald (who may have emigrated via Cape Breton) and his marriage to Grace MacAskill. Lists MacDonald children including Kenneth, Hugh MacAskill, Anne, Isabella, Margaret, John, Mary, and Jessie, with birth/death dates and marriage information. Alexander died October 31, 1843, in Little Branch, NB, establishing the family's New Brunswick settlement tied to Don's genealogical heritage.
content_preview:
Descendants of MacDonald Family







Generation No. 1




1.  MACDONALD1 FAMILY




Notes for MACDONALD FAMILY:

The Gaelic spelling of MacDonald, meaning the son of Donald, is Mac Dhomhnuill.  - but there were many Donalds.  The MacDonalds were a very large clan having taken many septs under their wing.  Alexander MacDonald, the first one for which I have a record,  was a native of the Parish of Assynt in Rosshire, Scotland.  That area of northwest Scotland is hilly and rocky with many inlets and streams with little land suitable for cultivation; the county also includes many islands




My Great Great Grandfather, Alexander MacDonald married Grace MacAskill (I believe a relative of the giant Mac Askill of Cape Breton) and was said to have actually come to the Miramichi by way of Cape Breton.  George Loggie said that Alexander MacDonald spent the first winter in Point Aux Carr after coming from Cape Breton; family  lore suggests Alexander and Grace were married in Cape Breton.  Their children include:




Kenneth		(1805-1837)

Annabel		(1806?-	)

Hugh MacAskill	(1808?-1873)

Anne		(1813-1896)		married William MacKnight	(1804-1865)

Isabella 		(1810-1893)		married Roderick Mackenzie	(1808-1893)

Margaret		(1815-1900)		married William Godfrey	(825-1904)

John		(1817 - 1900) 		married Elspeth Jardine	(1821-1907)

Mary		(1821-1885) 		married Frederick Robertson

Jessie		(1823-1912)







	

Child of MACDONALD FAMILY is:

2.	i.	ALEXANDER2 MACDONALD, b. 1775, Assynt, Scotland; d. October 31, 1843, Little Branch, NB.







Generation No. 2




2.  ALEXANDER2 MACDONALD (MACDONALD1 FAMILY)1 was born 1775 in Assynt, Scotland1, and died October 31, 1843 in Little Branch, NB1.  He married GRACE MACASKILL1.  She was born 1781 in Assynt, Cty Sutherland, Scotland1, and died February 23, 1874 in Little Branch, Black River, New Brunswick, Canada1.

	ALEXANDER MACDONALD
	
1775-1843
	



	
	
Alexander
	MacDonald was the author’s Great Great Grandfather and was a
	native of the Parish of Assynt in Rosshire, Scotland.  That area of
	northwest Scotland is hilly and rocky with many inlets and streams
	with little land suitable for cultivation; the county also includes
	many islands
	



	
	
He
	married Grace MacAskill also of Assynt, Scotland (I believe a
	relative of the giant MacAskill of Cape Breton); family  lore
	suggests Alexander and Grace were married in Cape Breton..  Their
	children included: Kenneth, Annabel, Hugh, Anne, Isabella ,
	Margaret, John, Mary, and Jessie. 
	
	



	
	
The
	original MacDonald home, I believe, was close to the river in the
	field just above where Norman Glendenning now lives.  In those days,
	travel was by boat and the land at that site sloped gently to the
	River. Both Bill Fowlie and my sister, Lillian, remembered the
	remnants of an old house in that area.  In a taped interview with
	Aunt Janet Godfrey, she recalled an old barn in that location also.

	author’s lineage includes:
	



	
	
		

Alexander

content_preview:
Descendants of MacNaughton Family







Generation No. 1




1.  MACNAUGHTON1 FAMILY




Notes for MACNAUGHTON FAMILY:







The first in line is John MacNauchtan, thought to have been born at Dunderave Castle, Scotland and died (before 1750) at Glenlyon, Perthshire, Scotland.  His son, Malcolm was also thought to have been born at Dunderave Castle and died at Glenlyon, Perthshire, Scotland. Following the publication of this information in Family Chronicle No. 28, however, I received the following Email from  Thomas Holme:




 "There were no McNaughtons living in Dunderave castle after around 1720. Your website states that Malcolm's son John was born in Dunderave castle July 24, 1774. But the MacNaughtons lost the castle and all their lands in the first decade of the 1700s. By 1711 they final paperwork was finished and Dunderave no longer belonged to them. Dunderave belonged to the family of Campbel of Ardkinglas that lived across Loch Fyne from the MacNauchtans. We are sure that a few members of the MacNauchtan family continued to dwell in the castle for perhaps another ten years in hope that some way would develop to return the lands and castle to the MacNauchtans. But that did not happen. Famous historians living in that time write that the castle was abandoned and none of the MacNauchtan family lived there afterwards. So you see, he couldn't have been born in Dunderave in 1774".




Malcolm's son, John, was  born July 24, 1774; he married Catherine Stewart and they had eight children.  John died in Scotland.

title: 2010-6 FTM Peters 7 Gen

content_preview:
Descendants of Peters Family







Generation No. 1




1.  PETERS1 FAMILY




Notes for PETERS FAMILY:

My grandmother, Elizabeth Peters, married Walter Glendenning.  Settlers of the Bay of Chaleur says that the Peters came from Ireland, however, my search shows also shows Peters meaning "Peter- a rock", is not uncommon in the  Angus, Kincardine and Aberdeen areas of Scotland.   The name John Peter is found in 1636, Andro Peter in Kirkcaldie in 1840, David Peter in Peebles, southern Scotland, in 1645 and Alexander Peter in Melrose in 1648.  The name is also found in southern Scotland which is closer to Dumfrieshsire.  Peters, Pieter, Peterson and probably Petrie have the same roots.  My references show Peters as a Sept of both the MacGregor and MacLaren clans.  The name Petrie was found in Balwelow in 1513, Andrew Petrie was Vicar of Wick Caithness in 1530 and there are a number of later references. Some of the Peters on Prince Edward Island trace their origin to the Acadian name, Petrie.




	

Children of PETERS FAMILY are:

2.	i.	JOHN2 PETERS, b. 1817, Ireland; d. June 30, 1904, Canobie, New Brunswick.

3.	ii.	RICHARD PETERS, b. 1827, Ireland; d. 1911, Canobie, NB.







Generation No. 2




2.  JOHN2 PETERS (PETERS1 FAMILY)1 was born 1817 in Ireland1, and died June 30, 1904 in Canobie, New Brunswick1.  He married (1) JANE SEALEY1 October 18471, daughter of SEALEY FAMILY.  She was born December 24, 1821 in County Cork, Ireland1, and died September 12, 1892 in Canobie1.  He married (2) SARAH ANN MCKNOLLAN April 17, 1895.  She was born July 29, 1856.




Notes for JOHN PETERS:

Jennie Foley says that John Peters was born  between December 24, 1817 and 1822 in Ireland and died between 1881 and August 1896; Jennie Foley has date of marriage as January 16, 1849.  Census of 1881 lists Jane J - 24, Albertina - 18, Norman - 16, Laura A - 14, Robert H - 11, Evelyn L - 9.

content_preview:
Descendants of Elmer Alton Glendenning







Generation No. 1




1.  ELMER ALTON6 GLENDENNING  (WALTER5, JOHN4 GLENDINNING, JOHN3, JOHN2, GLENDINNING/GLENDENNING1 FAMILY)1 was born June 29, 1875 in Canobie, NB1, and died May 18, 1938 in Black River Bridge, NB1.  He married JANE ELIZABETH JARDINE WATLING1 October 18, 1910 in Bride's home, Little Branch, Black River, New Brunswick1, daughter of JUBAL WATLING and GRACE MACDONALD.  She was born February 28, 1890 in Upper Black River, NB1, and died March 25, 1964 in Newcastle Hospital, NB1.




Notes for ELMER ALTON GLENDENNING:

Elmer, the second child and first son to Walter and Elizabeth (Peters) Glendenning, was born in Canobie on land that is now a grove of trees directly across the road from the Canobie School, now the Women's Institute Hall.   Baptismal record shows birthdate as June 10, 1875




It is likely that he went to the one room school on a corner of his Uncle's farm next door since the family seems to have valued education; this is not surprising in that his grandmother was a teacher and lived in the home until Elmer was 20.  As further evidence, his brother, Chip took a business course, Guy studied but did not finish dentistry and Margaret trained as a nurse.  It is likely that Dad took some technical courses while in Portland; I remember some engineering books at home.  His oldest sister, Venetia, provided a home for his sister, Margaret, so that she could finish high school in Portland; I believe that Uncle Guy also completed high school there; maybe others did as well.    




Elmer's father was a farmer and, judging by the amount of land accumulated, a successful one at that.  Elmer, and all the boys, and maybe even the girls, would be expected to do their share.  The land would have to be cleared of trees, and those who know Canobie, will remember the stony fields; and all the work would be done by hand or with the aid of horses.




At that time he probably knew people, even friends, who went to...

title: 2010 Author
summary: Professional biographical profile of Don Glendenning, authored by Don himself. Summarizes his career: born and raised in Little Branch; education at Teachers' College, New Brunswick Institute of Technology; teaching at Kouchibouguac and Miramichi Rural High School; principal role; training specialist with Federal government; President of Holland College (1969-1987, though not explicitly stated in this excerpt); education: Bradley University (BSc, MSc), University of London, Indiana University (PhD). Notes involvement with Community Foundation of PEI, genealogy research, gardening, and publishing "Family Chronicle" newsletter. Mentions wife Carol Chesney (from Peoria, Illinois) and two children (Brian and Janet) with two grandchildren.
content_preview:
ABOUT THE AUTHOR













Don Glendenning was born and raised in Little Branch, Black River, New Brunswick..  He attended the Little Branch School, a one-room school serving the district, and is a graduate of the Miramichi Rural High School, the first of a series of rural high schools established in New Brunswick prior to WW2.  




After his studies at Teachers’ College and the New Brunswick Institute of Technology (now the New Brunswick Community College) he taught first in a one-room school in Kouchibouguac, NB and later at the Miramichi Rural High School where he served first as a teacher and later as Principal.  Community involvement included Secretary to the Farm Radio Forum, a member of St. Paul’s Presbyterian Church and a Scout leader.




Most of his life was spent in education in the public schools of Mew Brunswick, at the New Brunswick Institute of Technology, as a training specialist with the Federal government and as President of Holland College in Charlottetown, PEI.  Formal studies include a year at the University of London (England), Bradley University from which he received a BSc. and MSc, and Indiana University where he received his Ph.D.  




He is currently active in The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, tracing his roots, reading and puttering around in his garden and on his “farm”. For many years, he was a regular contributor to the CVA Journal, edited a newsletter for the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, and currently publishes the Family Chronicle, a newsletter that reports his genealogical findings and recollections of life in Black River.




Don married Carol Chesney from Peoria, Illinois and they have two children and two grandchildren.

He
	came to Canada in 1830, married Margaret Harley, who came to New
	Brunswick for Ireland,  in 1833 and settled on a piece of property
	at Salmon Beach on the Baie de Chaleur.  John farmed and Margaret
	taught school.  The family later relocated to Canobie.  John and
	Margaret had five children: Mary Ann, John, Margaret, Elizabeth Jain
	and Walter.,
	



	
	
The
	Glendinning/Glendenning name is not as rare as first thought.  A
	number of families, mostly Glendenning rather than Glendinning, came
	to New Brunswick in the early 1800’s and all seem to have come
	from Dumfriesshire.  They settled near Bathurst, Saint John, Rexton,
	Sussex, Woodstock and in the Port Elgin area. Although I expect a

Thinking
of you at Christmas!











                       Little
Branch, N.B. (Undated)












From
our home to your home!







Greetings:







As I
write, I am looking into our back yard and thinking “What a
beautiful morning”. The sun is shining, temperature about five
degrees and hardly a cloud in the sky.  Shortly, I will head to the
country for a walk in the woods.








The year
was a good one and included a Christmas cruise at the end of 2010, a
hip replacement in April for Carol, visits from Brian, Janet,
granddaughter Laura and Cory, attendance at the annual Glendenning
Family Reunion (our 34th),
and a visit in October with Brian and Marie in New Mexico with the
added joy of having Granddaughter, Lisa, come home while we were
there.  While in the west, we also travelled to Sonoma, California to
visit the wine country.








There
are no significant changes in our lives since I last wrote except
that Janet and Mike are now married and living in Ottawa and Laura is
living and paying taxes in Maryland. Lisa continues her studies in
Seattle where Kevin handles our Amazon accounts, Brian continues to
improve our knowledge of the universe and Marie keeps the NRAO
computers running, Janet keeps an eye on how our taxes are spent
while Mike learns how to shovel Canadian snow.  I still plant a
garden, go to my woodlot, and do a bit of volunteer work, my Holland
College Recollections are finished and I have no intention of
publishing them but they can be found on the Glendenning website.








Carol
had a full recovery from her hip operation, is back in her bridge
routine, enjoys her IPod (thanks to Brian and Marie) and generally
keeps on the go.  Her flower garden this year was one of the best
ever, while my vegetable was one of the poorest.  Our only confirmed
travel plans at the moment is for three weeks on Treasure Island in
Florida in early March.

photo at the left showing the Little Branch School, with a snowplow

LOCAL HISTORY PUBLICATIONS

by

Publications:




1	Glendenning Roots - Background and photos on the life and times of Elmer and Jane (Watling) Glendenning with a focus on their years in the USA.  It also lists ancestors for each as well as their descendants.  (Approximately 200 pages bound.)




Carol Louise (Chesney) Glendenning - Background information and photos of Carol Chesney, her family and friends in Illinois.  (Approximately 100 pp bound)




Family Chronicles; Volumes 1 and 2 – Copies of an informal newsletter intended to share with siblings the latest findings about relatives and ancestors.  Later Chronicles morphed into recollections of life and times of the author growing up in Black River, New Brunswick, especially in the period preceding WW2.  Each newsletter was two pages; each volume includes 100 newsletters.  Newsletters are also available on line at   HYPERLINK "http://www.glendenning.net/don" www.glendenning.net/don.  (Approximately 200 pp each volume, bound)  




The Neighbourhood - At the beginning of WW2, there were about 120 households along the Black River in Northumberland County, New Brunswick.  This volume identifies heads of households and their offspring; children are identified even though many had married and left home.  The volume also provides ancestor charts, where known, for many of the heads of households.  (Approximately 325 pages bound)




Presbyterians in Black River – starting with the early church history from the book, Black River and Its Early Settlers by A. W. MacDougall, (used with permission of the family), this book describes the worship of Presbyterians after Church Union in 1925.  (Approximately 60 pages bound)

summary: A 2011 Foundation brochure covering governance, achievements, and complete portfolio fund listings including the Glendenning Family Fund. Reiterates the organization's commitment to perpetuity-based charitable giving and transparent stewardship of community resources.
content_preview:
THE FOUNDATION







The Community Foundation of PEI is a volunteer driven, registered, non-profit, charitable organization. Our mission is to improve quality of life on PEI through the creation and building of endowment funds that will help ensure vital futures for Island communities.




The Community Foundation of PEI provides an established means for individuals, families, community groups, corporations, and private foundations to support philanthropic activities which invest in sustainable solutions to community needs. We connect people who care with causes that matter.







The Community Foundation of PEI honours the vision and wisdom of donors and guides disbursements according to their wishes. We facilitate and simplify donor-directed giving and help establish endowments in perpetuity. We manage trust funds with diligence and transparency and adhere to conventional reporting practices.






















I am impressed with the ability of the foundation to design funds that reflect both donor interests and community needs – Dr. Thomas Hall













ACHIEVEMENTS




Ongoing annual Scholarship and Granting awards

Investment portfolio reached $1,000,000

Hosted a number of events to build a network of Summer Islanders interested in  giving back to their adopted home;

Organized  capacity building and leadership workshops for the charitable sector

Completed an $800,000 project  to help arts and heritage organizations gain long term stability

Awarded $100,000 in capacity building grants to various PEI non-profits over a three year campaign

Leading agency in the design of charitable endowments




SPECIAL NOTE FOR US CITIZENS




CFPEI offers the following services to US citizens:




Receipts acceptable to the US Internal Revenue Service

Anonymity, if desired 

Flow through to charity of choice

A single donation to CFPEI can be distributed to a number of charities of your choice.

title: 2012-Black River Anniversary-2
summary: Speaking notes by Don Glendenning for 200th anniversary of Black River lot grants (June 2, 2012). Traces early settlement patterns from First Nations through Scottish immigration, American Revolution Loyalists, and clan disruptions—demonstrates his deep knowledge of regional history and family roots.

Notes




200th
Anniversary


Granting
of Lots along the Black River


June
2, 2012






A
Opening comments

	


	Delighted
	to be here
	


	Commend
	the planners
	


	Proud
	of my roots
	


	Important
	to be aware of our roots
	


	Honour
	our forebears
	


	Not
	an historian but have an interest
	


	Believe
	what I tell you to be true, but always open to new information
	


	A
	W MacDougall
	


	Ernie
	MacLean, 
	
	


	Passport-Little
	Branch







B
Who were our early settlers?






	


	First
	nations
	


	French
	fishermen came ashore at mouth of Miramichi in the 1500s;
	fur-trading settlement on Bay du Vin Island by mid – 1660’s;
	Gardiners Point had settlement of at least 15 families by 1750’s;
	French settlers at Hardwicke about the same time; most French
	settlers driven out by 1758; no evidence that either aboriginal or
	French settlers along the Black River.








	


	Scotland
	– some major strains; in mid-1700’ss clan system was destroyed,
	clans were broken up, could not wear tartans or carry arms leases
	were terminated and estates were converted to sheep farms to take
	advantage of soaring mutton prices, people left in droves for North
	Amertica where settlers could own their own land and it was free or
	cheap.




















	


	American
	Revolution – 1776;  people who had fought on side of the British
	and wanted to remain part of British North America; known as United
	Empire Loyalists; came by the boat to Nova Scotia which included
	what is now New Brunswick; mostly during period !785-1795; first
	permanent settlers; fought on side of British, after American
	revolution, many were well educated, had been successful leaders in
	their community, business men, government officials; dramatic
	reduction in the size of the military.








	


	Many
	Loyalists settled in Canada just north of the St Lawrence River. As
	you would expect, most landed at Halifax or St. John; most were
	given grants in in central Nova Scotia or Southern New Bru...

title: 2012-Reunion-Elmer and Jane (Minor edit 2018}
summary: Comprehensive biography of Don's parents Elmer Alton Glendenning (1875-1938) and Jane Elizabeth Jardine Watling (1890-1964), tracing their families from New Brunswick/England origins through their careers in hydroelectric dam construction and domestic life. Extensively documents family migrations to Portland Maine, Tennessee, and other locations, providing essential genealogical and family history context.
content_preview:
Elmer
and Jane 


Glendenning























































Prepared
by


Don
Glendenning


for


Glendenning
Family Reunion


July
27-29, 2012


Minor
edit 2018


























ELMER
ALTON GLENDENNING


1875-1938








Elmer
was the second child and first son of Walter and Elizabeth (Peters)
Glendenning.  He was born in Canobie on land
that is now a grove of trees directly across the road from the
Canobie School, now the Women’s Institute Hall.   









It
is likely that he went to the one room school, now long gone, located
on a corner of his Uncle John’s farm next door.  The
family seems to have valued education; his grandmother having been a
teacher lived in the home after his Grandfather died.  As further
evidence, his brother, Chip took a business course, Guy studied but
did not finish dentistry and Margaret trained as a nurse.  Other
family records suggest that he may have taken some technical courses,
probably at night in Portland, Maine.  It is known that his oldest
sister, Venetia, provided a home for his sister, Margaret, so that
she could finish high school in Portland and likely did the same for
her brother, Guy, as well.   









Elmer’s
father was a farmer and, judging by the amount of land accumulated, a
successful one at that.  Elmer, and all the boys, and maybe even the
girls, would be expected to do their share.  Since the homestead was
an original grant, the land would have to be cleared of trees, and
those who know Canobie, will remember the stony fields; and all the
work would be done by hand or with the aid of horses.







It
was not uncommon at the time for New Brunswickers to go to the North
Eastern USA during the winter to work in the woods and then return to
farm and fish in the summer and Elmer may have even done that
himself.  We also know, for example, that his Aunt, Mary Ann Harley,
who had married a Stevens and lived next door in Canobie, had moved
to Portland to be with family after her hu...
