title: 2014 Advisory committee@2014-12-03T13;56;57
summary: Documentation of the Glendenning Fund Advisory Committee established to oversee an endowment created by the Glendenning family with the Community Foundation of PEI for supporting community development projects in Black River Bridge, New Brunswick. This reflects Don's dedication to giving back to his ancestral community through charitable giving.
content_preview:
GLENDENNING FUND 

Advisory Committee




In the year 2000, the Glendenning Family established an endowment with the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island for the purpose of providing financial support for projects that contribute to the quality of life of residents of Black River Bridge, Northumberland County, New Brunswick. 

An Advisory committee has been struck to implement the wishes of the family as to the nature of activities and projects to be supported.  Advisory Committee members include:

  
Lois Anne (Glendenning) Gregan, Chair, 325 Hardwicke Road, Hardwicke, NB E9A 1L5
  
Donna (Russell) Goodfellow, PO Box 114, Upper Kent, NB, E0J 1Y0
  
Amanda (Taylor) Manuel, 7903 Rte. 117, Black River Bridge, NB, E1N 5K7





The Committee:

  
Shall be known as  the Glendenning Fund Advisory Committee
  
Shall be comprised of three members, preferably descendants of Elmer and Jane (Watling) Glendenning in whose memory the fund was established.
  
Will make reasonable efforts to inform and involve other descendants informed.
  
Will focus on how decisions will impact the quality of life in the community.
  
Will maintain a record of actions and recommendations
  
Will encourage contributions to the Fund

title: 2014-Letter-
summary: 2014 Christmas letter detailing year of health, mobility, and independence. Don describes annual foray into PEI wilds to cut spindly balsam fir Christmas tree. Notes Charlottetown received record 20-25 cm snow. Don and Carol grateful for good health, Carol with bridge and book club, Don with vegetable garden and letters to editor/coffee group meetings. Mentions they didn't leave PEI over winter (Carol had medicine change, insurance concerns). May trip to Pennsylvania. Cottage summer highlighted by family visits. Family photo from 2012 at cottage flagpole: Don, Carol, Brian, Mike, Janet (Marie photographer). Granddaughters Lisa/Kevin in Seattle, Laura in Columbia Maryland. Brian and Marie home August, Janet early September (first visit since seeing granddaughters). Home renovations: painted house, added room, stained cottage, replaced fridge, wall oven repair. Brian and Janet recently returned from 3-week India sojourn. Note: file shows text corruption with embedded formatting.
content_preview:
Christmas
Greetings


 from
the Glendennings


Christmas
2014


	


	
	

	


	
	

	

	

	Home
	

	


	
	

	Dear  
	
	

	


	
	

	As is our custom, we start
	each Christmas season with a review of last year’s cards and,
	while doing so, reminisce about good friends and good times of
	yesteryear.  Each year brings changes to the list but the new
	absences, and there are  several, do not dull the memory of our
	friendships. 
	
	

	


	
	

	The Christmas season was
	officially marked a few days ago by my annual foray into the  wilds
	of PEI to cut my Christmas tree – a rather spindly balsam fir, I
	will admit.  Our snow, some 20-25 centimeters, has come and gone,
	and hours of daylight begin to lengthen in a couple of weeks; my
	candy cane is on the side of the house, my deer stands on the patio
	looking in the window and, as of an hour ago, I draped some lights
	over our burning bush.
	

	


	
	

	We are grateful for good health, mobility, and
	independence – Carol with bridge, book club, and circle of
	friends; Don with his 
	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	summer vegetable garden and interest education;
	most of Don’s time appears to be spent in creating letters to the
	editor and having coffee with others of the same mind. 
	
	

	


	
	

	We did not leave PEI last
	winter; Carol had had a change in her medicine and our out of
	country insurance would not cover us.  We did get away for a couple
	of weeks in May and travelled  as far as Pennsylvania.  The
	highlight of our summer was time at the cottage and visits  from
	family.  
	
	

	


	
	

	

	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	The above family photo, Don,
	Carol, Brian, Mike and Janet (Marie took the photo)  was actually
	taken in 2012 beside the flagpole at our cottage.  Granddaughter,
	Lisa, and husband, Kevin, live in Seattle while other Granddaughter,
	 Laura, lives in Columbia, Maryland.  Brian and Marie were home for
	a couple of weeks in early August and Mike and Janet in early
	September.  It is a couple of y...

title: 2014 Notes to Committee 2014
summary: Dated December 3, 2014, from Don to Amanda, Donna, and LoisAnne. Fund market value reached $20,200 (original contributions $14,000+; remainder from investment returns). Provides copies of original agreement and amendment. Explains committee's role and Community Foundation's investment track record. Notes annual payout is typically 4% ($800 in 2014), but practice has been to spend less to promote growth (now committee's decision). Requests signed amendment returns to Foundation. Demonstrates Don's personal mentorship of committee members and his satisfaction with results.
content_preview:
December 3, 2014




To:	Amanda

	Donna

	LoisAnne

Glendenning Fund




Trust all is well and that the recent storm was not too unkind.




We spoke some time ago about the Glendenning Fund; it was established shortly after our 2000 Family reunion; our original target was $5,000 and, if we were lucky, perhaps $10,000.  I phoned a few minutes ago and was told that the market value of the fund today is $20.200; the actual contributions were a bit over 14,000 – the remainder resulted from returns on investment.  On top of that, we made some grants.




Enclosed is:

  
A copy of the original agreement
  
A copy of the amendment
  
Some notes on  the role of the Committee





We chose the Community Foundation to host our fund because that is what community foundations do, and because they have an excellent investment record.  I always thought that one day, there would be a community foundation in the Miramichi and the fund would be transferred to them.  Given PEI’s investment record, one shouldn’t be hasty in making a transfer.




Each year, you will be advised as to how much is available for granting purposes – usually 4% which this year would mean $800; our practice, as Lois Anne knows, has been to use less  than what is available in order to grow the Fund – but that decision is now up to you.




Please sign one copy of the amendment, (as donors) and return it to the Foundation; I’d just sign it separately rather than trying to get all three signatures on the same copy




You should deal directly with the Foundation from now on but let me know if I can help in any way




Thanks for agreeing to act and enjoy being a philanthropist




Don

title: 2015-Christmas Letter-@2015-12-08T18;23;18
summary: A heartfelt Christmas letter from Don and Carol reflecting on their year at age 86, including travel to Cuba and Victoria BC, summer cottage life, family visits including grandchildren, and continued good health and community involvement. The letter reveals Don's appreciation for family, travel, gardening, and maintaining deep connections across a lifetime.
content_preview:
Christmas
Greetings


 from
the Glendennings


Christmas
2015


	


	
	

	


	
	

	

	

	Cuba 2015
	

	


	
	

	Dear  
	
	

	


	
	

	Time to reminisce and write a
	Christmas note to family and friends.  
	
	

	


	
	

	We’ve had another good
	year.  We are still together, able to live in our own home, have
	reasonably good health and drive ourselves to most places – except
	after dark. Yes, we have our share of aches and pains, newspaper
	print is smaller than it once was, messages travel a bit slower to
	our brains and limbs, stairs have gotten steeper and most nights
	appear foggy. But we are here and functioning so what more could we
	ask?  
	
	

	


	
	

	I’ve always enjoyed
	puttering around and doing the chores but last year I decided to
	hire someone to shovel our walk; it was a good  decision in that
	Charlottetown set a record – 16 feet of snow.  And I’ve always
	cut my own Christmas tree but his year decided to purchase one.  It
	is a nice little tree but not nearly as nice as the ones I brought
	home in past years.
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	Thanks to Janet, we spent a
	week in Havana last February.  Janet was a great guide and 
	
	

	


	
	

	made sure that we got around.
	 Although Havana is run down, one can still imagine what it must
	have been like in its hey day
	

	


	
	

	In late April we spent a
	couple of weeks in Victoria, BC; weather was great, we were just one
	block back from the harbour, and we had great accommodation at a
	reasonable rate.  Although we had rented a car, we could walk to the
	museum art gallery and a number of good restaurants. 
	
	

	


	
	

	While in Victoria, our grand
	daughter and her husband, Lisa and Kevin came one weekend for a
	visit:  While they were there, we got around the city a bit and had
	a visit to Bouchart Gardens.
	

	


	
	

	It was also great to visit
	with Laine Warden, who we hadn’t seen for 40 years.  Laine and
	Bill were friends from our Ottawa days.  Their oldest child, Tommy
	and ou...

title: 2018-Family Publications

content_preview:
GENEALOGY AND LOCAL HISTORY

By 

Don Glendenning




1	Glendenning Roots - Background and photos on the life and times of Elmer and Jane (Watling) Glendenning with a focus on their years in the USA.  It also lists ancestors for each as well as their descendants.  (Approximately 200 pages bound.)




Carol Louise (Chesney) Glendenning - Background information and photos of Carol Chesney, her family and friends in Illinois.  (Approximately 100 pp)




Family Chronicles; Volumes 1 and 2 - An informal newsletter intended to share with siblings the latest findings about relatives and ancestors.  Later the chronicle morphed into recollections of life and times of the author growing up in Black River, New Brunswick, especially in the period preceding WW2.  Each chronicle has two pages; each volume includes 100 newsletters; chronicles are also available on line at   HYPERLINK "http://www.glendenning.net/don" www.glendenning.net/don.   




The Neighbourhood - At the beginning of WW2, there were about 120 households along the Black River in Northumberland County, New Brunswick.  This volume identifies heads of households and their offspring; children are identified even though many had married and left home.  The volume also provides ancestor charts, where known, for many of the heads of households.  (Approximately 325 pages)




John Glendinning – my great, great grandfather born Dumfriesshire, Scotland about 1755.




Presbyterians in Black River, NB – starting with the early church history rom “Black River and Its Fist Settlers by A. W, MacDougall, (Included with permission of the Family} describes the worship of Presbyterians in Black River after 1925.




Jubal Watling – my great, great grandfather born in Brockdish, England about 1790




My Life and Times – Recollections by Lillian (Glendenning) Weeks prepared in 1975-76 at the urging of her sister, Grace

title: 2022 Christmas letter
summary: Don's 2022 Christmas letter reflecting on nostalgia for his mother and the importance of Christmas in his family's history. He recalls his parents' moves through Wisconsin, Texas, Alabama, Tennessee, New Hampshire, Connecticut, Maine during their early married years. Don reports having a light case of COVID while Carol remained unaffected. He recounts Brian's retirement and new travels (including Egypt and Jordan), Janet's visits to Washington and Middle East, and family time at the Orwell Bay cottage. Don mentions PEI's September hurricane, which left them without electricity for seven days and damaged trees on their property. He remains engaged with retired friends' coffees, education work, and family tree projects. Handwritten by Don.
content_preview:
Christmas Greetings

 from Carol and Don

Christmas 2022

_____________________________________________________________________________________________

.GREETINGS ACROSS THE MILES:




‘Tis that time of year again. 




We are looking forward to Christmas 2022. Beautiful fall weather, long evenings, occasionally a lighted fireplace and great memories of family and friends. What a great time of year.




 I also think of my Mother and how she treasured this time of year and the Christmas cards and notes.  Dad and Mum spent the first 10 years of married life moving from worksite to worksite in Wisconsin, Texas, Alabama, Tennessee, New Hampshire, Connecticut, Maine and perhaps a few others. Christmas ws a special time for her.




Another good year.  We are still here, still together, still in our own home and mostly managing on our own with the help of local restaurants and meal suppliers .I had a light case of Covid but Carol has escaped so far.




Carol is doing fine, she looks after herself around the house but needs to rest quite a bit. She no longer tends her garden but we managed to spend July and August  at our cottage.  




Brian and Marie, Janet and Mike spent   time with us at the cottage this summer; it is so peaceful atching the sunsets and the tranquil Orwell Bay. It is such a eautiful setting with the red cliffs on all sides of us. Five of the originals still summer there, plus a number of their offspring.  How fortunate we are!




PEI suffered a devasting hurricane in September.  We were without electricity for seven days; we also lost some trees in our back yard. Fortunately no one was hurt.  Janet came home for a week to tend out on us,




Children. grandchildren and great Granddaughter keep well but live too far away. We are thankful that all keep well and Marie keeps us  up to date with photos.




Think I reportrd last year on Brian’s retirement. He and Marie bought a camper trailer and travel in Western USA. They just returned from a trip yo ...

summary: "The Family Chronicle" No. 26, July 9, 2002, written by Don Glendenning. Focuses on Watling family roots with sections on: the origin of the Watling name (from Sussex, England; possible Viking/Norman connections); three generations of Jubal Watlings (the first born in Suffolk, married Susan Leach in 1814; Jubal II born 1823, came to Black River ca. 1850, married Christina MacNaughton, died 1900; Jubal III born 1846, married Grace MacDonald); the Leech/Leitch family; Captain George Watling the "pious pirate" of the Bahamas; and James Fowlie (1829-1923), a Presbyterian minister and science professor. Contains genealogical detail on Don's direct ancestors and their migrations from England to Canada.
content_preview:
The Family Chronicle

No.26										    July 9, 2002

                                                                                                                                  __________

My search for Watling roots has been less extensive than that on the Glendenning side, nevertheless, I will record what I have and add as time and energy permit.  Some time ago, Edith (MacKenzie) Schickle gave me a copy of information given to her by Ernie Watling.  Much of the information which follows comes from that source although I have been able to augment it from other sources.




Origin of Name




The first record of the name was found in Sussex, England somewhere between London and Dover.  It is likely that the name arises from Wartling which was a hamlet in the area but others believe that it was associated with Watling Road, the great Roman Road, which started near Dover, passed through Canterbury , turned north at London and went as far as St Albans     It is thought, that the Watlings were Vikings who landed in Northern Scotland in 870 AD, invaded northern France in 910 AD and then came to England with William the Conqueror in 1066.  The name is found in the Domesday Book which was a census taken in England in 1086.




By the time of Richard 1, the Watling name had spread north to Watlingford in Oxfordshire, Watlington in Norfolk, Essex and Hertfordshire.  Many Norman families moved north to Scotland in the 12th century and this may have included some Watlings.




Watling is thought to share the same roots as Whatling, Watlington, Watlingtone, Whatlington, Whatlingtone, Wadling, and Wadlingdon.  Over time, the name spread into the northern parts of England and to Scotland as well.

Kinsmen of the family Watling who came to North America include Ffrances Watling who settled in Virginia in 1660, John Watling who landed in America in 1753, James Watling settled in Philadelphia in 1842 and Mary Watlington who settled in Antigua in 1679.  Some Watlings moved to...

summary: "The Family Chronicle" No. 29, October 17, 2002, written by Don Glendenning. Opens with a touching poem titled "Mothers" signed "JWG Oct. 1934" (Don's mother, Jane Watling Glendenning), which was rediscovered at a family reunion through Ruth Lewis. Includes genealogical corrections about Watling roots using census and land petition records, documenting Jubal Watling Sr.'s 1814 marriage and migration to Black River via Cape Breton; mentions visits to Wausau, Wisconsin (where Don's father worked in 1910) and a book called "Glendinning" by Pamela Ferguson about a rum runner. Showcases Don's role preserving family poetry and documenting family movements.
content_preview:
The Family Chronicle

No.29										    October 17, 2002

                                                                                                                                  __________






MOTHERS




The lamp is lit in the window

And back of it is her chair

And as I look across, it seems

She surely must be there.




I picture too her little room

So very neat and snug

Her very fingers made it so

Oh yes, the braided rug.




The cushion on her rocking chair,

The quilt upon her bed,

Her dresser with the many things

Her very hands had spread.




I pull apart the curtains

Her mark again I see

Her dresses hung up neatly

Yes, as neatly as can be.




And as I sit and ponder

A picture there I see

It’s of my Mother’s Mother

Whose room it used to be




Yes, patient, tireless Mother

Who gave to their world their best

Your children call you blessed

God’s love made manifest.




And when my work on earth is done

And I have crossed the Bar

God grant that I may enter in

Where those dear Mothers are.

			JWG

			Oct. 1934




Family members remembered seeing some of my Mother’s poetry but none of it survived.  At a family reunion a few years ago, Ruth (MacNaughton) Lewis mentioned having a poem written by my mother and, subsequently, she sent the above poem to me.  This poem was written about a month after her mother died.
















Watling Roots




My information about the earliest Watlings was the Jubal Watling was married to Susan Leach, that he came from Suffolk, England, was married in 1814, had a son, Jubal who was born about 1823.  (The census of 1851 shows Jubal as age 28)  Thanks to Tina (Watling) Newton, we have a bit more factual information about the Watlings. Based on the above and additional information gathered from the Roger Watling website, here are my conclusions.

 

Jubal Watling, born in 1823 in Syleham, Suffolk, England, He was the son of Jubal Watling and Susan Leach. 




Jubal Watling married Susan Leach in M...

title: 3-Introduction
summary: Don's introduction to "Glendenning Family Memories" (June 16, 2005) explaining the genesis and scope of his genealogical research. Describes early fascination with Black River family relationships (late 1940s), expansion from Glendenning roots to include Peters, Sealey, Harley, Bidders, Beattie, Rae, MacDonald, Watling, MacAskill, MacNaughton, Leach, and Jardine ancestry. Details research methods: family Bible, surveys, census data, newspapers, church/cemetery records, internet searches, family interviews. References ~4,000 names in database, extensive photo collections from mother Jane and sister Venetia. Acknowledges siblings' contributions and thanks family/friends. Emphasizes incompleteness of genealogical work and invites reader participation. Reveals Don's scholarly approach and collaborative philosophy. Crucial for understanding his intellectual motivation and methodology.
content_preview:
INTRODUCTION







My father and mother came from large and close families; visits and visitors were frequent and family ties were emphasized and strong.  At an early age, I became intrigued by the number of neighbours along the length of the Black River to whom I was related.  By the late 1940’s I began gathering information about my ancestors.  




Information was drawn from many sources with the Glendenning Family Bible in my Mother’s possession being my entry point into the field.  Shortly thereafter, I conducted a survey on my father’s side of the family.  By then, I was hooked although my information gathering was sporadic, at best.  The benefit of computer based technology and a new spurt of information gathering after retirement resulted in a cabinet full of files, scraps of paper on every flat surface in my basement and a database containing nearly 4,000 names.  The conclusion reached as a youngster in Black River has been borne out; at that time I was related to most people in the community.




My focus has been broad rather than narrow.  By that, I mean, I am interested in the broad picture of who I am rather than pursuing only my Glendenning roots.  As a result, I have since learned that, in addition to my Glendenning ancestry, I am also a descendant of folks named Peters, Sealey, Harley, Bidders, Beattie, Rae, MacDonald, Watling, MacAskill, MacNaughton, Leach and Jardine.  And if I were to reach back further, I would find other ancestors as well.  




This document does not pretend to be a history of the family; instead, it is a record of what I learned during my search; a history would be more thorough and complete.  If a lead interested me I followed it.  As a result the amount of information on each individual or family varies greatly.  




I believe the included information to be accurate but I am sure that there are mistakes; if I knew what the mistakes were, I would have corrected them.  When in doubt, I prefaced my remarks with “I think” or ...

summary: Family Chronicle (No. 35, February 28, 2003) featuring reader follow-ups and nostalgic recollections. Confirms the family card game "Flinch" originated with his sister Grace. Clarifies "Ken's Hill" geography near Little Branch School—identifies Ken MacDonald property and Weldon MacDonald's bungalow. Includes an anecdote about classmate Ken's comment on "slipgut" porridge in health class, and stories about John's 1939-42 Ford truck service transporting community members to town, including a skunk strike and a recovered set of false teeth. Recounts Don's first dance (summer 1946) with Norma Williston at Black River Hall, followed by frequent dances 2-3 times weekly. Includes portrait of Jim Finno (a blind neighbor with prized transparent apples) and a failed theft attempt that resulted in Don's sprained ankle. Captures small-town social life and youthful adventures.
content_preview:
The Family Chronicle

No.35										   February 28, 2003

                                                                                                                                 ________________Follow-up




Donna (Russell) Goodfellow confirms that their flinch Game came from my sister, Grace.  I must now conclude that Flinch was a game unique to our family.  Parker Brothers still sells the game; I bought two games yesterday.




Dorothy (MacKay) Lind wondered about Ken’s Hill.  As one left the Little Branch School heading for Loggieville, one passed the Jim Finno property.  It was a large two-story home in a long lane and near the river.  From the turn to the brook was what we called the “Finno property.”  Dad had bought it from Jim Finno many years ago.  Still traveling towards Loggieville, one climbed “Ken’s Hill”.  On the right, towards the shore, stood the Ken MacDonald house.  Further along, still on the right hand side of the road, was a small bungalow built originally, I believe, by Weldon MacDonald.  Ken and Cameron MacDonald were Weldon’s sons.  As a matter of interest, Cameron retired back to Black River and built a home on the hill where the Ken MacDonald property once stood.




I’ve also heard the breakfast story.  During a health class, the teacher was asking students what they had for breakfast.  Ken is reported to have said “Some mornings we have porridge and some mornings we have "slipgut”,  Slipgut was a term used for porridge made from home grown wheat ground into flour.  (At one time there was a gristmill up the Branch but in my time, grain was taken to the “Monks” in Rogersville to be ground)




The Ford truck




On Saturday, we finished work early and went in town; stores were open until nine.  John usually picked up a number of people from around Black River and took them to town; he also brought them back home usually sometime after 10:00 or eleven o’clock.  The truck had a covered box and often there would be 10 or more people c...

summary: Family Chronicle (No. 39, April 26, 2003) including undated photo of Don's father Elmer and his lumber crew (assumed USA-based). Features reader follow-ups: Donald Edge's memory of grandfather's sawmill and pitch-covered hands; Earl Taylor's similar experience at Fowlie's mill; Shirley MacKay's story of being flipped off a load of logs under a clothesline into a snowbank; and corrections about Uncle George's locations (Tennessee, Virginia/Hampton, New Hampshire). Introduces "The Woodcutter" section describing family wood-cutting operations—seasonal harvesting of furnace and firewood, use of horse-drawn bobsleds, specialized equipment (circular saw, engine-driven), and community labor exchanges. Illustrates the interconnected rural economy and Don's deep knowledge of traditional farm operations.

title: 4-A Chronology
summary: A master chronology spanning 1772–1964 documenting births, deaths, and marriages of Don's ancestors across five generations. Lists key family events including arrival of Great Grandfather John Glendinning from Scotland in 1830, settlement at Canobie and Salmon Beach, emigration to USA (Portland, Maine; Tennessee; Wisconsin), and return to Little Branch, New Brunswick. Notable: Don's birth September 8, 1929 at Little Branch; parents' deaths in 1938 (father) and 1964 (mother). Compiled by Don Glendenning in June 2005.

summary: Family Chronicle (No. 40, May 10, 2003) providing research resources for Crown Land history in New Brunswick (Crown Land Grant Index, maps, Geographical Names reference). Includes genealogical follow-up correcting a photo identifier (Norman Ferguson, grandson of Cynthia Finno and Hector Ferguson—Don's second cousin). Supplies revised list of 13 teachers at Little Branch School (1920s-1950s), noting lapses in documentation. Recalls coasting accident with Fraser MacKay (sled riding over birch tree, tumbling to shore ice), trout fishing techniques using alder rods and worms from the wharf and bridge, anecdote about Major Ramsay (tetchy NB Tel employee), and Billy Harper as skilled fisherman mentor. Mentions white string fishing line soaked in strong tea to reduce visibility, and an experimental fish net strung across the river (catching one gasperaux). Demonstrates Don's capacity for both archival scholarship and vivid sensory memoir.

title: 5 Little Branch
summary: A 1929 account of Little Branch School, where Don was born that same year (September 8, 1929). The school was erected around 1850 in District 71/2, Parish of Glenelg, serving students from the Branch Road area with 50 students during 1933-34. This document directly connects to Don's birthplace and childhood community, representing both personal and regional history research.
content_preview:
Little Branch – 1929







Little
Branch School






The
Little Branch School sits at the junction of Route 117 and the Little
Branch Road (formerly the MacKenzie Road).  A. W. MacDougall in his
book, Black River and
its First Settlers,
tells us that the first school was erected about 1850; it burned
shortly thereafter but was soon replaced.   The Little Branch School
was in District 71/2 in the Parish of Glenelg Parish in
Northumberland County.  An out door toilet, with separate doors for
boys and girls, can be seen perched over the cove just beyond the
school.






The
Little Branch Schools served children from along the Branch Road,
Hexham to the end of the Victoria Bridge and along the south side of
the Black River as far as the community hall.  


During
the year 1933-34, it served 50 students with a few ending their
schooling by Christmas and a few commencing their school starting in
January; the teacher was Donald J. MacLean who held a Second class
license.






In
1939, The Little Branch School became one of seven schools in the
newly-created Miramichi Rural High School district providing
instruction only to the end of Grade Six.  Students in the higher
grades travelled by bus to the newly constructed Miramichi Rural High
School




































	In the case of the Little
	Branch School, there was a little wash room with a pump and sink
	directly beyond the entry to the left.  In my time, however, the
	sink worked but the pump did not so students were designated to take
	turns carrying water from my home to the school.  The shed on the
	right was used to store wood; the double outhouse was further right
	perched on the edge of the bank. 
	
	

	


	
	

	

	

	


	
	

	


	
	

	

	

	Little Branch School in 1929 
	
	

	Thanks to Della Adams ONeil

summary: "The Family Chronicle" No. 59, January 23, 2004, written by Don Glendenning. Contains photographs of his great-great-grandparents Alexander MacDonald (b. 1775, Assynt, Scotland; d. 1843 at Little Branch) and Grace MacAskill (b. 1781, d. 1874); their son John D. MacDonald (1817–1900) and his wife Elspeth Jardine (1821–1907); and John's daughter Grace (Don's grandmother, 1848–1934) who married Jubal Watling. Includes memories of his small, wiry grandmother and anecdotes: George Dutcher's sloven, a WWII fruit truck accident on Johnny Dick's hill, Jack MacMaster's apple truck breaking through a bridge, correspondence with Robert Stevens about the Peters/Harley connection, and childhood stories from Marjorie (Watling) Young about crossing the Little Branch Bridge. References his new website at www.glendenning.net.
content_preview:
The
Family
Chronicle

No.59								
                        January 23,2004

                                               
                                                           
________________







	     
	

	



	
	
    
	

		
	



	
	
    
	

	
Photos
	



	
	
I
	am grateful to Cameron MacDonald for copies of the photos appearing
	on the left.  We are not certain, but they may be my GGGrandparents,
	Alexander and Grace (McAskill) MacDonald, their son, John and his
	wife, Elspeth Jardine.
	



	
	
Alexander
	MacDonald (top left), my GG Grandfather, was born in Assynt,
	Scotland in 1775 and died in Little Branch in 1843.  His wife, Grace
	MacAskill was born in 1781 in Assynt, Scotland and died on February
	23, 1874 in Little Branch.  Alexander MacDonald was granted 225
	acres (Lot No.2) at Little Branch on June 3, 1812.  They had nine
	children.  The original house, I believe, was in the field above
	where Norman Glendenning now lives near the old apple orchard.
	



	
	
John
	D. MacDonald, (centre left) my Great Grandfather, (1817-1900) owned
	the land where Uncle Jim Watling lived; his sister, Jessie, owned
	the land where Norman now lives.  (Each received half of the
	original property)  John married Elspeth Jardine,  (1821 –1907). 
	They had 10 children including a daughter Grace, my Grandmother,
	(1848 – 1934) who married Jubal Watling (1846 – 1915).  Jubal
	and Grace lived for a while at the Meadows but moved to Little
	Branch in 1901.
	



	
	
Again,
	these may or may not be correct but I thought that you would be
	interested.
	
Grandmother
	



	
	
I
	barely remember my Grandmother Watling.  She died in 1934 but I do
	recall her as a small wiry woman.  I can remember her buttoning the

title: 6-Glendenning Roots
summary: Comprehensive genealogical research by Don tracing Glendenning family origins to Dumfriesshire, Scotland (first documented 1286) and settlement in Canobie, New Brunswick. Includes extensive research on ancestral surnames (Beattie, Rae, Harley, Peters, Jardine, MacNaughton), with detailed histories and Scottish place origins. Features a remarkable first-person account by his great-great-grandmother Mary Ann Harley (born 1799 in Ireland) describing her 1822 passage to Canada and 75-mile trek through wilderness to Newcastle. Includes Don's 1989 visit to Callister Hall (Scotland, birthplace of John Glendinning, 1807) and detailed land grant documentation. Major genealogical work authored by Don showing meticulous scholarship and personal research travels.
content_preview:
Glendenning
	Family Memories

	GLENDENNING
ROOTS   

















The Canadian roots of my paternal ancestors are in
an area north east of Bathurst, more precisely, the inland community
of Canobie.  Travelling east from Bathurst along the coast towards
Caraquet, one finds a number of communities familiar to the
Glendenning family.  Most relevant are the following as described in
the Geographical Names of New Brunswick, 1875:






	

Bathurst,
	originally named St. Peters in 1671, was named for the Third Earl of
	Bathurst in 1826. 
	



	

	

Salmon
	Beach
	was settled around 1820 by immigrants from Ireland and included the
	districts of Prospect Hill, Strawberry Plain and Mount Pleasant.  
	







	

Janeville
	was named for Jane Dawson, wife of Benjamin Dawson who settled there
	about 1835.  
	







	

Stonehaven
	was probably named for Stonehaven, Scotland. 
	
	







	

New
	Bandon
	was settled in 1819 by several families from Bandon, Ireland.







	

Canobie
	named  after Canonbie, Dumfriesshire, Scotland.  	












According
to  Pioneer Settlers of the Bay Chaleur, settlement on the coast east
of Bathurst took place by the Acadians in the latter half of the
1700s and, although living on the land, they grants were not given
their grants until 1812.  Apparently, an organized system of granting
of land did not evolve until the 1800s and even then there could be
delays of a decade or more between petitioning land and receiving
land.  Even then, a grant was not final until at least five acres had
been cleared.  The first registered land grants in the area were made
to James Sutherland and his brother Hugh, and to Richard Nevison in
1789.






Once
settled, men began the task of clearing land and erecting a house and
barn.  Trees not needed were stacked, dried and burned.  Few oxen or
horses were available so the land was broken and cultivated with the
aid of a hoe.  The initial crops were planted between the stumps,
which, over time, rotted and were ...

title: 7-Watling Roots
summary: Comprehensive genealogical research by Don on Watling family ancestry and settlements in Black River, New Brunswick. Covers European origins, American Revolution context, and integration into Maritime communities—extensive foundational family history work.
content_preview:
25
	Glendenning Family Memories
	

WATLING
ROOTS


























To the extent
known, this section deals with actual ancestral families and their
locations.  The nature and extent of information for each family or
location varies, reflecting the extent of my search rather that
available information.  In no way should this section be considered a
complete family history.






While we usually
carry the name of the male side of our ancestral family, in fact,
each person is an equal descendant of many other families as well. 
In the writer’s case, he is directly descended on his maternal side
from families named Watling, Leech, MacNaughton, MacDonald, McAskill
and Jardine.  These families reflect Highland and Lowland Scottish
roots.  Of my maternal Great Grandparents, all were Scots except two.
 







The Canadian roots
of my maternal ancestors reside in the community where I was born,
Black River, New Brunswick – a community some 10 miles south and
east of Chatham.  







BLACK RIVER CONNECTIONS











A.
W. MacDougall says that the name Black River, in the MicMac language
is Mat-quan-ti-gook
- a term intended to describe its waters.    MacDougall describes at
least one lot, at McDougall's Point near the mouth of the river,
which was granted to Delesderniere and Marsten prior to 1784.  United
Empire Loyalists came to Black River between 1785 and 1795. 
Following this, there arrived mostly people from Scotland,
highlanders and lowlanders alike, including MacDonalds (McDonalds),
MacNaughtons, McBeaths and MacLeans.  Many came directly from
Scotland while others are thought to have come to the Miramichi via
Cape Breton, Prince Edward Island, or other Maritime ports.






The
Black River flows from west to east and empties into Bay du Vin,
which is part of the Miramichi River.  By 1800, grants had been made
to settlers along the shores from Hexham east.  In 1812, there was a
major push to settle the Black River including the Little Black River
now know...

title: A CLOSE CALLl
summary: Vivid recollection of near-fatal automobile/train collision near Chatham, NB just before Christmas 1938 (year father Elmer died). Don's brother Walter was driving Model A Ford with mother, Don, siblings Grace, Lillian (home from Boston), Kenneth, Norman. Cardboard window blocked view; train approaching from blind side. **Walter accelerated through crossing narrowly avoiding impact.** Captures moment of family danger during vulnerable period and demonstrates Don's narrative storytelling ability.
content_preview:
A CLOSE CALL




It was a day or two before Christmas of 1938, the year Dad died.  Grace and Venetia were married and living away; Lillian had come home from Boston where she was working.  It was a crisp but clear morning; there was snow on the ground but it was well packed and not considered slippery.




Walter slid behind the wheel, Mum got in the front seat with me in the middle.  Lillian, Ken, and Norm sat in the back.   We were off to Chatham for some last minute shopping.  John and Elinor stayed at home.    The window on the passenger side of the Model A had broken and was replaced temporarily with a piece of cardboard.  In those days, one always travelled via Loggieville on the way to Chatham.  




There was not much traffic on the road that morning but between Loggieville and Chatham, we caught up to our neighbours, the Adams family, in their chocolate brown truck; it was a one-ton truck with a wooden box over which a tarpaulin had been tied to protect a few passengers from the winter’s cold.  No doubt, they were also on the way to Chatham for last minute Christmas shopping as well.  




In those days, most towns and villages of any size were served by rail – in our area, by the Canadian National Railways; Loggieville was a terminus for passengers and the point at which local farmers also picked up, among other things, their fertilizer, lime and feed.  Train traffic was certainly not heavy but trains probably travelled that stretch of line 3- 4 times each day.  From Loggieville, the train tracks followed the south side of the road and crossed to the north side just before reaching Chatham.




Christmas was always an exciting time at our house and having Lillian home, I am sure, added to our excitement.  I am sure that all in the car pitched into the conversation.  Suddenly, just as we reached the railway crossing, the sound of an approaching train and a train whistle was heard and a train was bearing down on us from the right, our blind side.  The cardbo...

title: According to my sister Lillian
summary: Don records anecdotal recollections from his sister Lillian about Black River life in early 1900s—cars, school, weather, medical practices, hunting, and family stories. Preserves oral history of regional life and Don's childhood era.
content_preview:
According to my sister Lillian:




An earthquake was felt in Black River in 1925

The person who put on the fire in the Little Branch school received $8.00 for the year

Sleds often carried a lantern hanging on the side so that they could be spotted by other drivers, especially during stormy weather.

Fred Fowlie was the first person to have a car in Black River and Harrison Smith was the first in Bayside.  Malcolm MacNaughton also had a car about the same time.

Dr. MacKenzie was the first one around to have a snowmobile; it was built out of a car and had runners on it.  

If someone needed a doctor, and they knew that Dr. MacKenzie was down river, they would hang a lantern at their gate so that the doctor would know to stop in.

Dad would drive through to Bathurst when there was grass showing in the center of the road

Dad would take the kids down to “Bay du Vin” night at Bernie Williston’s Beach where there would be dancing, fireworks and treats.

Dad used to resole the children’s shoes

Dad and John W. MacNaughton had a “rosser” (for peeling pulpwood)







Cows were allowed to graze along the roads

A cyclone struck Black River in 1932 and blew the roof off Jimmy Major’s barn and also moved the Victoria Bridge on its piers

She was paid one cent for every hundred potato bugs she picked

Uncle Jim Watling had a “Star” car; he sold a device that was supposed to increase gas mileage in cars

Dad had his celluloid collars done at a Chinese laundry in Chatham

Grace taught herself to play the violin

Dad used to work in the canteen when there were dances in the Little Branch school

One year there were 53 children in the Branch school with one teacher

Dad hunted geese at the Finno field and the family had goose for Thanksgiving dinner

Dad and Harry Glendenning first met at a Farmers and Dairymen Convention in Woodstock, NB.  (Uncle Harry lived in Shediac and, although not related, we visisted back and forth regularly – Ed.)

One of the older children used to wal...

title: AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY
summary: Don documents Agricultural Society No. 103 serving Black River and area farmers. **Father Elmer was Secretary-Treasurer for 18 years; oldest brother Walter succeeded him for another 18 years; two other brothers served as Directors.** Society functioned as bulk-purchasing cooperative handling lime, fertilizer, grass seed, pesticides, binder twine. Father maintained society shed (14x22 feet). Don recalls winter canvassing farmers, rail delivery logistics, unloading crews. **Documents his father's death spring 1938 and Walter's succession.** Reflects on Agricultural Societies' gradual replacement by cooperatives.
content_preview:
AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY







Agricultural Society No. 103 provided an important service to the farmers of Black River and points east.  The society, as well as sister organizations throughout the Province gradually were absorbed in or replaced by agricultural cooperatives.  Their story deserves to be told but, unfortunately, still remains hidden.  Perhaps it has particular significance for me because my father was Secretary Treasurer for 18 years, my oldest brother followed in his footsteps for another 18 years and two other brothers served as Directors.




An Agricultural Society was like a Co-op although members did not own shares.  Farmers at the community level banded together and bought agricultural supplies in bulk and resold them, at a slight profit, to local farmers.  As I recall, the Society handled such things as lime, fertilize, grass seed and perhaps some of turnips, mangles and xx.  Initially fertilizers, nitrogen, potash and phosphate, were purchased separately and mixed by each farmer but later fertilizer was purchased premixed.  Seems to me that they also handled some agricultural pesticides or herbicides such as Paris Green and xx.  Perhaps the Society even handled binder twine (which came in wrapped bundles of six or eight rolls each.)




During the winter, farmers were canvassed as to their needs for the coming planting season; their needs aggregated and then orders were placed. Lime and fertilizer was ordered by the ton (by the boxcar) either loose or bagged.  It came to the railroad station in Loggieville (about 11 miles from where I lived) and farmers came individually with their teams and truck wagons, loaded what they had ordered, and moved it to their respective farms.  Sometimes it was taken loose and other times it was bagged; taking it loose was cheaper.  When the lime or fertilizer “came in”, farmers awaiting their supply, were phoned and to come for their orders.  It had to be picked up quickly otherwise there was a daily charge by the...

title: Alexander MacDonald Property
summary: A short document based on A. W. MacDougall's "Black River and Its First Settlers" (1935), documenting Alexander MacDonald's land acquisition at Little Branch (Lot #3, Third Division) in 1803. Includes a vivid anecdote of MacDonald wading across a creek to extend his land grant while surveyors followed by canoe. Speculates on property locations relative to current residents (Norman Glendenning, Neil Watling, Uncle Jim) and discusses the division of property between his son John and daughter Jessie, with dates of property transfers and Don's father's 1912 purchase of Jessie's property. Shows Don's detailed local knowledge and family connections to the land.
content_preview:
Alexander MacDonald Property




The following was taken from the book by A. W. MacDougall.




AAlexander MacDonald came from the Highlands with the 1803 immigration.  He settled on Lot #3 of the Third Division, on the west side of the southwest branch of Black River...




It has been told of the elder Mr MacDonald , that when the Government Surveyors were allotting the land to the prospective settlers, he was told to proceed along the shore till he had secured a sufficient frontage for his lot, the surveying party following him downstream in a canoe.  Land being plentiful, Mr. MacDonald decided to secure as large a grant as possible.  After he had gone a considerable distance, his further progress was barred by a creek, but he plunged in and waded across, only to be brought to a halt on the other side by the government men, who considered that he had already acquired sufficient.@  (Would this be Miller=s Brook?)

I have not searched the titles but believe that the Alexander MacDonald property would be the properties now owned by Norman Glendenning I have not searched the titles but believe that the Alexander Macdonald lproperty would be the properties now owned by Norman Glendenning and Neil Watling.  




I do not know, but it is likely that the Alexander MacDonald home was located above the home now occupied by Norman Glendenning.  There was a depression, like that from an old basement, near the orchard.  Since the Little Branch River provided transportation, it would make sense to be close to the water.  Lillian recalls old lumber piled in the field roughly in that area.  It is possible, however, that the house was actually in the next field above the orchard (Uncle Jim=s field).  At one time there was a pump in this field.




If I=m correct, half the property was given to or purchased by his son John and the other half passed to or was purchased by daughter, Jessie (1823-1912).  Dad bought Jessie=s property in 1912.

title: Alexander Watling
summary: Genealogical background document on Alexander Watling. File listed among Family Tree Maker files suggests this may be ancestral research on the Watling family. Given that Don's cemetery contact at Black River was "Neil Watling," this indicates research into local Black River/New Brunswick family connections, possibly ancestral to Don's own heritage or related to his community roots.
content_preview:
From: "Judy Watling" <watlingj@nbnet.nb.ca>
To: <don@glendenning.net>
Subject: Genealogy
Date: April 30, 2008 5:27 PM

Hi Don :

Thanks for sending me your chart - I've attached my descendant file for Alexander Watling - it should add to your names and dates. I picked up on a couple of differences that I'll mention :

- You named 11 children for Alex and Catherine - actually ,there were 12 . The 12th child was Jane Mclean Watling (1879-1881) .She died in 1881 along with 2 of her siblings, Albert and Peter (1 from each set of twins) all within weeks of each other. There was some sort of epidemic - possibly scarlet fever.

- You list a Rodney Watling as a child of John Gordon Watling and Myrtle May Dempsey (my grandparents). I don't know who he is, but he certainly isn't one of my fathers siblings!

- You have Peter Watling (child of Alex & Catherine) as having died in 1947 and leaving 2 children.  As I mentionned above ,Peter died 1n 1881.  The 1947 death date and 2 children actually belong to James Petrie Watling which you have right later in your file.

Unfortunately ,I don't know Emily/Emmas wedding date -like you ,I only know her husbands name, William Eddy. I do have them listed as having a child named Amos. Were you aware of him ?

Hope this info and descendant file is of help to you - please don't hesitate to contact me if you'd like further information or pictures.


Judy Watling�

title: Appendices
summary: Table of contents/organizational document for supporting materials in a larger family history project. Lists four appendices: A) Autograph Album (entries 1910-1915 with addresses from Portland, ME and various locations); B) Household Record Book (first year after marriage, Portland, ME to Parksville, TN); C) Clippings and copies (newspaper articles featuring Elmer and Jane); D) Photos (integrated throughout text). Technical organizational note rather than biographical content. Third-party reference/research framework.
content_preview:
APPENDIX













A	Autograph Album




Among Mother’s mementoes, was a hard-covered, maroon-coloured autograph album.  The first entry was by E. A. Glendenning on September 18, 1910 in which he gave his address as Wausau, Wisconsin.  I wonder if it was a memento brought to her when he returned from Wausau but prior to their wedding. 




The next entry is on December 1, 1910, after their marriage, in which she gave her address as Bonny Eagle, Maine; then there are a number of entries in December and January just before their departure for Tennessee.  The last entry is at Little Branch on July 9, 1915; this is after Uncle Guy enlisted in Bathurst but before he was inducted in Sussex, NB. 




B	Household Record Book




Mother maintained a household record book during the first year after marriage.  The riest record was made on xxx  in Portland, Maine and continued to Parksville, Tennessee with the last entry being on xxx




C	Clippings and copies




To the extent possible, clippings have been copied and included in the text.  Those that did not seem to fit are included in this appendix.  Clippings include those in which they are featured, clippings of activities in which they were known to be involved or clippings in which they were mentioned..




D	Photos




To the extent possible, relevant photos have been incorporated into the text; others are included in this section.

title: Archibald Cameron Sr.
summary: Comprehensive genealogical chart documenting descendants of Archibald Cameron (b. 1769, Scotland; d. 1861, Black River NB) and Mary McKeller Cameron. Covers nine generations of family lines in Black River, Northumberland County NB area, with detailed birth/death dates, marriage records, occupations, and burial locations. Archibald and Mary emigrated August 1802 to Miramichi with eight sons and three daughters. Includes extensive notes on children (Hugh Ewen, John, Donald, Alexander, Marjorie, James, Murdoch, Christina, Dougald) and their descendants. This genealogy provides family context for understanding Don's heritage and deep roots in the Black River/Miramichi region spanning 200+ years. Third-party genealogical research document.

title: Back to NB
summary: Comprehensive family record documenting Elmer Glendenning's return to Canada (1919) and settlement in Little Branch. Details property acquisitions (1914-1931): Jessie MacDonald property ($800), James Finno land (1924), Dan MacLean property, Bob MacLean property with life tenancy, James Watling property (1926). Describes house renovations using timber from property, barn expansions, and farming operations. Records his postal service role (Nov 1914-Aug 1916). Extensively details his multi-faceted work career: construction (dam at John Godfrey's, Tinker Dam near Woodstock), pulp operations in Middle Black River, lumber camps, bridge building. Captures his personal work ethic (shoe resoling, harness repair, axe handle making), community involvement (founding member St. Paul's Presbyterian Church 1926, Agricultural Society Secretary-Treasurer, Orange Lodge, Oddfellows, Masons). Notes pernicious anaemia diagnosis (~1933), death in 1938. Describes wife Jane's community roles and death from pancreatic cancer (1964). Final anecdote about Uncle Allie MacDonald's recollection working with Elmer, noting his strength and humility. Contains family recollections (not first-person from Elmer, but compiled by Don).
content_preview:
BACK TO NEW BEUNSWICK




Note:	The following random notes were gathered primarily from family and are in random order; hopefully I can both add to them and put them in order at some future date.







Dad purchased the property at Little Branch, where Norman now lives, from Alexander and Ethyl MacDonald on July 21, 1914 for the sum of $800.00.  It was known as the Jessie MacDonald property.  "Miss Jessie" who was a schoolteacher, died in 1912.  This property was directly across the road from where Mum's father and mother lived.  The western property line, starting at the Little Branch School, forms the back property line for many of the properties along Black River.  The rear of the property was known as Jessie's Corner - probably at the rear of either the Godfrey or Gibson property.   While I have not completed my search or county records, I believe that the property passed from John MacDonald to Jessie and on her death from Jessie to her nephew, Alexander MacDonald




The original house, owned by Miss Jessie, was a traditional “story and a half” with a gable roof and built end on to the road.  Dad added an ell, likely in the early 1920’s, suing lumber he cut on the property including a hardwood for the floor.  The space added to the main floor included a large kitchen, pantry, back entry and another stairway to the second floor as well as one to the basement.  Upstairs was added two bedrooms and a large closet/storage room.  It is likely that a new concrete wall was placed under the entire house at the same time.  A veranda was added along the entire length of the house.




The barn was lengthened (doubled) with room for horses, pigs and a haymow.  Lillian remembers Dad up on the roof shingling at daybreak.




Mum came home from Tennessee prior to Walter’s birth in September 1913.  Dad may have come at the same time because work on Ocee #2 ended about that time.  In any case, Post Office records show that Elmer Glendenning was appointed Postmaster on November...

title: Background
summary: Comprehensive background essay (dated January 19, 2005) by Don Glendenning on Scottish and Irish immigration to Canada in the late 1700s–early 1800s. Explains causes: aftermath of the Scottish Rebellion and outlawing of the clan system (1745), wool price increases displacing tenant farmers, religious persecution, and poverty. Details the harsh immigration experience and Grosse Île mortality. Features an extended first-person account from 1897 newspaper interview with Mary Ann Harley (b. 1799, Courtmasherry, Ireland), Don's great-great-grandmother, recounting her 1822 emigration, the Battle of Waterloo celebration, the first steamship in Cork Harbor, her brother William (a government surveyor), her 75-mile walk through forests to Newcastle, and marriage to John Henry. Includes sections on coats of arms, clans, and tartans. Demonstrates Don's scholarly approach to understanding his family's historical context.
content_preview:
BACKGROUND







Introduction




The surge of Scottish settlers in the late 1700’s may be attributed to a number of events.  First was the Scottish Rebellion followed by an outlawing of the clan system by an Act of Parliament in 1745.  Scots were required to take an oath not to carry weapons and never use Highland garb.  Also in the late 1700’s there was a great increase in the price of wool and mutton.  This resulted in tenant farmers being turfed from the land and replaced by large sheep farms.  




It is obvious from my family names that most of my ancestors came from the British Isles - Scotland and England mostly but a few from Ireland as well.  So far, I have not found a Welsh connection.  Of course, if one reaches back a bit further, one then finds a connection to continental Europe.




People left their homes to come to Canada for many reasons including:




escape from political unrest, religious strife and war

getting away from poverty and crowded slums

breaking with the rigid social class structure

start a new adventure and a new life

an alternative to serving time in prison

being forced out as tenant farmers

religious persecution

to become masters of their own fate

see for themselves the land where trees yielded sugar, soap and fuel

taking up land offered at the close of military service.




Immigrants were often at the mercy of promoters, profiteers and land speculators.  The journey by sea was long, overcrowded and difficult; many did not reach the new land.  On Grose Isle, at the mouth of the Saint Lawrence River, over five thousand people who endured the passage lie buried.  




As of the time of writing, I do not know where any of my ancestors they first set foot on solid ground in the new w land.  It is likely, however, that it was Cape Breton, Pictou, Halifax, Saint John, the Miramichi of Baie Chaleur.  The exception to our not knowing is my great grandmother’s sister, Mary Ann Harley.  




Mary Ann Harley was born in Courtmasherry...

title: Beautification  Miramichi
summary: Planning document for "Black River Beautification Awards" program to promote roadside beautification in the Black River community (Northumberland County, NB). Describes community boundaries, volunteer committee structure, beautification criteria (landscaping, painting, etc.), and annual $500 grant from the foundation. Lists issues for consideration including cash prizes, promotion timing, and eligible use of funds. Shows Don's involvement in community beautification initiatives related to his Black River heritage.
content_preview:
Black River Beautification Awards

	___________________________________________________________







  
The community of Black River wishes to promote the beautification of roadside properties within its boundaries. 


 

  
For the purpose of the Award, Black River is described as the community in Northumberland county, New Brunswick situated on both sides of the of Black River and its tributaries between the former Victoria Bridge and the headwaters of the River.





  
To oversee the making of the Award, a volunteer committee will be struck by the community for the purpose establishing the criteria and amounts of the award, and to select or approve the recipients.





  
Beautification is intended primarily for those parts of a property visible from the road and may include planting, trimming and shaping flowers, shrubs, gardens, painting of structures, gardens, gates, fences, hedges, benches 





  
The Award, given annually, will be given to a resident or residents of the community in recognition of efforts to improve the visual impact of their property





  
Each year the Foundation will make a grant, currently in the amount of $500, for the above mentioned purpose. 





  
Revenue Canada requires that the grant be made to a qualified donee.  





Issues:

  
Cash prize(s), banner, trophy
  
Cost of promotion
  
Announced before labour Day weekend
  
What would the money actually be used for?

title: Black River Community Hall
summary: Extensively researched document by Don on Black River Community Hall's history 1930-1973, based on the original account book. Details first hall construction (October 1930-summer 1931, cost ~$1,500), donations by Robertson Orange Lodge and Dorcas Club, volunteer labor, and funding through dances. Horrifyingly documents the August 24, 1932 fire consuming the completed hall. Chronicles second hall construction (1932-1934), 1967 centennial renovations, and February 1973 fire that again destroyed the building. Includes complete financial ledger transcriptions, donor names, builder compensation, and detailed work schedules with family members' participation (Elmer Glendenning, E.A. Glendenning). Shows Don's genealogical connection to community institution-building and archival preservation methods.
content_preview:
Black River Community Hall













	Wanted
	



	
	
A
	photo of the first and second Black River Community Halls






































































Like most communities
of the day, the church and the local school served as centers for
community gatherings.  My sister, Lillian, recalled many dances in
the Little Branch School at which my father volunteered to sell candy
and pop, take tickets, and help with setting up and cleaning up
afterwards.  Many others in the community, I know, could say the same
about their parents and neighbours at their local school.  







This changed in 1931
with the opening of the Black River Community Hall on the same site
as the current building.  Most of the information that follows was
gleaned and interpreted from The Book of Accounts for the Black River
Community Hall for the period 1930 to 1973, newspaper references,
personal knowledge and discussion with family and friends.






Discussion about a
community hall, I am sure, consumed considerable time in the
community in the late 1920’s and, if minutes of the local
Agricultural Society #103 ere available, as are later minutes,
references to such discussions could be found..  







The first record of
construction of the Black River Community Hall is for the trucking of
gravel on October 20, 1930.  On that date, the first loads of gravel
and sand were taken to the site by George Cameron, A. W. MacDougall,
Harold Godfrey and Robert Harper.  Wallace MacDonald worked that day
but did not haul gravel.  Forms were built on October 21 and 22 and
on October 23 and 24 concrete was poured.  A dream began to take
shape.






Framing commenced of the two-story
structure on October 29.  A later newspaper account said that the
hall was a two story building 50 by 34 feet,  Shingles were purchased
from A&R Loggie Co. on October 24 and windows and doors were
purchased on November 4.  It appears, but I cannot be certain, that
the building was closed in a...

title: Black River Connections
summary: Extensive historical documentation (partially shown; ~5,767 words) by Don Glendenning on Black River settlement and local institutions. Covers: the Mi'kmaq origin of "Black River" (Mat-quan-ti-gook); settlement timeline from UE Loyalists (1785–95) through Scottish immigration; Miramichi place names and their origins; transportation via river routes; land grants documentation with specific lot numbers and grantee names (MacNaughton, Watling, Glendenning, MacDonald families); schools established 1825 onward; mills including George Fowlie's gristmill (1833); churches—St. Stephen's Presbyterian (1836, rebuilt 1906), St. Paul's Presbyterian (1930), and the United Church of Canada merger (1925); post offices and postmasters (1871–1928) including Don's father as Postmaster at Little Branch (1914–1928) and Elmer Glendenning (1914–1916); detailed genealogies of MacDonald, MacNaughton, and Watling families with marriage and children records. Rich with anecdotes about local figures and infrastructure development.
content_preview:
BLACK RIVER CONNECTIONS







A. W. MacDougall says that the name Black River, in the MicMac language is AMat-quan-ti-gook - a term intended to describe its waters.  In the early days, Black River was a large area including Bay du Vin and point Aux Carr but now embraces only the communities along both the north and south sides of the river - a distance of 10 to 15 miles.  McDougall describes at least one lot, at McDougall's Point near the mouth of the river, which was granted to Delesderniere and Marsten prior to 1784.  The first settlers were United Empire Loyalists coming to Black River between 1785 and 1795.  Following this, there arrived mostly people from Scotland, highlanders and lowlanders alike including MacDonalds (McDonalds), MacNaughtons, McBeaths and MacLeans.  Many came directly from Scotland while others came to the Miramichi via Cape Breton or Prince Edward Island.




The Black River flows from west to east and empties into Bay du Vin, which is part of the Miramichi River.  By 1800, grants had been made to settlers along the shores from Hexham east.  In 1812, there was a major push to settle the Black River including the Little Black River now known as the Little Branch.  Settlements on the upper reaches of the Black River came a decade later and the Meadows closer to mid- century.  Some specific settlement dates are found later in this chapter.







Miramichi Place Names




Information about early place names of the area was taken from Geographical Names of New Brunswick, 1875.  




Chatham was once known as Spruce Tree after a large Spruce tree growing on Water Street.  The name changed to Chatham about 1800 after William Pitt, the Earl of Chatham, Prime Minister of England.




Although Wells Brook, Weldfield and Redmondville are shown, the origin of the names is not given.  




McKenzie Settlement was likely named after John and Roderick MacKenzie who were each granted 100 acres there in 1871 and 1873.  (Could this have been the Roderick Ma...

title: Blacksmiths
summary: Brief note, likely from a correspondent, providing information about blacksmith shops in Black River. The writer mentions Jack Dick's blacksmith shop and a building beside John W's house that was formerly a store. This appears to be a response to research inquiry sent to Don, showing his collaborative research methods with community members.
content_preview:
Sorry for the tardiness in replying. I can't remember any other establishments other than the

ones you mentioned, but of course my recollections date from our arrival in Black River in 1945.

I remember Jack Dick's blacksmith shop. I should mention , and perhaps you recall, there was

a small building right beside the road in front of John W's house. They always referred to it

as the "shop", and I understand it was a store at one time. I don't know what years it operated,

but certainly pre- 1945.

title: Bruce-3
summary: Extended letter from Don to Bruce Caughill dated May 22, 2005 providing family context for Bruce's genealogical research project. Detailed background on: Christina Catherine Watling (1876-1956), first daughter of Jubal/Grace Watling, married Robert Thomas Adams; Janet Watling (1883-1977), lived in Waltham MA; Jane Watling (Don's mother) married Elmer Glendenning, lived in Portland/Connecticut/USA before returning NB 1919; Ernest (Ern) Watling's military service; various Watling family neighbors (Archie MacNaughton, Jim Palmer, Walter MacDonald). Explains relationships, residences, church attendance at St. Stephen's. Critical document for understanding Don's immediate family, his mother Jane Watling Glendenning, and his childhood community. References accompanying photographs and archival materials (postcards, letters from Uncle Ern and Uncle Guy).
content_preview:
Date:		 TIME \@ "MMMM d, yyyy" May 22, 2005




To:		Bruce




From:		Don




Greetings from PEI.




As discussed, here are a few notes as background to your project:




Christina Catherine Watling (1876-1956) was the first born of Jubal and Grace (MacDonald) Watling.  On August 17, 1895, she married Robert Thomas Adams.  They had three children of which James Irenus was the oldest.  Robert Thomas Adams died in 1902.  I am not sure where they lived originally, but family lore says that “Uncle Tom Adams” was ill for an extended period of time and the family moved in with, and later died at the home of, his wife’s parents who were living at Little Branch.  A number of Aunt Tine’s younger siblings would be living in the home at the same time (Janet, Ern, Jane, Jim and maybe others).  Jimmie Adams would be more like a sibling than a nephew.




Aunt Tine may have lived at the Watling home until she remarried in August 1907.  If so, Jimmie would have been part of the family for a period of at least 5 and maybe even 7 years.  During this period, Jubal was postmaster and family lore sys that Aunt Tine operated the post office for him.  Marjorie Young even mentioned it on my recent trip to the Miramichi.  Aunt Tine and John MacKenzie moved to Loggieville, about 11 miles away, and would have been living there when Jimmie enlisted in the army.




Janet Watling (1883-1977) lived and worked for a while in Waltham, Mass.  On February 1, 1913 she married John R. Godfrey and they continued to live in Back River about 3-4 miles from the family home..




Jane Watling went to Portland in 1908 and married Elmer Glendenning on October 10, 1910 and lived and worked in the USA.  In 1914 they returned to NB and bought the property directly across the road from the old family home departing for the USA again in late 1916.  




Ernest Watling was probably living at home when he enlisted.




All of the above would have been aunts and uncles to Jimmie.




Archie MacNaughton (1896-1944)...

title: Cameron Bridge
summary: Don documents the Cameron Bridge at Middle Black River, the shortest of three covered bridges spanning the river, named for the preponderance of Cameron families in the area. He notes that in winter, a designated resident was responsible for snowing the bridge for sled travel. The bridge was badly damaged by fire in 1970, followed by a temporary Bailey bridge, and a new pre-cast concrete bridge in 1976. Don also notes it was "a great trout fishing location," adding personal knowledge of community recreation.
content_preview:
Cameron Bridge



























An undated photo of the
Cameron Bridge looking south provided by Francis J. MacNaughton




















The Cameron Bridge provided a crossing for the main road at Middle
Black River; the bridge and the adjacent school are so named because
of the preponderance of settlers named Cameron in the immediate area.
 Like other covered bridges, each winter a nearby resident was
designated to snow the bridge to ease the travel of sleds.








The bridge, the shortest of the three spanning the Black River, was
badly damaged by fire in 1970.  Following the fire, a Bailey bridge
provided temporary crossing.  A new pre-cast concrete bridge was
constructed in 1976.






This
was also considered a great trout fishing location.

title: Canobie Connection
summary: Genealogical and historical documentation of Glendenning family connection to Canobie, NB area. Opens with statement: John Glendinning (Elmer's father) settled Bathurst area ~1830, later moved to Canobie where Elmer was born. Documents place names along coastal route east from Bathurst: Salmon Beach (1820 Irish settlers), Janeville (named Jane Dawson), Stonehaven (possibly Scottish origin), New Bandon (1819 Irish settlers), Canobie (named after Canonbie, Dumfriesshire, Scotland). Provides historical context on settlement patterns (1700s Acadian settlement, organized land granting from 1800s). Details John Glendinning Sr. (Elmer's grandfather): born April 2, 1807 at Callister Hall, Dumfriesshire, Scotland; sailed from Annan 1830; purchased Lot 7 Salmon Beach with Margaret Harley (married August 23, 1833); Margaret taught first school in Salmon Beach (home-based 1838, purpose-built 1842; 27 students, 12x12x6 feet schoolhouse). Describes property movements: John and Margaret moved inland to Canobie 1855, sold Salmon Beach property. Lists early Canobie land grants (100-acre lots) with names and dates (1868-1939). Census records from 1861/1871 showing household composition. Children: Mary Anne, John, Margaret, Elizabeth Jane, Walter. John Sr. died May 15, 1877 in Canobie; Margaret died October 21, 1895. Extensive section on John Jr. (married Ellen Dickey; children practically raised by brother Walter's family), burial New Bandon Cemetery. Details Walter Glendenning (grandfather): born November 26, 1845; married Elizabeth Peters (daughter of John Peters, October 23, 1821-June 31, 1904, and Jane Sealy, December 24, 1821-September 12, 1892). Walter active in church (Sunday School teacher), Trinity Union Church trustee (1899), cut first lumber for building. Successful farmer with documented property holdings (Lot 30 Canobie homestead, 100-acre Lot 28, Stevens Farm 100 acres, Taylor Farm 50 acres). Will inventory lists extensive livestock and equipment (horses, cows, sheep, bull, farm machinery). Walter died of pneumonia while visiting daughter Venetia in Falmouth Foreside, Maine (will January 6, 1908, death February 1908); Elizabeth relocated to Maine, died May 14, 1915. Burial in Presbyterian cemetery New Bandon. References FWH manuscript "Boyhood Memories of New Brunswick" (~1940) with anecdotes about Canobie neighbors and family connections. Establishes genealogical continuity from John Sr. through Elmer's generation.
content_preview:
9
	Glendenning
	Roots
	

CANOBIE
CONNECTION
















John
Glendinning, my Great Grandfather settled in the Bathurst area about
1830; later he moved to Canobie where my father, Elmer Glendenning
was born.  This chapter deals with the Canobie connection to the
Glendenning family.











Early
Names






Travelling
east from Bathurst along the coast towards Caraquet, one finds a
number of communities familiar to the Glendenning family.  The
following information was taken from Geographical Names of New
Brunswick, 1875.  








Bathurst,
originally named St. Peters in 1671, was named for the Third Earl of
Bathurst in 1826. 



 	


Salmon
Beach
was settled around 1820 by immigrants from Ireland and included the
districts of Prospect Hill, Strawberry Plain and Mount Pleasant.  



Janeville
was named for Jane Dawson, wife of Benjamin Dawson who settled there
about 1835.  



Stonehaven
was probably named for Stonehaven, Scotland. 




New
Bandon
was settled in 1819 by several families from Bandon, Ireland.












If
one turns inland along the Janeville Road one comes to Canobie
which
was named


 after
Canonbie, Dumfriesshire, Scotland.  	






According
to  Pioneer Settlers of the Bay Chaleur. Settlement on the coast east
of Bathurst took place by the Acadians in the latter half of the
1700s and, although living on the land, their grants were not given
until 1812.  The first registered land grant was to James Sutherland
and his brother Hugh, and Richard Nevison in 1789.  
Apparently,
an organized system of granting of land did not evolve until the
1800s and even then there could be delays of a decade or more between
petitioning for land and receiving it.  Even then, the grant was not
final until at least five acres had been cleared.  







Once
settled, men began the task of clearing land and erecting a dwelling
and barn.  Trees not needed were stacked, dried and burned.  Few oxen
or horses were available so the land was broken and cultivated with
...

title: Cemetery
summary: Don describes the Black River/St. Stephen's Cemetery located on Gunn's Point, originally part of a lot granted to Enoch Gunn in 1812. The property was purchased by Enoch Godfrey in 1820, with the first burial believed to be Robert MacBeath in 1823. A Presbyterian church (St. Stephen's) was built in 1836 in the current cemetery area. Following Church Union in 1925, the cemetery served full burial rights to former Presbyterians continuing in the tradition. The document includes reference to a Glendenning family collection and mentions a Veterans' Memorial for soldiers who died in service. This reflects Don's attention to family burial traditions and community genealogy.
content_preview:
Black River/St. Stephen’s Cemetery



	


	
	



	
	



	
	

	

	

	


	
	

	Glendenning Collection
	

	


	



	


	
	



	
	


	



	
	
Veterans’
	Memorial erected in memory of soldiers who died in the service of
	their country.  Names include:
	



	
	



	
	



	
	



	
	



	
	

	The Black River Cemetery is situated on a point
	of land known as Gunn’s Point, and later Church Point; it was part
	of Lot No. 4 originally granted to Enoch Gunn on June 3, 1812.  The
	property was purchased by Enoch Godfrey in 1820 and the first
	burial, I believe, was that of Enoch Godfrey’s father-in-law,
	Robert MacBeath in 1923.  A more detailed history of the church and
	the cemetery can be found in an article by Ernie MacLean in the
	Spring 2001 Issue of Generations.
	  Although the nearest church was in
	Bay du Vin, other burials of Black River folk took place at Gunn’s
	Point even though the land was privately owned.  In 1836, a new
	church, St. Stephen’s Presbyterian, was opened in an area now part
	of the cemetery.
	



	
	
Following
	Church Union in 1925, St. Stephens United Church gave full burial
	rights to those former members who decided to continue in the
	Presbyterians tradition.  Today, this sacred plot is considered a
	community burial ground.
