title: challenged
summary: Brief note by Don comparing Suffolk county England (described in 1812) with the homesteading experience at the Meadows in New Brunswick in the mid-1800s. Emphasizes the dramatic transition his ancestors made from rural English county life to wilderness clearing in colonial North America. Reflects on ancestral resilience and adaptability.
content_preview:
challenged.




Suffolk, England




My great grandfather, Jubal Watling was born in Suffolk county England in 1823.  Suffolk County was described in 1812 as follows:

"Suffolk, an English  HYPERLINK "http://www.genuki.org.uk/big/eng/SFK/map.html" COUNTY 47 miles in length and 30 miles in breadth, bounded on the West by Cambridgeshire, on the North by Norfolk, on the South by Essex and on the East by the German Ocean. It contains 575 parishes, 28 market towns and sends 16 members to Parliament. The air is generally wholesome, but the soil is various, on the sea coast it is sandy and there are several small hills which yield hemp, pease and rye. The inland parts are clayey and more full of trees. The borders towards Essex are fit for pastures and the NW produces corn of all sorts. There are manufactures of several kinds, particularly all sorts of broad-cloth, stuffs and coarse linen. The principal rivers are Little Ouse, the Waveney, the Stour, The Breton, the Orwell or Gippe, the Ore and the Blyth. Ipswich and St.Edmundsberry are the principal towns".



From "The Complete and Universal Dictionary" by Rev James Barclay – 1812

Quite a change from there to carving out a homestead at the Meadows in the mid-1800s

title: Chesney final-2007
summary: Written by Don Glendenning in February 2007, this is a comprehensive genealogical and biographical history of Carol Louise (Chesney) Glendenning, Don's wife. The document traces Carol's family roots in Illinois (German and Scottish heritage), describes her childhood in Henry, Tiskilwa, and Peoria, her nursing education and career, and their meeting in 1957. It includes extensive details of their life together—marriage in 1958, Don's graduate studies in Bloomington, the births of Brian (1962) and Janet (1967), moves to Ottawa and Charlottetown, Carol's entrepreneurial ventures (The Accenter craft business), her artistic pursuits, and family travels. The narrative captures Don's affection and admiration for his wife, includes many photographs, and demonstrates his commitment to preserving family history for future generations.
content_preview:
Carol Louise (Chesney)
Glendenning










































































































































































































































Dedicated 



to 



Carol Louise (Chesney)
Glendenning


























































































































INTRODUCTION
















I am
of the view that it is important for us to know something of our
family roots, not to dwell there but to understand and recognize at
least some of the circumstances that shape us.  This is a brief
record of information gathered about Carol’s roots. 







Carol
was born and raised in Illinois, USA; first in Henry where she was
born and later in Tiskilwa and Peoria.  Her roots are primarily
German on Kaifer side but the Chesneys have Scottish roots.  In the
USA, Carol’s roots are anchored in the rich farmland of central
Illinois for nearly 200 years.






During
visits to Illinois, I managed to gather information about Carol’s
ancestors.  While not as complete as my information about the
Glendennings, I consider it to be significant and accurate.  Much of
my information came from Carol’s Aunt Esther Jardine, by whom  she
was raised, but this was supplemented from other sources including
cemetery stones, other relatives and newspaper clippings.






I
trust that children and grandchildren, and generations yet unborn,
will find this document an interesting record and useful beginning
for their explorations in the field of genealogy.
















Donald
Glendenning

title: Cormier,Maude Glendenning
summary: This obituary documents Alda Maude Glendenning Cormier (1883-1956), wife of James Cormier, who died at Saint John Hospital. Maude was daughter of Walter and Elizabeth Glendenning, making her one of Don Glendenning's siblings or close relatives. The obituary lists her surviving children and siblings, including connections to Florida, New York, Ontario, and Maine. The document shows the widespread geographic dispersal of the Glendenning family across North America.
content_preview:
Obituary provided by Grandson, Walter Berry; paper and date not known




(Transcription for Mrs. James Cormier)

“Mrs. James Cormier died April 19, 1956 at Saint John Hospital.  She was the former Alda Maude Glendenning born in Canobie May 2, 1883.  She was the daughter of Walter and Elizabeth Glendenning.  She is survived by her husband and four daughters Mrs. George Hood (Edna) in Lewiston, Maine;  Mrs. Fred Bierley (Doris) in Long Island, NY;   Mrs. Clayton Scott (Lillian) in Bathurst Mines;  Mrs. James Berry (Meta) in Hamilton, Ontario.   Three sons Raymond in Boston, Mass.;   James in Komoka, Ontario;   Sanford at home.  She is also survived by three brothers;  Guy in Florida;  Leonard in Salmon Beach;  and Raymond in Canobie.    Two sisters; Velnetia and Margaret in Florida.

Internment was made in the New Bandon Cemetery.”

 

I hope this is what you were requesting.  They give quite a bit of info but I see a discrepancy in the number of children between the two obits.

 

Note - The discrepancy in the number of children would be Boyd & Tina (Martina) who were children of my mother - but raised as children of Maude And James.

title: Cost of living 1
summary: Don presents historical context on New Brunswick's early currency (beaver pelts and equivalencies) and detailed records from his brother Walter's 1948 account books. Documents wood-cutting and grain-threshing crew compositions and wages (e.g., James A. Watling paid $5.50 for 3 hours, Theodore Fowlie $4.50 for a day). Records shared equipment ownership (thresher, engine) and community labor exchange practices typical of farm life, noting George Adams' possession of the only sloven (low-platform farm wagon) in Black River.
content_preview:
New Brunswick Currency




According to the October 2004 issue of the Miramichi Branch, NBGS, Newsletter, the early “coin” of New Brunswick was “one pound of spring beaver pelts”; this was equal to 1 otter, 3 sable or marten skins, 6 mink skins, 10 muskrat, 10 ermine, 5 pounds of deerskin, and 6 pounds of feathers.  I beaver skin would buy 14 pounds of pork, 30 pounds of flour, 21/2 gallons of molasses, 2 gallons of rum or 2/3 yard of cloth.

 

Walter’s record book

 

On April 5, 1948, Walter cut his wood - 24 inches for the furnace and 16 inches for the stove.  The following comprised the crew:







James A Watling – 		1 day		

Murray MacNaughton –		I day	$4.00

Theodore Fowlie – 1 day		$4.50

Fraser MacRae – 		½ day	$2.00

Claude McDonald – 		1 day

 Jack McDonald –		½ day	$2.00

Cecil McDonald –		21/2 hrs

Norman Glendenning – 		1 day

John Glendenning – 		1 day

Walter Glendenning – 		1 day

 

Another entry shows shared costs for the woodcutter of:

 

12 gal. Gas $3.00;   1 gal. Oil   $1.25

 

Another entry shows 43/4 hr at John’s; 43/4 at company pile and 43/4 hrs at own pile.  I believe this refers to some wood that John and Walter cut in common, perhaps on Crown land, as well as their own supply.

 

On October 18, 1948 Walter threshed his grain.  The following comprised the crew:

 

James T. D Watling	3 hrs	$5.50

Fraser McRae		$2.00

J.D. McRae		Returned

Godfreys		Returned

John Glendenning	

Sterling Cameron	Returned

Murray McNaughton	pd

 

Both the above cases illustrate the custom of woodcutting and threshing crews comprised of folk who exchange time as well as those who were paid.  Given the amount paid to James T. D. Watling, I wonder if he owned the thresher.  Although we shared ownership of a woodcutter with Uncle Jim, we did not have our own thresher. We also shared a stationary engine with Uncle Jim.  I think that we used a thresher owned by George Adams, Sr. who brought thresher and engine on a sloven.  Sometimes we used our own engine ...

title: Dad purchased a Model T
summary: Documents Elmer's automotive acquisitions with specific details: Model T Ford (purchased from MacLennan's Garage in Chatham; salesman took Grace for test drive before purchase); 1929 Model A 2-door Sedan (purchased from Babineau sisters who operated Chatham cinema). Includes vehicle registration reproductions (1928 Model T, 1938 Model A). Narrative anecdotes: Elmer and Walter cutting wood at Bay du Vin River to earn car money; Model T upset at Gilberts Corner near Shediac (Grace broke wrist when Elmer was bringing her home from business college); Model A stored in wagon shed (possibly due to recession); allowance of $2.00 weekly gas; technical detail about gravity-fed fuel systems and backward driving on steep hills like Tabisintac. Portrays Elmer as not a very good driver (Aunt Venetia's skepticism), with occasional mishaps but practical problem-solving. Contains reproductions and sourced from Lillian.
content_preview:
Dad purchased a Model T. Ford, year unknown, but Lillian (Weeks)
Glendenning thought that he had purchased it from MacLennan’s
Garage in Chatham (At the corner of the Park).  Lillian remembered
that the salesman let Grace tryout the car before Dad bought it. 
Sometime after 1931 he purchased a 1929  Model A 2-door Sedan –
purchased, I believe, from the Babineau sisters (The Babineau's
operated the movie theatre in Chatham.)  According to both Walter and
Lillian, the car was purchased on the day that Annie MacDougall died.









Walter worked with Dad cutting wood up Bay du Vin River to earn money
to buy one of the cars; I cannot recall which one.  Shown above are
the 1928 registrations for the Model T Ford and in 1938 for the Model
A. Ford  Thanks to Lillian (Glendenning) Murray for access to the
original documents.








The gas tank for the Model A, and perhaps for the Model T, was just
in front of the windshield and gas flowed by gravity to the engine. 
On very steep hills, the Tabisintac for example, the car had to be
turned around and driven backward up the hill.  .  Dad upset the
Model T at Gilberts Corner, near Shediac, the day he brought Grace
home from business college.  The Model A sat in the old wagon shed,
presumably because of the recession.   Walter said that Dad allowed
$2.00 worth of gas each week but I do not recall for what year.  Gas
pumps of the day were pumped by hand to fill a chamber at the top of
the pump.  The gas then flowed by gravity through the hose to the gas
tank on a car.

title: Dances
summary: Don's first dance in June 1946 at age 16—a "Lancer" with Norma Williston (classmate from Branch School and Miramichi Rural High School). That summer he attended dances two to three times weekly at various halls (Black River Hall, Mel Adams' hall, Napan School, Sunny Corner) with friends including Francis MacNaughton. Describes a brawl that emptied the Black River Hall. Includes story of Jim Finno, a blind neighbor with an apple orchard, and the incident where Don's group attempted to steal "transparent" apples but fled when Finno appeared, resulting in Don's sprained ankle.
content_preview:
My first Dance




One late afternoon about the second week of June 1946, Elinor and I were in the front yard, perhaps even raking the yard, when Harry MacLean walked by on the way home (from work?).  We spoke as he walked by and he asked me if I was going to the dance in the Black River Hall that night.  I went for the first time and had my first dance, a “Lancer”, with Norma Williston.  Norma and I were in the same Grade at the Branch School and later at the Miramichi Rural High School.




That summer we often went to dances two or three times a week at the Black River Hall, at Mel Adams’ hall, Napan School and probably elsewhere.  One night a fight erupted at the Black River Hall and spilled out into the yard emptying the hall.  Francis MacNaughton and I even went to dances in Sunny Corner.




Jim Finno




Earlier I mentioned the Finno home by the river.  Jim Finno was blind.  I believe that he had a dog and stories were told about him having a shotgun.  He had a small apple orchard, which included a “transparent” apple tree.  Transparent were an early apple, a brilliant yellow (but not to be confused with the “Dutch Apples”) and sweet to the taste.  The Finno apples were reputed to be the best.




One evening about dusk, a number of us decided to try some of his transparent apples.  We went to the wharf and then started up the hill towards the house walking near the riverbank.  When we were still about 150 feet from the house, Mr. Finno came out on the porch.  We did not wait but scrambled over the steep bank.  I forget about the others but recall that I ended up with a sprained ankle.

title: Dick, Royal Canadian Legion Chatham Branch
summary: Don's correspondence offering paintings of Black River WWI soldiers to Royal Canadian Legion, including Gnr. Stephen Dick who died in action. Demonstrates Don's community involvement and effort to preserve local military history and honor fallen soldiers.
content_preview:
Royal Canadian Legion Chatham Branch #3, 

PO Box 86, 

Miramichi, NB

 E1N 3A5. 




Attn: Rene Smith, Treasurer




Thanks for your Email; I am delighted to hear from you and of your interest in receiving the painting from Carolyn Haggard.

 

Actually there are two paintings:  




The first is of Gnr. Stephen Dick of Black River who was killed in action overseas during WW1.  I am enclosing a brief note about both Stephen and the artist on a separate page.  The painting is being offered to the Chatham Branch #3 of the Royal Canadian Legion by his grand niece, Carolyn Haggard who lives in Alberta.  I will get in touch with Carolyn and provide her with your mailing address.  




I know from earlier correspondence that Carolyn is pleased that the painting will have a home back in New Brunswick and especially to the Chatham Legion.




The second painting, still in progress, is by Carolyn Haggard who is an artist in her own right.  This painting is of five “Boys” from Black River, including Stephen Dick, who lost their lives overseas during WW1.  When finished, Carolyn plans to send this to you as well.




As for myself is concerned, I am a Glendenning from Black River; my brother Kenneth is a member of Royal Canadian Legion Branch #3.  Any acknowledgement or recognition should go to Carolyn Haggard; I am only too pleased to have played a role in bringing the painting back to the Miramichi.




You may find the attached copy of the attached newsletter of interest.




Sincerely




Don Glendenning

title: Dick,Stephen@2015-03-15T23;54;00
summary: A biographical account of Stephen John Dick, born 1895 in Black River Bridge, NB, who died as a soldier in World War I at age 23 in France. The document describes his sister Barbara Victoria's oil portrait of him and the painting's eventual donation to the Irvine Museum in Alberta. This genealogical record connects to Don's family history and his interest in documenting family narratives.
content_preview:
Stephen John Dick


January 18, 1895-October 1, 1918


























Stephen
John Dick, was born in Black River Bridge, Northumberland County,
New Brunswick.  He was the youngest child of Alexander and Selina
(Weaver) Dick .His siblings were Elizabeth Agnes, Barbara Victoria
and John William






Gnr.
Stephen John Dick, #522059, 1st Brigade, Canadian
Field Artillery, buried in Haynecourt British Cemetery, about 6 miles
northwest of Cambrai, France, age 23.






The
Painting






Barbara
Victoria, Stephen’s sister painted a portrait in oil and shows
Stephen Dick, from mid torso up in a suit or perhaps a university
robe; the painting is approximately 24x 32 inches; while I haven’t
seen it, I am told that it is in very good condition considering its
age.  The painting is signed by the artist, Barbara, Stephen’s
sister; I do not know if the painting is dated






The
Artist






The
artist, Stephen’s sister, Barbara Victoria, married Charles Albert
Parker and lived in Athabaska, Alberta.  Among her paintings was one
of her brother, Stephen, painted just before he went overseas.  The
painting passed down through the family and was donated to the Irvine
Museum, Irvine, Alberta, by Carolyn Haggart, daughter of Eldon Dick
and Opal Fraser, and a Grand Niece of Stephen Dick.

title: Edge-Outhouse
summary: Written by Donald Edge (NOT Don Glendenning; received as email correspondence Feb 2003), this witty and detailed essay describes life in Black River using outdoor privies and chamber pots, drawing from childhood memories and observations. References Don's Watling cousins and their remarkably modern indoor privy within their barn complex. A valuable resource for understanding the material conditions of early 20th-century Black River life and provides context for Don's own childhood experiences in that community. Edge's piece reflects on outhouses as "hallmarks of democracy" and symbols of self-reliance.
content_preview:
canada.com | Help | Read Mail in InboxFrom:  Djedge007@aol.com

      Date:  Thu Feb 6 18:41:58 2003 (PST)

      To:  gjgarner@telusplanet.net, dglende@attglobal.net, 

      jhwilson@nbnet.nb.ca, jewatling@yahoo.com

      Subject:  The Outhouse: Final version

       







 

The Outhouse










"And it shall come to pass, that instead of sweet smell there shall be stink…"

[Isaiah 3:24]










My grandparents' house saw many firsts.  It was the first house in Black River 

to have a telephone, the first to have electricity, the first to have running 

hot water, and the first to have an indoor toilet.  Of course the toilet and the 

light bulbs and the hot water depended on the electricity, and that came from a 

generator that rarely worked.  Thus we basked in firsts but like everyone else 

in Black River we used kerosene lamps and bathed in a bathtub filled by lugging 

up stairs water heated in  the kitchen wood stove. Youngsters weren't worth the 

lugging, and were thought to have not much dignity, and so late on Saturdays 

they were bathed in a zinc washtub set in the middle of the kitchen floor.  In 

the most private of moments everyone resorted to  an outdoor privy and chamber 

pots. 




Chamber pots could be quite fancy.  Every home in Black River had one or more 

wash stands, each containing a small bowl for washing, a water pitcher, a 

wastewater bowl, and a chamber pot.  Today these are just for show, but when I 

was a boy these were the hallmarks of a well kept home and a public display that 

cleanliness is next to Godliness. Given the circumstances and the equipment, we 

were about as clean as could be expected.  For that matter, we were probably 

about as Godly as could be expected, all things considered.




I was always too young to be trusted with carrying a brimming chamber pot 

downstairs and outside to wherever filled pots went to, and so I know nothing 

about that end of the business. Nor to this day do I care to.  



...

title: Electric Power
summary: Don documents the arrival of electricity to Black River in fall 1948. His mother had the house wired in advance by Harry Simmonds; Don recalls coming home from his teaching position at Miramichi Rural High School to see the house lit for the first time. His brother Norman installed an electric water pump at Christmas 1948 and a hot water heater Christmas 1949, with Don assisting and later helping install a water line to the barn (dug 5 feet deep, 1950-1951) using a float-chamber system. Includes memory of his mother's electric iron, kept in storage during prior years when his father worked at hydroelectric dam projects with electricity access.
content_preview:
Electric Power




Electric power came, as I recall, to Black River in the fall of 1948.  The hydro poles had been put in and wires strung the year before.  Mum had the house wired, I think, by Harry Simmonds, months before power was turned on.  I was teaching at the Miramichi at the time and remember coming home from school, probably in September or October, and looking up the hill to see the house lighted for the first time.




Seems to me that Norm put in an electric water pump that Christmas and a hot water heater the following Christmas (1949).  I remember helping with both.  He also ran a water line to the barn, dug about by hand 5 feet deep either in 1950 or 1951.  The reason I remember the latter is that I was at NBIT at the time and had a float chamber made in the welding shop.  We used a toilet valve to control the water level and a couple of light bulbs as a float.  The float chamber was located near the entrance from the cowbarn to the barn floor and a pipe run along the stalls.  It was gravity fed to the individual drinking bowls.










The Electric Iron




During the first years of their married life, Dad worked at construction sites, usually dam sites as far as I know.  Some of the sites had electricity, probably to power some of the equipment but also available to the homes where the families lived.  As a result, Mum had an electric iron among things stored in the closet at the head of the stairs (the equivalent of the attic in novels and movies).  Sometimes on a stormy wintry day, I was allowed to root around in the attic.  That’s where the electric iron was kept.




Before the advent of wrinkle free or wrinkle resistant fabric, most clothing required pressing.  (Even men’s dress pants were pressed from time to time.)  Irons 




for pressing usually came in sets of three and were warmed on the stovetop.  A detachable handle was used to change irons when a hot one was needed.   Ironing was a necessary and frequent task when raising a family o...

title: Elmer (1)@2015-10-10T20;21;20
summary: Comprehensive genealogical research documenting Elmer Alton Glendenning (1875-1938) and wife Jane Elizabeth Jardine Watling (1890-1964), Don's parents. Details Elmer's ancestors, properties in Canobie NB, nine children (including Don), and community roles (Agricultural Society secretary-treasurer, Masonic member, Oddfellow, Orange Lodge member 43 years). Includes newspaper clippings, property records, and extensive family documentation, essential for understanding Don's family background and values.
content_preview:
Ancestors of Elmer Alton Glendenning 







Generation 1 




1. 

Elmer Alton Glendenning, son of Walter Glendenning and Elizabeth Peters was born on 29 Jun 

1875 in Canobie, NB. He died on 18 May 1938 in Black River Bridge, NB. He married Jane 

Elizabeth Jardine Watling on 18 Oct 1910 in Little Branch, Black River, New Brunswick, daughter 

of Jubal Watling and Grace MacAskill MacDonald. She was born on 28 Feb 1890 in Upper Black 

River, NB. She died on 25 Mar 1964 in Newcastle Hospital, NB. 

Notes for Elmer Alton Glendenning: 

It is interesting that Dad's name sometimes appears as Alton Elmer and other times as Elmer Alton 

Glendenning. Although I have not seen a birth certificate, my earliest references are to Elmer Alton 

Glendenning. A separate set of notes has been prepared for Elmer and Jane (Watling) 

Glendenning. 







Venetia's clippings included the following believed to have been taken from the Moncton Times: 

CHATHAM,May 22 -The community of Black River and the Miramichi generally will learn with 

deep regret of the death of Elmer A. Glendenning at his home Black River Bridge. For 14 years he 

had been the energetic secretary-treasurer of the progressive Agricultural Society of that district. 

For over a quarter of a century he has been a member of the Masonic Order; for 30 years enjoyed 

membership in the Oddfellows Craft, and for the long period of 43 years was a member of the 

Loyal Orange Lodge. 

Surviving are his wife (formerly Miss. Jean Watling of Black River) and nine children. There are 

four daughters, Mrs. Roy Smith of Medford, Mass., Mrs Cameron Russell of Point Aux Carr, Lillian 

of Needham, Mass., and Elinor at home, an infant daughter, Margaret Virginia was buried in 

Hampton, Virginia in 19918; five sons, Walter, John, Kenneth, Norman and Don, all at home. 

The funeral of the late Mr. Glendenning was held yesterday afternoon at 2:30 o'clock with Dr. 

Genge of Calvin Church, Chatham, officiating. Interment was made...

title: Ernie MacLean - Black River
summary: Comprehensive historical record of St. Stephens United Church of Canada at Black River, New Brunswick, from 1812 onwards. Documents land transfers, church construction (1835-1836), financial difficulties, and organizational changes through 1940s. Includes details on trustees, properties, ministers (Rev. Simon Fraser, Rev. Angus MacMaster, Rev. Myers, Rev. G. A. Grant), and community figures. Given Don's birth at Black River Bridge in 1929, this detailed local history directly contextualizes his family's community and religious life. Shows deep historical documentation of the area central to Don's family heritage and early life.
content_preview:
From: "SHIRLEY MAC KAY" <kildonan@verizon.net>
To: "Don Glendenning" <dglende@pei.sympatico.ca>
Subject: ERNIE MACLEAN LAND - some good reading - will dig out the MacKay stuff tomorrow - in the closet
Date: November 23, 2008 7:02 PM

SAINT STEPHENS UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA, BLACK RIVER
LAND PURCHASES AND CHURCH BUILDING INFORMATION

Lot # 4 - all that certain parcel of land on the southerly side of the main branch of Black River was granted to Alexander Gunn by letters protect under the great seal of the province bearing date at Fredericton, June 5, 1812, signed Martin Hunter, Esquire

On this land Alexander Gunn had a house close to the old church road and between the present church and the gulch next to the cemetery.

In a deed signed by Alexander Gunn on July 24, 1820, registered on July 27, 1820, Vol. 17, Page 1, Alexander Gunn deeds to Enoch Godfrey all of Lot # 4 together with the buildings and improvements thereon, for the sum of 50 pounds.

On the 31st of October, 1816 Enoch Godfrey married Elizabeth MacBeath, daughter of Robert MacBeath and Christy MacBeath.

Lot # 5 - On May 23, 1820 Enoch Godfrey bought from his wife's parents, all of Lot # 5 for 100 pounds, provided that it be understood that Robert MacBeath and his wife Christy MacBeath during their natural lives may occupy 1/2 of the lot, on the demise of them both the whole may become the lawful property of Enoch Godfrey.

Robert MacBeath, Enoch Godfrey's Father-in-law died in 1823, I am quite sure he was the first one buried on the church point.

A falling log killed Duncan MacNaughton in 1824, and he is the second one buried there.

This piece of land was used as the regular cemetery, even though it still belonged to Enoch Godfrey until 1836.

At a meeting of the inhabitants of the Black River district held at the home of Archibald Cameron on the 10th of November, 1834, the following person were appointed to use all due efforts for the erection of a church on Alexander Gunn's point, being a part of L...

title: Family Educator
summary: Collection of Don's educational commentary and proposals written for public discourse. Includes multiple essays/letters: "Family Educator" proposing independent education advisory service separate from school system; "Cookie Cutter Schools" offering recommendations for educational reform; "When a School Can't Help" discussing reading instruction gaps; and "Advisor, Advocate, or Ombudsman?" exploring educational support roles. Signed "Don Glendenning, A long-time student of education" with contact email standards2020@gmail.com. Reflects Don's passion for education reform, his belief that education extends beyond schooling, and his advocacy for comprehensive educational support systems. Written for letters-to-editor publication.
content_preview:
My notes

Educational Advisor







There is a major gap in our educational system, a gap that results, I believe, from the fact that we fail to differentiate between education and schooling.  Just think of the question “Where did you get your education?  What the person wants to know is where did you go to school or what university did you go to.  As a result, we fail to provide independent advice to learners of all ages as to their educational concerns.  The system expects you to go to an institution for advice about education; what you get is advice about their product.  It’s a bit like going to the Ford dealer to ask about a transportation problem.




Learning benefits from a variety of support such as personal well-being, counselling, feedback, information, opportunity, encouragement, instruction and guided practice; homes and communities are major suppliers of educational support.  Schools are also important but they have a limited focus, that of providing instruction in a range of academic studies. 




Decisions about education are often complex, are a major determinant of the kind of future we will have, confront us with many options each with its own set of consequences; and are becoming moreso.  A case in point is the many young people with shiny diplomas and degrees still lacking the basic  skills to function in a modern economy.




  
Assistance/advice readily available to students
  
Educational advice to people not in school is limited and mostly focused on employability





  
Proposal:


  
To establish an education advisory service for people are not in the school system.  
  
The service to be individualized, personalized, separate from the school system. 
  
Services to include information, counselling, advice, assessment and referral depending on individual needs and objectives. 


The office would serve a community not a school district and operate out of local

A family adviser on education




The process of getting an education is a comp...

title: Family of Dr Hesta
summary: A template or reference document about the Hesta MacDonald Fund established with the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island. The fund aimed to support school libraries with annual grants to Belfast Consolidated School and another unnamed school. This document is NOT personally authored by Don but serves as a reference model, likely for understanding how his family's charitable giving works.
content_preview:
Family of Dr. Hesta MacDonald




Dear




One of your mother’s many interests was education and learning.  To this end, she wanted to make an ongoing contribution to education of Island children and established the Hesta MacDonald Fund with the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island.  Her personal goal was to build an endowment of $5,000 over a period of five years.  This would provide an endowment from which a grant of $200.00 is given for the purchase of library books at the Belfast Consolidated School and the (Marla can confirm the name of the second school from my note in the MacDonald file) ______________ School.  




Enclosed is a program for our last Awards Nights which highlights the benefits the Community Foundation provides by connecting people who care with causes that matter.  Also included is a year-end report on our activities in general including the performance of the investment portfolio.




Each year we provided her information on the current financial status of her fund, so therefore, we are sending to you our customary year-end report as follows:




	Opening Fair Market Value		$

	Contribution during year		$

	Administration Fee			$

	Investment/Management Fees	$

	Grant/Award				$

	Year end Fair Market Value		$




If you would like further information about the Fund, do not hesitate to let me know.  We also think that there are people in the community who would be interested in contributing to the Hesta MacDonald Fund and thereby helping to realize her objective of building an endowment to provide support to school libraries in perpetuity.  .  In the meantime, Dr. Glendenning will be in contact with you to discuss the future of the fund and any changes or additions you may wish to make.




The Community Foundation of PEI is pleased to have the Hesta MacDonald Fund as part of our portfolio and look forward to serving you in the years ahead.  




Sincerely,




John Robinson

President

title: First Radios
summary: Don relates his sister Lillian's recollection that Malcolm MacNaughton owned the first radio in Black River (early listeners shared earphones), followed by Herb Fowlie and Uncle Jim Watling. Walter and Venetia (wife) purchased the first radio at Don's home, placed in the dining room and powered by a 6-volt car battery, two B-batteries (cylindrical, 3 inches diameter), and a C-battery (soda-box sized). An aerial wire ran from the house eave to a tall pole at the gatepost near the henhouse.
content_preview:
First Radios




My sister, Lillian, recalled that Malcolm MacNaughton from the north side of Black River was the first one in the community to have a radio.  People used to visit to listen and had to take turns listening through earphones.  The next two radios were Herb Fowlie and Uncle Jim Watling.




Walter and Venetia bought the first radio at my home.  It sat in the dining room near the back wall.  A copper wire was run as an aerial from the eave of the house to a tall, slender pole at the gatepost near the henhouse.  




The radio was powered, as I recall by a 6-volt car battery (was that the A Battery?), two B-Batteries cylindrical and about 3 inches in diameter, and a C-battery, which was the size of a box of soda.

title: Fowlie's Mill
summary: Don investigates the history of Fowlie's Mill on the Little Black River using newspaper clippings and historical records. Documents include an 1828 account of Mrs. Fowlie's grist and saw mills burning under suspicious circumstances, an 1833 Gleaner article about George Fowlie establishing the mill, and a 1932 Chatham Gazette article about F.A. Fowlie remodeling the mill. Don expresses uncertainty about ownership details but provides valuable local historical documentation. The mill was burned and rebuilt twice and served as a community resource.
content_preview:
Fowlie’s Mill







clipping date and newspaper not known but believed to be 1978, includes the following uder a column entitled “150 years ago 1828”




Foul play suspected




The grist and saw mills of Little Black River owned by Mrs. Fowlie, were totally consumed by fire on the 10th Feb.There was a large quantity of wheat, flour and oatmeal in the mill at the time, which was all consumed, together with everything on the premises.  

From all the information we are able to glean, there is every reason to apprehend that it was the work of an incendiary.  The fire in the stove was carefully put out early the preceding evening, and when the fire was discovered the next morning, the flames were insuing from the opposite end of the building to where the stove stood.

The loss of property will be from 800 pounds to 1000 pounds.




3	




Fowlie’s Mill




























































































































I was not aware of the mill ever having been owned by F. A. Fowlie.










Saw Mills




I do not know when the first saw mill was constructed at Little Branch, however, the History of Bay du Vin records a sawmill operated by Ortho Robichaud in 1789 in the Bay du Vin area.




The Bay du Vin history also reports the following taken from the Gleaner in 1833.




“Mr. George Fowlie erected a grist mill on the Little Black River, which commenced grinding last week.  We have seen some bread made of the flour manufactured at this mill and it was of superior quality.  It has a never failing stream of water and will be a great accommodation to the inhabitants of Bay du Vin and adjoining settlements where such an establishment was much wanted.”  The Fowlie mill was burned and rebuilt twice. “







Fowlie’s Mill




Among my notes, I found a clipping entitled “150 years ago - 1828”.  Presumably it was from a Miramichi paper.

 

“Foul play suspected




The grist and saw mills of Little Black River own...

title: Games
summary: Charming recollection of childhood games and pastimes in Black River, including Anti-I-Over (a team ball game played over buildings), buckety wade (teeter-totter), homemade darts made from cork and horseshoe nails, and the card game Flinch which was unique to the Glendenning family. Don credits his sister Grace with introducing Flinch via a Parker Brothers game sent from Salem, Massachusetts. Also describes snow-crust skating and coasting with a humorous incident of his front wheel dropping through.
content_preview:
Anti-I-Over?




Donald Edge was trying to recall the name of a game played by youngsters in Black River.  It was, I believe, Anti-I-Over although I am not sure of the correct spelling.




It was played between two teams separated by a building – usually the house, the barn or a large shed.  One team would throw the ball over the building – anywhere along the roof.  The other team would wait for the ball to appear and would try to catch it.  If not successful, they threw the ball back over.  If successful in catching the ball, team members would run around the building and attempt to catch (hit the other team with the ball.  If they did, they won.




This is my recollection of the rules of the game but I would welcome comments.




What’s a “buckety wade?




I am not sure of the word or it’s spelling but didn’t we call a teeter-totter a buckety wade?  Seems that we made ours with a 2x6 plank over a fence or gate, or perhaps a sawhorse. (A 2x4 was not strong enough.)  In order to balance the plank, the lighter person would move a bit closer to the end of the plank.  A great demonstration of one of the laws of physics







Flinch

Follow-up




Donna (Russell) Goodfellow confirms that their flinch Game came from my sister, Grace.  I must now conclude that Flinch was a game unique to our family.  Parker Brothers still sells the game; I bought two games yesterday.




Flinch was a very popular game at our home.  Although I played it, I especially remember a crowd of young people, only the boys I think, gathered around our dining room table of an evening.  I remember the Harpers, Adams and our own crew and I think Roy and Win and others.  




Flinch is played with one or more packs of cards; cards are numbered from one to 15.  One has a hand, a flinch pile where you lay down a card at the end of your turn and a stack of cards from which players take new hands.  The objective is to get rid of your flinch pile first.  If you had a card in your flinch pile and did not...

INTRODUCTION
















My father and mother came from large and close
families; visits and visitors were frequent and family ties were
strong, even if remote.  At an early age, I became intrigued by the
number of neighbours along the length of the Black River to whom I
was related.  By the late 1940’s I began gathering family
information.  







Information
was drawn from many sources with the Glendenning Family Bible in my
Mother’s possession as my point of entry.  Shortly thereafter, I
conducted a survey on my father’s side of the family and I was
hooked, although my information gathering was sporadic, at best.  The
benefit of computer based technology and a new spurt of information
gathering after retirement resulted in a cabinet full of files,
scraps of paper on every flat surface ...

title: Glendenning-Big Cove
summary: Genealogical family group sheet for Richard R. Glendenning (b. 1806, d. before 1891) and Mary Boyd (b. 1816, m. 1837, d. June 1891). Lists eight children including Isabella Brown, John Glendenning (m. Margaret Fletcher, 1872), James Boyd, George R. (1850-1918, m. Mary Pentland), Richard Richardson, Anne Harris, Margaret (m. Edwin L. Simonton, 1882), and Jane. Represents a collateral branch of the Glendenning family that Don researched, showing his documentation of extended family lines beyond his direct ancestors.

title: Glendenning, Elmer1875-1938
summary: Newspaper obituary of Elmer A. Glendenning (Don's father) from Moncton Times, detailing his 14 years as secretary-treasurer of the Agricultural Society, membership in Masonic Order (25+ years), Oddfellows (30 years), and Orange Lodge (43 years). Lists surviving wife Jean Watling and nine children including Don and four daughters. Includes Don's reflective note about his father's work at Wilson Dam and J.G. White Engineering Company connections. Document shows Don's genealogical research into his parents' history.
content_preview:
Venetia's clippings included the following believed to have been taken from the Moncton Times:

CHATHAM,May 22 - The community of Black River and the Miramichi generally will learn with deep regret of the death of Elmer A. Glendenning at his home Black River Bridge.  For 14 years he had been the energetic secretary-treasurer of the progressive Agricultural Society of that district.  For over a quarter of a century  he has been a member of the Masonic Order; for 30 years enjoyed membership in the Oddfellows Craft, and for the long period of 43 years was a member of the Loyal Orange Lodge.

Surviving are his wife (formerly Miss. Jean Watling of Black River) and nine children.  There are four daughters, Mrs. Roy Smith of Medford, Mass., Mrs Cameron Russell of Point Aux Carr, Lillian of Needham, Mass., and Elinor at home, an infant daughter, Margaret Virginia was buried in Hampton, Virginia in 19918; five sons, Walter, John, Kenneth, Norman and Don, all at home.  

The funeral of the late Mr. Glendenning was held yesterday afternoon at 2:30 o'clock with Dr. Genge of Calvin Church, Chatham, officiating.  Interment was made in St. Stephen's cemetery, Black River." 




We always thought that Dad worked at the Wilson Dam in Mussell Shoals, At the same time, we have evidence that Uncle Frank worked at Plant No. 1, US Nitrate Co. in Sheffield Alabama.  He was working  for the J. G. White Engineering Co, which is the same one Dad worked for in Hampton, Virginia.

title: Glendenning Fund
summary: Documentation of the Glendenning Family Fund established by the family of Elmer and Jane Watling Glendenning (Don's parents) for charitable purposes related to Black River Bridge, New Brunswick (Don's birthplace). Lists grants (2002-2008): history prizes, library books for Miramichi Rural School, and planned cemetery bench. Notes include contacts (Janet Glendenning, Loisanne Gregan, Donna Goodfellow) and discussion of future Miramichi Foundation transfer. Demonstrates family philanthropy rooted in ancestral community.
content_preview:
13

Glendenning Fund







Contacts:	Janet Glendenning, 46 Holland Ave, Ottawa, K1Y  0X4

		Loisanne Gregan, 325 Hardwicke Road, Hardwick, NB  E9A 1L5   Tel:

		Donna Goodfellow, Upper Kent, New Brunswick

		




Background




Established by the family of Elmer and Jane (Watling) Glendenning, grants may be made for any charitable purpose related to the community of Black River Bridge, New Brunswick.  (Black River is a rural community stretching along both sides of the Black River which empties into the Miramichi near its mouth)  Grants to date:




2002	A first and second prize for a history related to Black River to Barry

MacKenzie and ?

2005	A grant of $200 to Miramichi Rural School for the purchase of library

 Books

2006	A second grant to the Miramichi rural School also for the purchase of

library books

2007	A third grant to the Miramichi Rural School for the purchase of library books

2008	Plans are to provide a bench for ate Black River Cemetery.  




Some of the committee members know that there is talk of establishing a community foundation in the Miramichi area but I have heard nothing lately.  If a Miramichi Foundation is established, the idea was/is to  transfer the glendenning endowment from PEI to the Miramichi.







May 8, 2008




Some support for planting trees/shrubs/flowers at Black River community hall but word is that hall and grounds are undergoing reconstruction. (Miramichi Recreation Council of Black River & Bay du Vin -- I believe the president is either Hilary or Jonathan Guimond.)

 

The nature of this kind of fund makes for slow decision-making; some day it will likely be converted to a scholarship; if so, it should not be limited to a student attending university

title: Glendenning, George Maxwell
summary: Undated Chatham Gazette clipping reporting funeral service for infant George Maxwell Glendenning, son of Mary and John Glendenning, held at their Black River Bridge home. Rev. Fraser Dunbar conducted service with hymns "When He Cometh to Make up his Jewels" and "Jesus Loves Me." Infant survived by parents and siblings Margaret, Jean, and Frankie. Purely genealogical record.
content_preview:
An undated newspaper clipping believe to be from the Chatham Gazette, reports




"GEORGE MAXWELL GLENDENNING  "On Sunday, February 24th, at 2 the funeral of George Maxwell, infant son of Mary and John Glendenning was held from their home at Black River Bridge.

Rev. Fraser Dunbar, minister of St. Paul's Presbyterian Church  conducted the service.  The hymns sung were, When He Cometh to Make up his Jewels also Jesus Loves Me.  

Burial was in Black River Cemetery.  Pallbearers were uncles of the little one.  

Besides his parents, he leaves to mourn two sisters, Margaret and Jean and brother Frankie."

title: Glendenning, Guy Wellington
summary: Herald Advocate obituary from February 24, 1967, reporting death of Guy W. Glendenning, age 77 (born Canobie, NB). Canadian WWI veteran; moved to Bowling Green, Florida in 1930. Active Mason (Past Master of Bowling Green Lodge 121, Scottish Rite Mason) and member of Wauchula Elks Lodge. Survived by widow Hazel Stultz Glendenning, son Robert, daughter Cornelia, brother Ray, and four grandchildren. Family connection document.
content_preview:
The Herald Advocate of February 24, 1967 carried the following:

 

Guy W. Glendenning, 77, Died February 8 after an extended illness.

 

He was born in Canobie, New Brunswick, Canada and was a Canadian Veteran of World War l.  He came to Bowling Green in 1930 from Peru where he was affiliated with the Masonic Lodge in 1921, serving as Worshipful Master a few years later.

 

He was Past Master of Bowling Green Lodge 121 and Past Patron of  Bowling Green Chapter 23, Order of the Eastern Star, a Scottish Rite Mason, and a member of the Wauchula Elks Lodge.

 

Survivors are his widow, Hazel Stultz Glendenning; a son Robert Glendenning of Chesterton, Md.; a daughter, Cornelia Farrell, Huntington Station, Long Island, N. Y.; one brother, Ray Glendenning of Canobie, New Brunswick, Canada and four grandchildren.

 

Funeral services were held February 13 at the Bowling Green Methodist Church with the Rev. E. J. Halter officiating.  Burial was in the Bowling Green Cemetery.

title: Glendenning. Hilda Ellis
summary: Newspaper clipping (source/date unknown) reporting death of Mrs. Hilda Glendenning, age 95, of Bathurst (formerly Canobie). Daughter of Edwin and Nina Jagoe Ellis. Last surviving member of immediate family. Member United Church Clifton and Women's Institute. Husband Raymond Glendenning died 1970. Survived by three sons (Marson, Guy, George), six daughters, 56 grandchildren, 94 great-grandchildren, and seven great-great-grandchildren. Extended family connection showing large family tree.
content_preview:
A newspaper clipping, paper and date not known, reports:

"Mrs. H. Glendenning

CANOBIE (Special) - Mrs. Hilda Glendenning, 95, of 2055 Vallee Lourdes Dr., Bathurst, formerly of Canobie, died Sunday at Foyer Notre Dame de Lourdes.

Born in Canobie, she was the daughter of  the late Edwin and Nina (Jagoe) Ellis.  The last surviving member of her immediate family, she was a member of the United Church, Clifton and the Women's Institute.  She was also a member of the Canobie Community Club.  Her husband, Raymond Glendenning, died in 1970.

She is survived by three sons, Marson of Bathurst, Guy and George both of Canobie; six daughters, Mrs. Kenneth Scott (Ada) of Clifton, Mrs Shirley Wiseman of New Hampshire, Mrs Robert Borland  (Ruby) of Florida, Mrs. Charles Sullivan (Muriel) of Toronto, Mrs Elmer Daley (Fran) of Bathurst, and Mrs Margaret Peters (Peggy) of Robertville; 56 grand children, 94 great grandchildren,  and seven great great grandchildren.  Two sons, Sterne and Gordon,  and two daughters, Mrs Everett Daley (Alice) and Mrs Patricia Scott died previously.

The body will be at Elhatton's Funeral Home, Bathurst after 2 p.m. Tuesday.  Funeral service will be held Wednesday at Central United Church, Clifton at 2 p.m.  Interment will be in the New Bandon Cemetery."

title: Glendenning, Leonard
summary: Northern Light obituary from November 13, 1958, of Leonard Glendenning, age 77, who died at home of Weston Breckenridge in Bass River after lengthy illness. Born in Canobie; lived in Palermo, Maine before returning to Salmon Beach. Survived by wife Alma Jagoe, two daughters (Verna, Millie), two sons (Myron, Stedman), and siblings. Notes large number of floral tributes. Extended family connection.
content_preview:
The Northern Light of November 13, 1958 includes the following on page 8 "Leonard Glendenning Paid Final Tribute

The death of Leonard Glendenning occurred  at the home of Weston Breckenridge in Bass River Sunday evening after a lengthy illness. He was 77.

Born in Canobie, he moved to the United States and resided in Palermo, Maine until about ten years ago when he returned to take up residence in Salmon Beach.

He is survived by his wife, the former Alma Jagoe of New Bandon; two daughters, (Verna) Mrs. Parker O'Brien of Newton, Mass; (Millie) Mrs. George Parker of Illinois; two sons, Myron of Palermo; Stedman of Hampton Heights; one sister, Mrs. Venetia Doring of Daytona Beach, Florida; two brothers, Raymond of Canobie and Guy of Florida.

A private service was held at the home of Clinton Glendenning on St. Andrew Street, Bathurst at 10:00 am Wednesday from where the funeral was held at 3:00 pm, to the Pentecostal Tabernacle where the service was conducted by Rev. S. Irvine, Rev. E. R. Woodside and Pastor Leslie Mann.  Burial was in the Sand Hill cemetery.  Pall bearers were John Glendenning, Walter Glendenning, Guy Glendenning, Sterne Glendenning, Ira Jagoe and Hazen Jagoe.

A large number of floral tributes and messages of sympathy were received by the family testifying to the high regard in which Mr. Glendenning was held."

title: Glendenning, Margaret Harley
summary: Brief genealogical note from Daniel F. Johnson's New Brunswick Newspaper Vital Statistics database. Reports death of Margaret (Harley) Glendenning on October 21, 1895 in Canobie at age 92; husband John Glendinning, Sr. died May 15, 1877. Burial at Presbyterian cemetery in New Bandon. Note about unmarked graves encountered during burial work. Purely genealogical reference.
content_preview: John Glendinning, Sr. died May 15th 1877 in Canobie; his wife, Margaret (Harley) Glendenning died on October 21, 1895.   Daniel F. Johnson's New Brunswick Newspaper Vital Statistics reports: "Clifton (Glou. Co.) October 23 - Mrs. Margaret Glendenning of Canobie departed this life Monday, Oct. 21st, at the age of 92 years.  The interment took place Wednesday 23rd in the Presbyterian burying ground, New Bandon.  Mr. MacInnis was the officiating clergyman."; presumably her husband is buried there also. George Glendenning also told me that, it was not unusual to encounter bones from unmarked graces when digging new graves.

title: Glendenning, Walter Sr.

title: Glendenning, Walter
summary: Moncton Times obituary of Walter J. Glendenning, age 84 (Don's eldest brother), who died June 16, 1998 at Moncton Hospital. Born Black River Bridge, son of Elmer and Jane Watling Glendenning. Retired from Modern Enterprises (30+ years), member St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church Moncton and past elder at St. Paul's Black River Bridge. WWII Canadian Army veteran. Married 58+ years to E. Agnes Gibson. Survived by two daughters, one son, seven grandchildren, one great-grandson, and four siblings including Don. Extensive family record.
content_preview:
The Moncton Times carried the following (Clipping undated)




"Walter J. Glendenning		Mr. Walter J. Glendenning, 84, of Beech St., Moncton and formerly of Black River Bridge, passed away at the Moncton Hospital on Tuesday, June 16, 1998 after a lengthy illness.

Born in Black River Bridge, NB, he was the eldest son of the late Elmer and Jane (Watling) Glendenning.  Walter was a retired employee of Modern Enterprises  with over 30 years service.  He was a member of St. Andrew's Presbyterian church, Moncton; a past elder of St. Paul's Presbyterian Church, Black River Bridge and was a veteran of world War ll, serving with the Canadian Army.

Walter is survived by his loving wife of over 58 years of marriage, E. Agnes (Gibson) Glendenning; two daughters, Lillian Murray (Mike). Carla Flewelling (Tom) of Moncton; one son, Stephen (Carolyn) of Brampton, ON; seven grandchildren, Kim, Stephen, Shelly, Kristy, Meghan, Sara and Michael; one great grandson, Stephen; two sisters, Venetia Russell of Point Aux Carr, NB, Lillian Weeks of Harvey Station, NB; three brothers, Kenneth (Verne) of Napan, NB, Norman (Jean) of Black river Bridge, NB, Donald (Carol) of Charlottetown, PEI; several nieces and nephews.  He was predeceased by a daughter, Betty Ann; three sisters, Grace, Elinor and Margaret Virginia; one brother, John.

Resting at Ferguson Knowles Funeral Home, 1657 Mountain Road, Moncton (858-1995) with visiting hours Thursday from 7 to 9 pm and and Friday from 2 to 4 pm and 7 to 9 pm.  Funeral services will be held at St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church, Park Street, Moncton, on Saturday, June 20 at 11 a.m. with Rev. George Anderson officiating followed by a service at St. Paul's Presbyterian Church, Black River Bridge son Saturday, June 20 at 4 pm.  Interment in the Black River Community Cemetery.

In Walter's memory, donations to the Heart and Stroke Foundation would be appreciated by the family."

title: Glendinning-front pages
summary: Front matter of major genealogical work titled "Family Series - 2: Descendants of Jubal Watling" authored by Donald E. M. Glendenning (2010).
