title: Glendinning, Kath-letter to
summary: Letter from Don Glendenning to Mrs. K. Glendinning, Low Hesket, Carlisle, Cumbria, UK (August 15, 2007). Don responds to a genealogical inquiry passed through the Dumfries and Galloway Family History Society. Outlines his direct descent from John Glendinning (b. 1807 at Callister Hall) through John's emigration to New Brunswick (1830), marriage to Margaret Harley (1833), and death in 1877 at Canobie. References his informal family newsletter and website (www.glendenning.net/don). Demonstrates Don's engagement with international genealogical communities and his role as a family historian sharing research across continents.
content_preview:
62 Queen Elizabeth Drive

Charlottetown

Prince Edward Island, C1A 3A9

Canada







Mrs. K. Glendinning

8 Southwaite Rd.

Low Hesket,Carlisle

Cumbria,  CA4 OES

United Kingdom




Dear Mrs.  Glendinning:




Your request for information, #3515, in the Dumfries and Galloway Family History Society was passed to me by a Ian Glendinning.




I am a descendant of John Glendinning and Mary Rae through their son, John, who was my great Grandfather.




John, my Great Grandfather, was born at Callister Hall in 1807, came to New Brunswick, Canada in 1830, married Margaret Harley in 1833 and died in 1877 in Canobie, New Brunswick.




Some years ago, I commenced an informal newsletter as a vehicle to pass along family information to my siblings.  I am enclosing the first issue for your information.  Since then my son, Brian, established a website and all issues of the newsletter are now found there although not all deal with family information.,   HYPERLINK "http://www.glendenning.net/don" www.glendenning.net/don.  I also may be reached by Email at  HYPERLINK "mailto:don@glendenning.net" don@glendenning.net




If you are interested, I would be delighted to share such information as I have about my branch of the family.  I am assuming that you have a family connection to John Glendinning and Mary Rae and, therefore, I would be interested in learning more about other branches of the family tree.




Sincerely







Donald Glendenning

August 15, 2007

title: Glendinning, Kath, UK
summary: Letter from Don Glendenning to Kath Glendinning in the UK (July 15, 2009) sharing a newly discovered entry in the family Bible (c. 1830) that extends his ancestry by one generation. Proposes John Glendinning (1755-1830) as his Great Great Great Grandfather, and queries Kath's knowledge to support this interpretation. Shows Don's continued genealogical investigation into late life and his international family connections with Scottish relatives. Contact address: 62 Queen Elizabeth Drive, Charlottetown, PEI; email: don@glendenning.net.
content_preview:
July 15, 2009







62 Queen Elizabeth Drive

Charlottetown, PEI	C1A 3A9

Canada




Dear Kath:




Some time ago, I had computer problems and, as a result, seem to have lost your Email address – hence this letter.




Recently, I found another entry in the family Bible in possession of my brother, Norman Glendenning – an entry, I should add, that had completely escaped me earlier.  The family Bible had belonged to my Great Grandfather, John Glendinning (1807 – 1877).  While quite faint in places, as best I can decipher, it reads:




“In Memory of John Gl(endinning?)

Who Died at Calester Hall (Parish of?) Middlbie, Dumfriesshire…

April the 14th, 1830 

Aged 75




At age 75 in 1830, this John would have been born in 1755 and could have been my Great Great Great Grandfather thus extending my family one generation earlier; if so the lineage would be:




John Glendinning	     1755-1830

John Glendinning	     1772-           m Mary Rae

John Glendinning	     1807-1877   m Margaret Harley

Walter Glendenning  1845-1908  m Elizabeth Peters

Elmer Glendenning   1875-1938  m Jane Watling

Donald Glendenning 1929-          m Carol Chesney




I am wondering if you have any information that either supports or refutes my interpretation. 




My Email address is  HYPERLINK "mailto:don@glendenning.net" don@glendenning.net




Trust all is well with you.




Warmest regards




Don Glendenning

title: Gllendenning, Hazel Stultz
summary: Florida Advocate obituary from May 29, 1936 of Robinson L. Doring, age 72, engineer and construction superintendent. Moved to Bowling Green, Florida in 1915 from Portland, Maine. Major construction projects included Stevens Creek dam, irrigation systems in Idaho, and WWI Amatol ammunition plant in New Jersey. Widow was Venetia G. Doring (Don's aunt). Children: Verna Elizabeth, Walter G., and John S. Doring. Document filed under Hazel Stultz but concerns her first husband Robinson Doring. Genealogical reference.
content_preview:
The following obituary was taken from the Florida Advocate dated May 29, 1936.




Robinson Doring Dies at Bowling Green Home




Robinson L. Doring, 72, died at his residence west of Bowling Green on Wednesday after a lengthy illness.  He was born in Perry, Maine April 24, 1864.  Moving to Bowling Green in 1915, from Portland, Me., the deceased had lived there until his death.




Mr. Doring followed hydro-electric powerhouse, dam and paper mill construction as an engineer and general construction superintendent until retiring in 1930 at his Bowling Green home.  His largest construction jobs were the Stevens Creek dam and powerhouse across the Savannah River above Augusta, Georgia; a large dirt dam and canal irrigation system in Idaho, and the construction during the World War in Amatol, N. J. of the most complete and largest ammunition loading plant and town site in the United States.




Survivors are his widow, Mrs. Venetia G. Doring; a daughter, Miss Verna Elizabeth; two sons, Walter G. and John S. Doring all of Bowling Green, and two sisters, Mrs. Charles Shaw of Perry, Me., and Miss Jessie Doring, supervisor of …(Unable to read)




Funeral services were conducted from the residence of the deceased yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock under the direction of Coker's Funeral Home, of this city, with Rev. J.F. Clark, of Bowling Green officiating.  Interment was in Bowling Green cemetery with the Masonic Order in Charge.

title: Godfrey, Janet Watling
summary: Miramichi Press (December 21, 1977) funeral service report for Mrs. Janet M. Godfrey, widow of John R. Godfrey of Black River Bridge (Don's aunt). Born Black River Bridge, daughter of Jubal and Grace MacDonald Watling. Active member St. Paul's Presbyterian Church, life member John Robertson WMS, former member Presbyterian Women's League and Women's Institute. Co-founder Victoria Knitting Club. Survived by daughter Grace Williston, son Alexander Newton, brother James A. Watling, six grandchildren, two great-grandchildren. Body placed in memorial vault pending spring burial.
content_preview:
The Miramichi Press of December 21, 1977 carried the following:

 

FUNERAL IN BLACK RIVER BRIDGE

 

The funeral service for Mrs. Janet M. Godfrey, widow of John R. Godfrey of Black River Bridge, was conducted at her home Dec. 10 at 2 p.m.

 

Rev. J. Posno conducted the service.  The organist, Mrs. Cameron Russell, played two hymns, "The Lord is My Shepherd" and "Safe in the Arms of Jesus."  "Amazing Grace" was sung by a quartet.

 

The honourary pallbearers were Rankine MacLean, George Adams, Sr., J.D. MacRae, Elliott Cail, John A. Godfrey and Kenneth Cameron.

 

Active pallbearers were Alexander Newton, Donald Newton, Norman Newton, Winfield Murdock, Austin Godfrey and Neil Watling.

 

The body was placed in the Black River Bridge Memorial Vault to await interment in the spring.

 

Born at Black River Bridge, she was the daughter of the late Jubal and Grace M. (MacDonald) Watling.  She was a member of St. Paul's Presbyterian Church, Black River Bridge, a life member of John Robertson WMS, a former member of the Presbyterian Women's League, a former member of the Women's Institute, and she took a very active part in all church affairs.  




She was one of the Founders of the Victoria Knitting Club,  Surviving are one daughter, Mrs. Grace Williston, Black River Bridge; one son, Alexander Newton, Black River Bridge; one brother, James A. Watling, Black River Bridge; six grand children and two great grandchildren.

title: Grandma Shuttle
summary: Don's narrative from March 14, 2016 (New Symrna Beach, Florida), describing receiving a weaving shuttle from his first cousin Cornelia (Glendenning) Traetta that belonged to their Great Grandmother Margaret (Harley) Glendenning (1803-1895). Documents the shuttle's journey from Ireland via Margaret's migration in the 1820s, through Margaret's grandson Walter, to Venetia Doring, then to Cornelia, and finally back to Don for donation to the New Brunswick Museum. Includes planned Facebook post text. Rich family heirloom story connecting Don to Irish heritage and frontier weaving traditions.
content_preview:
Grandma Glendenning’s shuttle




March 14, 2016

New Symrna Beach, Florida




Ha a visit today from my first cousin, Cornelia (Glendenning) Traetta, and her husband, Bob, who live in Ormond Beach not far from here.  During her visit she presented me with a shuttle that belonged to our Great Grandmother, Margaret (Harley) Glendenning. This is my understanding of the story.




The Harley’s been English but moved to Courtmacsherry, Ireland, where William Harley was believed to have been a school master.  All the children (2 boys and 3 girls) came to New Brunswick in the 1820’s; Margaret (1803-1895) married John Glendinning in 1833 settling first at Salmon Beach; later they moved to Canobie.  Pioneer Settlers, a history of Canobie, tells us that settlers had sheep,  spun their own wool and wove cloth; The book also says that John Glendenning had one of the first “weaving machines” (looms) in Canobie and taught many in  the community to weave, including Grandparents of Alma (Knowles) Glendenning.  Several family members including my mother, know/knew the story.  It certainly could even have been  a family heirloom given to Margaret prior to her departure for the New World.




The shuttle passed presumably through Margaret’s son, Walter, to granddaughter, Venetia (Glendenning) Doring who passed it to her niece, Cornelia (Glendenning) Traetta.  The story came up in a conversation a number of years ago, perhaps in the 1980’s, when visiting Bob and Cornelia; during the conversation, Cornelia left the room for a moment and returned with the shuttle.  In a telephone conversation, perhaps 3-4 years ago, Cornelia told me of a discussion with her family and the decision to return the shuttle to Canada.  The transfer was made today. 




The shuttle, measuring 111/4 x 11/8 z 7/8, tapered at both ends, is made of a dark wood like walnut and is in excellent condition.




My plan is to first put a photo and brief paragraph on Facebook and then donate it to the New Brunswick Muse...

title: Hampton,VA
summary: A concise genealogical summary (titled "Meadows to Little Branch") documenting the Watling family migration and property succession. Details Jubal Watling Sr.'s 1814 marriage to Susan Leach in England; the immigration of five children to Canada; Jubal Jr.'s 1851 land petition and 1881 grant of Lot #30 (100 acres) in the Meadows where Don's mother was born; Grace MacDonald's 1874 marriage to Jubal Jr.; their move to Little Branch after 1901; Alexander MacDonald's original 1812 grant and property division between his son John and daughter Jessie; and the November 1901 agreement where Jubal and Grace took over John's Little Branch property to care for elderly Elspeth MacDonald and her son James. Notes Jubal Jr.'s death on February 16, 1915, and Uncle Jim's return from Portland to manage the farm.
content_preview:
________________Meadows to Little Branch




Jubal Watling married a Susan Leach in Metfield, Suffolk County, England on November 14, 1814 and moved to Syleham, Suffolk County, England where their son, Jubal, was baptized on August 17, 1823.  They likely stayed in England, however, the following children came to Canada:

Jubal who married Christina MacNaughton

William who married Mary MacNaughton

Mary Ann who married William Maxwell

George who moved to the USA

Emma who married William Eddy




Jubal Watling petitioned for land (F4243) on the south side of Black River on April 9, 1851, presumably this is the Jubal who married Christina MacNaughton.  They also had a son, Jubal. 




Alexander MacDonald was granted Lot #2 on the Little Black River on June 2, 1812.  Half the property passed to his son, John, (where Uncle Jim Watling lived) and the other half passed to his daughter, Jessie.  My father bought the Jessie MacDonald property on July 21, 1914.




Grace, the daughter of John and Elspeth (Jardine) Watling married Jubal Watling on Dec 22, 1874 and, moved to Lot #30 in The Meadows.  (The Meadows has long since been reclaimed by the forests.)  All of their children were born there.




I believe that the elder Jubal died in 1900 and his wife, Christina died in 1901; Grace’s father, John MacDonald also died in 1900.  Graces mother was not well  (She died of “debility” in 1907) and Grace’s brother, James, was living at home but was not able to look after the farm. An agreement was struck late in 1901 for Elspeth MacDonald and her son, James, to turn over the property at Little Branch to Grace and Jubal.  In return, Grace and Jubal, and their sons, agreed to “keep, support, maintain and provide the said James J. MacDonald and his mother, Mrs. John D. MacDonald, each of them and the survivor of them during the respective terms of their natural lives with good and sufficient house, roof, meat, drink, washing, clothing, bedding, fire, light, medicine, medical atten...

title: Harley, Biography of John Harley
summary:
Dictionary of Miramichi Biography entry documenting John Harley (b. 1800 Courtmacsberry, Cork, Ireland; d. 1875 Chatham Head, NB). Harley was a prominent ship carpenter, master builder, and businessman who came to Miramichi around 1823. He built 62 ships on Miramichi (1850-1866), served as militia officer, justice of the peace, commissioner of lights, and harbormaster. Married Ann Coughlan in 1829; had three sons and two daughters, including Fanny Harley who married Charles Sargeant. Important connection to Carol Louise Chesney's Harley family ancestry.
- **Note:** Third-party source document (biographical dictionary entry).
content_preview:
Dictionary of Miramichi Biography







HARLEY, JOHN, ship carpenter and master builder, businessman, inspector of lights, harbormaster and JP; b. Courtmacsberry, Co. Cork, Ireland, 1800; m. 1829, Ann Coughlan, also a native of Ireland; d. Chatham Head, 26 Sep 1875.




The son of an Irish schoolmaster, John Harley came to the Miramichi around 1823 after a brother and sister had previously entered the province. He hired as a ship carpenter with William Abrams, for whom he was later master builder for more than twenty years. After Abrams died he became the master builder at Joseph Russell's yard on Beaubear's Island. 







In 1850, after Russell had given up his shipyard and lumber business in order to move to Utah, John Harley and George Burchill bought it for a fraction of its true value. During tbe next seven years they conducted woods operations, ran a sawmill, and built nine ships, all of whicb were sold in Britain. After their partnership was dissolved in 1857, Harley continued to build ships on the island with the help of his sons. In all, be is credited with having built sixty-two ships on the Miramichi, the last two in 1866. At around this time he lost the island to the Commercial Bank, to which it had been mortgaged some years previously. It was bought by Peter Mitchell in 1871. 




Harley was commissioned a lieutenant in the 2nd Battalion of militia in 1836 and promoted to captain in 1846. He retired with this rank in 1864. He undertook numerous community responsibilities at the parish level and in 1855 was appointed a justice of the peace. In 1851 he was made one of the three commissioners of lights for the Gulf of St Lawrence. This led to his appointment by the federal government, after Confederation, as inspector of lights, buoys, and beacons in New Brunswick. He attended to this work until 1871, when he retired. Meanwhile, in 1867, he was appointed harbormaster, as successor to Alexander Goodfellow, and he retained this position until overtaken by ...

title: Henry-Homespun Volume I
summary:
Extensive personal memoirs titled "Homespun Memories of a New Brunswick (Canada) Boyhood" by Rev. Frederick William Henry (b. 1872 near Bathurst, NB; d. 1964 Denver, CO). Contains multiple narrative sections: Rev. Henry's funeral notice (died Jan. 11, 1964, age 91); memoir by his mother Elizabeth Henry detailing family origins in Ireland, emigration, frontier life (teaching school, running shops, managing household during her husband's injury, 1844-1881); grandmother's memoir by Mary Ann Harley Henry (b. 1799 Courtmasherry, Cork, Ireland) describing 1822 emigration at age 23, marriage to John Henry (1823), and 19th-century New Brunswick settlement life; plus prefatory historical essays on Ulster-Scots settlement patterns and reflections on pioneer life. Rich primary source showing family resilience, women's roles, education, and community building. George Henry (Frederick's father) was directly related to John Harley (shipbuilder). Excellent biographical and historical material.
- **Note:** Personal memoir/autobiography; contains edited transcription note by Robert John Stevens (2008).
content_preview:
HOMESPUN

MEMORIES

of a

NEW BRUNSWICK (CANADA) BOYHOOD










Frederick William Henry







Note: Several years ago—probably in 2000, I had a BYU coed transcribe this from a copy of the original typed-written copy in my procession, which I obtained from Earline Gertrude (Stevens) Wright (January 4, 1926, South Portland, Maine – October 7, 2006, Standish, Maine), who was the long.-time nurse and founding Trustee of the Remick. Museum in Tamworth, New Hampshire. Earline new Frederick Henry and probably got her copy directly from him or from her cousin George Allan Henry.




This a very historical manuscript that details life in New Brunswick in the 19th century. Many historians would love to get their hands on it. I’ll try to find the time to proof read it and insert the diagrams.---Robert John Stevens, Highland, Utah, January 13, 2008.










Rev. Frederick W. Henry

DENVER, Colo. – Funeral services for the Rev. Frederick W. Henry, 91, formally of Portland, Maine, were held last Tuesday, with burial in Crown Hill Cemetery here.




The Rev. Mr. Henry, who had lived in Denver 62 years, died Jan. 11 in St. Anthony’s Hospital after a short illness.

He was born near Bathurst, N.B. June 6, 1872, son of George and Elizabeth Smith Henry. He was educated in public schools in Portland and studied for the ministry at Bible College, Transylvania University, Lexington, Ky.




The Rev. Mr. Henry came to Colorado in June 1889 as a minister at Loveland. He attended the University of Nebraska in 1899 and was a minister in Trinidad in 1900.




He married the former Edna D. Miller of Rockport, Mo., Dec. 28, 1900, in Colorado Springs. Mrs. Henry died Nov. 26, 1958.




They came here in 1901 and Mr. Henry combined work as an office equipment salesman with ministry of the Christian Church.




He was pastor of Berkeley, Col., Christian Church for a total of 15 years over five periods. During World War I he was director of YMCA activities with the Italian Army in Italy and w...

title: HOME
summary: Don's account of the family home in Little Branch, originally built in the mid-to-late 1800s for Miss Jessie (schoolteacher who died 1912). Elmer Glendenning purchased it in 1914 and significantly expanded it in 1919 to accommodate his growing family of nine children (four daughters, five sons). Details the major renovation including added ell, new kitchen, dining room, parlour, bedroom on first floor, and four upstairs bedrooms. Describes sourcing materials from their own property: spruce framing, maple floors, pine cupboards from Fowlie's mill. Includes outbuildings: barn, henhouse, grain shed, privy, and seed shed for Agricultural Society #103.
content_preview:
HOME







Miss Jessie’s home sao n a hill overlooking the Little Branch School, an appropriate location for a school teacher.  The home itself, in Miss Jessie’s day was a modest one and would have been quit appropriate for an unmarried school teacher in the late 1800s.  Miss Jessie died in 1912 at the age of 89, my father bought the home in 1914.  We do not know when it was built but probably in the mid to late 1800s.




It was a typical small farm home of the period.  One and one-half story with a pitched roof and a parlour just inside the front door.  The kitchen was likely attached with winding stairs to the second floor bedrooms.




My father bought the property in 1914 and, with Mum and the three oldest children, live there for a period of two years; then they returned to the USA.  In 1919, the family, now six in all, returned permanently to Little Branch.   – and more space was needed. He added an ell and remodeled the existing house and ended up with a large kitchen with a pantry  and back entry a dining room, parlour and a bedroom on the first floor.  There were four bedrooms on the second floor.  Under it all was a full basement with a large shute for putting wood in the basement and a verandah across the front.  Here they raised a family of four daughters and five sons.  Lumber for the addition and renovation was cut on the property, likely sawed at Fowlie’s mill, a mile further up the Little Branch River and included the spruce for framing, maple for the new floors and pine for the cupboards and trim.  The cedar shingles may have been cut on the property but most likely were purchased in Loggieville or Chatham.  




Outbuildings included a traditional barn about 100 feet from the house to which my father had added a piece thereby doubling its size, a henhouse, a grain shed and an outdoor privy.  The “seed shed”, owned by Agricultural Society #103, was located across the lane and for a few weeks in the fall of 1939, the shanty from the ridge was locat...

title: Homestead Map
summary: Don references a homestead map by Roe & Colby from 1876 showing residences in Black River at that time, including names in the Meadows, Little Branch, and McKenzie Settlement areas. Don notes that the Glendennings were "latecomers to Black River and are not included," indicating his family arrived after 1876. This documents available historical cartographic sources for the community.
content_preview:
Homestead Map - 1876




A homestead map by Roe & Colby shows the names, but not lot numbers, of people living in Black River in 1876; In the Meadows, on the south side of the River, we find D. Macbeth, J. Watling, W. MacNaughton, D. McNaughton, D. Cameron, J. Watling, and G. Archibald.  On the north side, across from the Meadows it shows J. Edge and W. Watling.




On the south side of the Little Branch, we find the Branch School, J. McDonald, J. McNaughton, G. Fowley and S. McDonald.




The McKenzie road included a McKenzie -no initial, J. Anderson, R. Robinson, J. McKenzie, R. MacKenzie, Mrs. Ward and M. McDonald.




The Glendennings were latecomers to Black River and are not included.

title: Jane
summary: Comprehensive biographical entry on Jane Elizabeth Jardine Watling (Elmer's wife, Don's mother), born February 28, 1890 at the Meadows, Upper Black River, NB. Second youngest of eight children of Jubal Watling and Grace MacAskill MacDonald; named after Jane Elizabeth Jardine (who married Donald Cameron). Documents her arrival in Portland, Maine on January 24, 1908 (day City Hall burned; age just prior to 18th birthday). Describes initial employment as nanny/housekeeper, likely with Mrs. Jennison family caring for children Marshall and Brian. Includes extensive documentation of friendships through photographs and autograph album entries (1910-1913): the Jennison, Ratcliffe, Kennedy, Courtney, and Lawrence families; friends including Goldie Ratcliffe (Cleveland, TN connection), Mae and Stanley Franke. Details her residence at 130 Emery Street, Portland and social circle. Final section on "Life Together in USA" describes marriage to Elmer at parents' home October 18, 1910 (Rev. George Grant officiating), honeymoon in Montreal, residence in Bonny Eagle, Maine, and move to Parksville, Tennessee. Chronicles household budget entries January 1911 showing domestic economy (cordwood, milk, flour, fish purchases). Not first-person from Jane but extensively documented family record compiled by Don.
content_preview:
JANE ELIZABETH JARDINE WATLING










Jane Watling was born, presumably at  home, at the Meadows, Upper Black River, New Brunswick on February 28, 1890. Although her name was Jane, it seems that Dad always called her Jean.  This may account for the fact that the Watling side of the family continued to call her Jane (or Janie as Uncle Ern called her) while the Glendenning side of the family referred to her as Jean.  I remember Mum saying that Dad referred to her as "Jeannie with the light brown hair".  Agnes has an annual report from St. Stephen's Presbyterian Church (now United Church), which shows the name as Jane.  . 




Jane was the second youngest of a family of eight born to Jubal Watling and Grace MacAskill MacDonald.   She was named after Jane Elizabeth Jardine who married Donald Cameron (Cameron Russell=s grandmother)  A few years ago when visiting Francis and Phyllis MacNaughton in Vancouver, Phyllis showed a framed, handmade embroidery (?) made by Jane Elizabeth Jardine.




When Mum was about 10 years old, the family moved from the Meadows to the Branch.  We know that she went to school in Upper Black River; it is unlikely that she went or went for very long to the school at the Branch.  I remember Mum saying that her mother would take her from school to help Aunt Elspie MacNaughton who had a young and growing family and needed help.




Portland, Maine




Jane Watling arrived in Portland on January 24, 1908 just prior to her 18th birthday.  In the same way as Maritimers now do to Ontario, points west or overseas, in those days young people went to "the Boston States". Young women frequently were employed to look after children and to do housework. 




The exact date that of her arrival in Portland is known only because she arrived there on the day that the City Hall burned.   I have since confirmed, through a phone call to the Portland Public Library, that the fire occurred on January 24, 1908.  (I also recalled Mum saying that she could have gone ...

title: John Glendinning
summary: Genealogical documentation of John Glendinning Sr. (Elmer's grandfather) and son Walter; legal petition records for land grants in Canobie, NB. Documents John Sr.'s two petitions (1854/1855) for 100-acre lots with notation of "forty-seven years" age in both petitions; lots were vacant but improved by applicant. Walter's petition (1865 notation, pre-printed "AUCTION" header) for Lot 30 Canobie, showing land transfer lineage from Charles Scott to John Glendinning to Walter. Notes significant lag between petition and actual grant (Walter's grant dated February 17, 1873). John Jr. land grant record (Lot 31, August 17, 1868). Includes tangential historical note: "The Pious Pirate" - San Salvador Island's Watling Castle, named Captain George Watling (buccaneer/"pious pirate" forbidding Sabbath card play/piracy), confirming no Watling family pirate connection. Brief final section on Grandfather Glendenning's land holdings itemization from will: 100-acre homestead (Lot 30, inherited by Leonard), 100 acres Canobie (Lot 28, to wife Elizabeth), Stevens Farm 100 acres (to wife with proviso to son Raymond if he settled Canobie), Taylor Farm 50 acres (to wife, eventually inherited/sold to daughter Venetia, then Matt Ellis). Primarily legal/archival document rather than narrative biography.
content_preview:
John Glendinning, Sr. (F5929, F5931)




John Glendinning, my Great Grandfather petitioned for two lots of 100 acres each in Canobie.  One petition shows the name as John Glendinning, Sr. and the other shows only John Glendinning but in both cases the age is given as Aforty-seven years@ so they are both the same person.  The petitions are faint and difficult to read.




One petition identifies the year as 1854 and mentions the Awest half of@ ....  No lot number is given.  The lot was vacant but had been improved by applicant.




The other petition, in 1855,  clearly identifies  lot #30 in Canobie which appears to have been surveyed in 1848 for Charles Scott.  The lot was vacant but improved - whether improved by John Glendinning, Charles Scott, or someone else we do not know.




Walter Glendinning (F9029)




Walter Glendinning of the Parish of New Bandon petitioned for one hundred acres situate as follows: ALot No. 30, Canobie, formerly surveyed for Charles Scott. By him transferred to John Glendinning and from John Glendinning to his son Walter the present applicant.@  The land is said to be occupied by the applicant, Walter Glendinning, and his father and improved by applicant and his father.  A notation on the top of the petition shows 1865.  Interestingly, the top of this form is pre-printed with the word AAUCTION@.  

My other source shows a grant of Lot #30 in Canobie to Walter Glendenning on February 17, 1783.  That is quite a lag between the making of a petition and the actual grant being made.




John Glendenning




While I did not find a petition from John Glendinning, Jr.  My reference shows a grant to John Glendenning of Lot #31 on August 17, 1868.




The Pious Pirate




San Salvador Island is part of the Bahamas.    On Sandy Point sits Watling Castle.  The island was originally named Watling=s Island in honour of Captain George Watling a famous buccaneer and pirate.  (It was renamed in 1926).  He was also known as the Apious pirate@ because he w...

title: John Watling Descendants (1)
summary: Extended genealogical research on descendants of John L. Watling (1825-), Don's ancestor. Details his immigration from England, marriage to Jessie Carruthers (1849), and census records tracking the family through 1871. Demonstrates Don's genealogical methodology and family connections.
content_preview:
Descendants of John L. Watling







First Generation




	1.	John L. Watling  was born in Dec 1825 in Syleham, Suffolk, England. He was christened on 6 Mar 1825 in Syleham, Suffolk, England. He died before 1920 in probably Ayer Junction, Massachusetts. 




John was employed as  a plasterer/mason. 




It is presumed that John Watling died before the Watlings made the Atlantic crossing in June of 1830, as 

he does not appear in any New Brunswick records.  That is, unless he did not make the crossing or 

settled somewhere other than NB.

There is another possibility, however. A John Watling appears in the 1851 NB Census. That census 

shows him in Napan, an immigrant of 1845 and the husband of Jessie (Carruthers). Perhaps our John 

stayed in England for some years before he immigrated to Canada. Some members of the family believe 

this to be true. Below is what I know about the family of John and Jessie (Carruthers) Watling, to err on 

the side of caution.

 - John Watling married Jessie Carruthers at Napan in June 1849, as reported in the 26 June 1849 issue 

of The Gleaner and Northumberland Schediasma. Jessie was the daughter of James Sr. and Jane 

Carruthers.

 - In the 1851 Census, John is listed with his wife Jessie in Napan, with a 1 year old daughter, Janet N. 

Watling. 

 - In the 1861 Census, John and Jessie are listed in the Parish of Newcastle with: Jennet (aged 11), 

Robert (aged 8), Susan J. (aged 5), and Mary A. (aged 2). Also, a 16 year old Jennet Edge (presumably 

of the Black River Edges), was their servant.

 - In the 1865-66 and 1867-68 Hutchison Directories, John is listed as living on McCallum St. in 

Newcastle, a mason by trade. He does not appear in the 1871 Lovell Directory.

 - Neither John nor Jessie appears in the 1871 Census. However, Robert , Jennet, and a William appear 

in Newcastle. Robert was employed as a clerk, living with the family of John Fish. Jennet and William 

appear in the household of James Fowler. Susan and ...

title: Jubal Watling
summary: A short note on Jubal Watling's land petition (F4243) dated April 9, 1851, requesting 50 acres on the south side of Black River. Documents the petition's status uncertainties and notes a later grant of 100 acres (Lot #30) in the Meadows to Jubal Watling Jr. on April 20, 1881. Identifies conflicting information in different sources and Don's hope to resolve discrepancies with further research. **NOT originally written by Don** — this is a documentary note on archival records.
content_preview:
Jubal Watling (F4243)




A petition for 50 acres of land Asituate as follows: on the South side of Black River adjoining south of William McBeath=s meadow  lot and east of a lot applied for by John Edge@  The petition is dated at Chatham on April 9, 1851 and includes his signature.  The property was vacant, surveyed but without improvements.  Other handwritten notes on the page are confusing in that they show apparent approval on May 21/51 and AAuction, August 51".  They are signed by Peters, the Deputy Surveyor.  No lot number is given.




The confusion arises from the fact that, my other sources show the William McBeath lot to 




be east of the ARichibucto Road@, Lot No. 30, consisting of 100 acres in the Meadows was granted to Jubal Watling, Junior on April 20, 1881.  This would be my Grandfather and certainly matches the location where Mum was born.  It is certainly possible that the first Jubal petitioned but did not receive the land,  that the land he petitioned was somewhere else or that the information on location was not correct.  Hopefully, we will be able to sort it out later.

title: Kelly,Peter
summary: Obituary of Peter Kelly (died December 17, age 95), native of Thomastown, Kilkenny, Ireland, who arrived in Canada in 1828. Educated teacher and "fine Penman" who educated many Black River and surrounding area residents. Noted for sincere practical piety and Presbyterian faith. Maintained hale and hearty lifestyle until near death. Document includes verse tribute and was submitted by Judy Watling (great-granddaughter). Historical community record with tangential family connection.
content_preview:
Peter Kelly




OBITUARY:- The late Mr. Peter Kelly who died at Black River on December 17th in his 95th year was a native of Thomastown, Kilkenny, Ireland.   Mr. Kelly arrived in this country in 1828.  Having a good education, he engaged in teaching for several years.  He was a fine Penman and well versed in the common branches of learning, and a considerable number of the inhabitants of Black River and the surrounding district are indebted to him for the education they received.  Mr. Kelly was a man of great intelligence.  His piety was sincere and practical, he was a …….Presbyterian church.  His memory will be held in respect and regard, for many a day.  He was hale and hearty till within a brief period of his death.  His life was truly a useful one, and it may be said of him in the (words?) of the lines:

How blest the righteous, which …

When sinks a weary soul to rest

How mildly beam the closing eyes

How gently heaves the expiring breast.




Sent to me by Judy Watling

A great Granddaughter

title: Kim-4
summary: Email thread between Don Glendenning and Kim Nielsen (January 2008) regarding the Harley family genealogy. Discusses Thomas Harley's presence in Toronto and York area in 1834, his position as Constable, and potential connections to the Harley relatives Don is researching. Kim mentions Loyalist connections (Barnes family) and attempts to establish family relationships. Shows Don's collaborative genealogical efforts and his interest in connecting various branches of ancestor families across different regions and time periods.
content_preview:
From: "Kim Nielsen" <chriskim@telusplanet.net>

To: "Don Glendenning" <dglende@pei.sympatico.ca>

Subject: Re: Harley

Date: January 25, 2008 6:10 PM




Hi Don,  just a quick question.  Do you recognize the surname Shortel? Back in 2005 I was in touch with a Warren Forsythe regarding a Timothy F. Harley.  His site is http://wc.rootsweb.com.  His Harley relatives came from Cork Ireland and were in New Brunswick about the same time as the ones we are researching.  I will have to go back to his site and check it out as my memory not so great.  Also getting back to my Thomas, He was in the City of Toronto in 1934 just before Toronto became a city actually.  There was a special sitting on Feb 2 for the Common Council (I'm not sure what this is) but there was a petition of Thomas Harley for situation of Constable.

Feb 15th - Report #1 which was received and read viz constable Thomas Harley which the standing committee on offices beg to submit to the favourable consideration of the council.

Feb - 27 was turned down by common council for a full time job by a vote of 10 to 6. 

Anyway this goes on but did you not mention you had relatives in York about the same time 1834 or so.  I tell you I'm expecting a new computer in a couple of days and I have been busy printing all my genealogy and it's all in a pile.  But I thought I remembered someone saying they had relatives in that area.  I also remember something of the Barnes family being Loyalists and I thought the Harley's might be also but this was something I haven't checked into yet.  Maybe that's how Thomas met Margaret.




Kim

  From: Don Glendenning

  Subject: Re: Harley







  After sending te other note, Ichecked the name Barnes.  There are 8 entries: 4 from Westmoreland Co, one from each of York, Charlotte, Kings and Queens counties.  Given the dates, 1773-1786, they may have been Loyalists




  Regards




  Don

title: King's Visit
summary: Two anecdotes related to British royalty. First is a childhood memory of stubbing his toe on a fence post stub in the lane—still remembered painfully. Main focus is the 1938/1939 visit of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth to Newcastle, when Don (age ~15-17) and about 20-25 others from Little Branch traveled by truck (possibly Smith family-owned) to witness the royals. Describes arriving early morning, standing throughout, and returning late evening singing. Includes the charming story of two sisters from Blackville/Boiestown photographing each other instead of the royal couple. Notes the Queen Mother's later death prompted this recollection.
content_preview:
My sore toe




Presumably when Dad put up the concrete post, he widened the lane.  I recall the stub of a fence post sticking up a couple of inches or so in the middle of the lane.  I not only recall seeing it but also recall feeling it when I stubbed my toe.  It hurts yet when I think about it. 










Queen Mother=s Birthday




The celebration of the Queen Mother=s birthday reminds me of the visit by the King and Queen to Newcastle in 1939.  We travelled to Newcastle in Hassie (?) Smith=s truck.  Or was it Harry or BW= truck?  As I recall, it was a sunny day and we were picked up at the Branch school about 5:30 am.  We stood in the back of the truck; I cannot recall who all was there but believe it included Ken, Norm, Roy, George, Harry MacLean, etc.  Probably 20 to 25 all together.




We saw the King and Queen and then came home.  As I recall, Mum packed a lunch but I am not sure.  We arrived home sometime in late evening, singing all the way.




The King and Queen motored to Fredericton from Newcastle.  The story is told about the two sisters in Blackville or Boiestown who waited on the side of the road for the King and Queen to pass.  They has each bought a camera and film to ensure that at least one would get a photo.  Just before the Royal Party came along, the sisters decided that one should be on each side of the road so that, whichever way the Royal couple faced, they would have them in the photo.  The Royal couple drove past smiling and waving.  They had seen their beloved Monarch. 




They could hardly wait to have their photos developed.  Imagine their surprise when they got their photos developed; they missed the  royal couple when they whizzed past but they had a great photo of each other.




Queen Mother




The death of the Queen Mother brought to mind the visit of the King and Queen to Newcastle in 1938. The King and Queen came by train to Newcastle then went by car to Fredericton.




A number of us from the Little Branch, maybe 15 or so?...

title: Land Grants
summary: Detailed land grant registry for the Little Black River area compiled from New Brunswick Department of Natural Resources records. Lists original Crown grants with lot numbers, acreages, grantee names, and dates from 1812 onward. Documents Alexander McDonald Sr.'s 1812 grant of Lot #2 (225 acres, now owned by Norman Glendenning), Sinclair, Glendinning, and Glendenning family grants, and Jubal Watling Jr.'s 1881 grant of Lot #30 in the Meadows. Notes Elmer Glendenning's 1936 grant of 100 acres. Includes detailed lot maps showing neighbors. Questions origin of "Millers Bridge" at Norman's property. **NOT originally written by Don** — this is compiled from government records.
content_preview:
Land Grants




The Department of Natural Resources, Fredericton has maps showing the first owners of land granted by the Crown.  They also have a book listing all the original owners.  Information in the book and maps should be the same, but isn=t always.  The following information was gleaned from these sources.




Alexander McDonald Sr. (not MacDonald) was granted Lot #2, 225 acres, on 1812-06-03. This is the property now owned by Norman Glendenning.




On the same date and further up the Branch




Kenneth Sinclair was granted Lot #3 with 220 acres.

Angus Sinclair was granted Lots 4 & 5 with 410 acres.

Alexander McDonald (the book says Sr. but the map shows Jr.) was granted Lot #6 consisting of 140 acres.

The next land was granted to George Fowlie but numbers and boundaries are not clear to me.




The west side of the Alexander McDonald property forms the rear line of the following properties:

Lot A - Enoch Godfrey

Lots # 1, 2 & 3 - John McLean

Lot #4 - Alexander Gunn

Lot #5 - Robert MacBeath

Lot #6 - John MacLeod




On 1936-09-16, Elmer Glendenning was granted 100 acres, Lot #7s.  This would be John=s woodlot.  The front half of this property was owned by Thomas Patterson.




Jubal Watling, Jr. was granted Lot #30, 100 acres, on the south side of Black River on 1881-04-20.




Next to Jubal, towards the highway, were Gardiner Archibald, Lot #29, granted in 1880-05-10 and Richard Hutchison, Lot #28, granted in 1849-0604.




Next to Jubal, up river, was Donald Cameron on Lot #31 granted in 1854-01-30.




Canobie




I cannot find any original grant to John Glendinning therefore, he must have purchased from someone else. APioneers of the Bay Chaleur@ says he bought part of Lot #7 in Salmon beach; this land was granted originally to Fidele and Joseph Arceneau in 1812-06-01.  The@Pioneer Book@ also says that John Glendinning sold his land in 1855 in Salmon Beach to Abram Buttimer and was granted land in Canobie in 1868







Lot #31, 100 acres, in Ca...

title: Lister, Patricia Weeks
summary: Obituary of Patricia Jane Lister, age 37, who died September 19, 1984 at Victoria General Hospital Halifax. Only daughter of K. Brydone Weeks and Lillian (Glendenning) Weeks of Black River Bridge. Wife of Paul Lister of New Maryland. Survived by husband, parents, paternal grandmother Eva Weeks, three brothers (John, Kenneth, Heath), and extended family. Funeral and burial September 23 at New Maryland United Church. Document lists attending relatives including Norman and John Glendenning families. Cousin of Don's generation.
content_preview:
Clipping, date and source unknown:

Died in Halifax

Word has been received of the death on September 19, 1984 of Patricia; Jane Lister of New Maryland, who died at the Victoria General Hosital, Halifax at age 37 years.  The wife of Paul Lister, she was the only daughhter of K. Brydone weeks formerly of Loggieville and Lillian (Glendenning) Weeks of Black River Bridsge.  Besides her husband and parents she is survived by her paaternal grandmother, Mrs. Eva Weeks of Loggieville; three brothers, John, saint John; Kenneth of Harvey Station; and Heath at home; several aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces and nephews.  Funeral and burial took place at New Maryland united church on sunday, September 23.

Among relatives attending the funeral or visiting the funeral home were Mr and Mrs Norman Glendenning and daughters Eileen Glendenning and LoisAnne Gregan, Mr. and Mrs John Glendenning and daughters, Mrs Ray Williston and Mrss Aubrey Gibson and Mr. Gibson; Mr and Mrs Cameron Russell, Mr and Mrs Kenneth Glendenning, also many other relatives and friends.

title: Living costs
summary: Provides historical economic snapshot of Black River community in 1939 and pricing data from 1947. Lists community facilities in 1939: community hall, four one-room schools (Little Branch, Cameron, Upper Black River, Victoria), Miramichi Rural High School at Bayside, two churches (St. Stephen's United, St. Paul's Presbyterian), and Agricultural Society #103. Cites records kept by brother Walter showing 1947 prices: butter at 45 cents/pound, eggs at 30 cents/dozen, young pig at $5, and wage work with New Brunswick Hydro at 55 cents/hour.
content_preview:
Community Facilities




In 1939, Black River was served a community Hall, four one-room schools (Little Branch, Middle Black River (Cameron), Upper Black River and Victoria), the Miramichi Rural High School at Bayside (Miramichi) and two churches (St. Stephen’s United and St. Paul’s Presbyterian).  The Community also had a community Hall and an active Agricultural Society, #103.







Living Costs




According to records kept by my brother, Walter Glendenning, in 1947 he received 45 cents per pound for butter, 30 cents a dozen for eggs, $5.00 for a young pig and 55 cents per hour for work with New Brunswick Hydro.

title: Lodges
summary: Documents Elmer's fraternal organization memberships. Presents facsimile of Hadattah Lodge No. 117 (Independent Order of Odd Fellows) certificate dated October 21, 1901 in Portland, Maine admitting "Bro. Elmer A. Glendenning" to membership. Includes handwritten inscription from Masonic textbook: "I was made a Master Mason the last Saturday night in 1911 at Ocoee Lodge No. 212, Benton, Tennessee, E.A.Glendenning." Notes Masonic book presentation from James Cortey of Knoxville, Tennessee. Provides context: Elmer and Jane established household in Parksville, Tennessee April 11, 1911; Elmer worked on Ocoee No. 1 dam construction; later worked on Ocoee No. 2 (few miles upriver). Jane returned to NB for Walter's birth September 1913; both returned to NB 1914. Fraternal organization involvement indicates Elmer's community engagement and social standing. Evidence of multiple organizations across geographic relocations.
content_preview:
Lodges




While looking through papers recently, I came across a certificate from Hadattah Lodge No. 117, Independent Order of Odd Fellows which reads s follows:




Portland, Me. , Oct 21st, 1901

This Certifies that Bro. Elmer A. Glendenning

Was this evening admitted to membership in this lodge.

John Steward  N.G

Henry G. Milliken Sec’y




In a Masonic Text Book, in Dad’s handwriting, is the following inscription:




I was made a Master Mason the last Saturday night in 1911 at Ocoee Lodge No. 212, Benton, Tennessee, E.A.Glendenning




And in another Masonic Book in Dad’s handwriting:




Presented to E. A. Glendenning

By James Cortey of

Knoxville, Tennessee




Dad and Mum set up housekeeping in Parksville, Tennessee on April 11, 1911 and their first child, Grace was born there. Dad worked on the construction of Ocoee No. 1, a dam at Parksville.  Later they moved a few miles up river where a second dam, Ocoee #2,  was built.  Mum returned to NB for Walter’s birth in 1913.  Dad may or may not have accompanied her but they were both in NB in 1914.

title: MacKay-2
summary:
Email correspondence from Dorothy & Bryan (February 22, 2006) to Don Glendenning regarding MacKay family genealogy, specifically regarding Norm and Peter MacKay genealogies. Includes descendants of John MacKay (1802-1880 married Marjory Cameron 1807-1878), listing eight children including Elizabeth, Jane, Peter, Archibald, Alexander James, Allan, Thomas George, and Hugh MacKay with marriage dates and death years. Writer references Peter MacKay obituary and asks for Don's input on genealogical connections. Shows Don was actively consulting with family members on genealogical research.
- **Note:** Third-party correspondence; email message preserved in genealogy files.

title: MacKay, Shirley letter from Elspie
summary: Personal letter dated February 8, 1943, from Elspie (Elspeth) to John, written from Black River. Rich with details of daily life during WWII era: weather, egg sales, logging operations, family news including son Clifford being called (to military service), wartime rationing of butter, concerns about Churchill and Stalin, local accidents (Bob MacDonald's injury), and cheerful family updates. Signed "Love to all. Mother" with note that "Jean's little girl is Norma Fay." Captures intimate family correspondence and historical context of rural New Brunswick during wartime. **Note: Written by Elspeth Watling MacNaughton, compiled by Shirley E. MacKay.**
content_preview:
Black River, Feb. 8th/43




Dear John:

     I do like to think that the winter is getting shorter each day. Soon be the middle of the month. 

We have had some warm days. Had some rain, and today was like spring. Colder again tonight. 

The snow plow is up to Dicks. I think he must be staying there tonight. It will be nice to have an 

open road again. I was to Newcastle and Chatham today. Doug Campbell cane in to the crossroads, 

and Gordon MacNaughton, brought me down from there. The Roads in Newcastle are like spring, 

pools of water. I had 20 doz. Of eggs out, but the price is down now to .30 cents. 

     Our chickens are more than working. The men are still hauling off their logs. Said it would take them this week. He is going to Bartibogue tomorrow to run a line for Kerr Loggie. He has to go to Redbank, this week too.

     What is Clifford doing? I just heard he had been called. Carlyle Edge, Boston has been called too. He is coming home for a visit, before he goes. He lives with his Aunt Cassie.

    Bob MacDonald met with a nasty hurt, on Friday. He was coming in from town, with Jack Dick, in a sled. They were sitting on a board, you know the way, they make a seat on a sled. Just a narrow margin of the seat over the side of the sled. A car came along at a great speed, caught the end of the seat., twitched it around, and jammed Bob's leg. Gave him a compound fracture, below the knee. The bone cut through the flesh. Arch his brother took him to the hospital. They reported it to the Mounties and they got the men. They had never stopped. I believe they were so drunk, they upset the car twice before they got to St. Margarets. The last time they turned it in the ditch. The police took possession fo the car. The owner was a man from St. John, Provincial salesman for the Irving Oil Co., and a young chap from Newcastle, who was getting a ride to St. John. He was doing the driving.

They say he is a splendid man this Dolan, and had a great job. Probably be lost ...

title: MacKenzie, Alex 22 Jan 08
summary:
Comprehensive genealogical research on descendants of Alexander MacKenzie (b. ca. 1780 Assynt, Sutherland, Scotland; d. after 1811). Documents his marriage to Annabella Watson (Jan. 10, 1800) and their children including David, Isobell, Euphemia, Allan, Hector, and Rodrick. Traces second generation including David MacKenzie (christened 1801, married Katherine Kerr 1835) and Euphemia MacKenzie (b. 1805, d. Apr. 2, 1885 Tabusintac, NB, with death notice included). Contains detailed Highland Scottish origins and links to MacKenzie family presence in New Brunswick (Tabusintac area). Multiple genealogical sources cited. Important for understanding Scottish Highlands origins of Don's wife's family connections.
- **Note:** Genealogical research compilation with ancestral Scottish details; dated Jan. 22, 2008.

title: MacKenzie, Christina Watling
summary: Undated press clipping reporting death of Mrs. Christina MacKenzie (formerly Christina Watling of Black River), age 80, wife of late John MacKenzie of Loggieville. Twice married: first to Thomas Adams (two sons: James, Willard in Chippewa, Ontario); second to John MacKenzie (two daughters: Mrs. F. Schickle Florida, Miss Jean MacKenzie Ontario). Siblings include Mrs. John R. Godfrey Black River Bridge and Mrs. Elmer Glendenning (Don's mother). Extended Watling family record.
content_preview:
I have an undated press clipping which reads as follows:




The death of Mrs. Christina MacKenzie, wife of the late John MacKenzie, a well-known resident of Loggieville, occurred at Mount St. Joseph's Pavilion here at an early hour Friday morning.




The late Mrs MacKenzie was the former Christina Watling of Black River and was eighty years of age.  She was twice married, her first husband being Thomas Adams of Black River.




Surviving from her first marriage are two sons, James Adams and Willard Adams both of Chippewa, Ontario.

Surviving from her second marriage are two daughters, Mrs. F. Schickle, Mandarin, Florida and Miss Jean MacKenzie, Chippewa, Ontario.  Two 	sisters and three brothers also survive.  They are Mrs. John R. Godfrey, Black River Bridge, and Mrs Elmer Glendenning, Black River; James A Watling, 	Black River, George A. Watling, New Hampshire, and D. Ernest Watling, Loggieville.  




The funeral was held on Sunday afternoon from the home of Ernest Watling, Loggieville.  A short service at the house was followed by a public service 	at Knox United Church.  Interment was made in the Pine Grove Cemetery.

title: MacNaughton Connection
summary: A genealogical summary (by Don Glendenning) of the MacNaughton family roots, tracing from John MacNauchtan at Dunderave Castle, Scotland (died before 1750) through Malcolm and John to Alexander (1789–1849). Establishes that Christina MacNaughton (1822–1901), Don's great-grandmother, married Jubal Watling (1823–1900); their son Jubal (1846–1915) married Grace MacDonald (1848–1934); and lists their eight children: Christina Catherine, Elspeth Jardine, Jubal George, Janet, John McDonald, James Alexander William, Jane Elizabeth Jardine, and Donald Ernest Watling. Shows Don's Scottish heritage through maternal connection and completes the genealogical chain leading directly to him.
content_preview:
MacNaughton Connection




For the benefit of other readers, this is what I have on my MacNaughton roots.  Information about Scotland came mostly from Donald Edge.




John MacNauchtan was born at Dunderave Castle, Scotland and died (before 1750) at Glenlyon, Perthshire, Scotland.  His son, Malcolm was also born at Dunderave Castle and died at Glenlyon.




Malcolm’s son, John, was also born (July 24, 1774) at Dunderave Castle; he married Catherine Stewart and they had eight children.  John died in Scotland.  Several of John’s children and his widow came to Black River.  One son, Alexander (1789-1849) married Janet Jack; they had four daughters one of whom, Christina, (1822 - 1901) married my Great Grandfather, Jubal (1823-1900) who was the son of Jubal Watling and Susan Leach.




Jubal and Christina’ s son, Jubal (1846-1915) married Grace McAskill MacDonald (1848-1934).  Their children were Christina Catherine MacKenzie, Elspeth Jardine MacNaughton, Jubal George Watling, Janet MacDonald Godfrey, John MacDonald Watling, James Alexander William Watling, Jane Elizabeth Jardine Glendenning, and Donald Ernest Watling.

title: MacNaughton, John Ward
summary: Community obituary of John W. MacNaughton, age 86, widely known farmer, lumberman, surveyor, and timber cruiser for A and R. Loggie Company Loggieville. Active Liberal, district party chairman, county council member representing Glenelg parish 37 years, county warden, Miramichi Hospital board member. Elder of St. Stephen's United Church since 1926, chair of 1907 building committee, cemetery improvement manager. Masonic, Orange Lodge, IOOF, Highland Society member. Wife Elspeth (daughter of Grace and Jubal Watling, Don's maternal grandparents) predeceased 1943. Eight daughters, three sons, 22 grandchildren, six great-grandchildren. Submitted by Dorothy Lind December 29, 2004. Community figure connected by marriage.
content_preview:
Mourn Death of Well Known Resident 




Black River (Special) - The death of John W. MacNaughton in his 86th year removed from the Miramichi scene a widely known and highly respected farmer and lumberman who, during his lifetime, took an active interest in affairs of his community. 




For many years he worked with the A and R. Loggie Company ofLoggieville. He was a lumberman, surveyor and cruiser of timber lands. His work carried him far afield and he won many friends. Until recent years he conducted his won mill and lumber business in Black River. 




An active Liberal, he was party chairman for his district for a number of years. He was a member of the county council and represented his native parish of Glenelg for 37 years and during one period was county warden. He was also a former member of the board of Miramichi Hospital, Newcastle. 




An able supporter ofSt. Stephen's United Church, he had been an elder of the church since 1926. In 1907 he was chairman of the building committee for the present church and until recently was manager of the cemetery improvement committee. 




Mr. MacNaughton was a member ofMiramichi Lodge No. 18 F. and AM., True Blue LOL No. 90, Unity Lodge No 18 IOOF and the Highland Society ofN. B. at Miramichi. 




He served as captain in the 73rd Northumberland Regiment for a number of years prior to the First World War. 




Mr. MacNaughton was one of a family of 10 sons and three daughters of the late John and Margaret Ward MacNaughton, who lived in a hewed log dwelling on the present homestead, one of the first settled in Black River. 




His wife, Elspeth, daughter of Grace and Jubal Watling, predeceased him in 1943. 




Surviving are eight daughters and three sons, 22 grandchildren, six great grandchildren and three brothers. 




Received from Dorothy Lind

Dec 29, 2004

title: Mail
summary: Genealogical and institutional research into Little Branch Post Office history using archival databases. Provides chronological postmaster succession from 1871-1928, including: Alexander Cameron, John MacNaughton, George Fowlie, Mrs. Marjorie Fowlie, Jubal Watling, A.E. MacDonald, Elmer Glendenning (Nov 1914-Aug 1916), and Donald MacNaughton. Don verifies his belief that his parents Elmer and "Mum" ran the post office between 1914-1916, using this data point to clarify family timeline. Notes parents were in Tennessee 1911-1913, then New Haven, Conn. (daughter Lillian born Jan 8, 1917), suggesting a return to Little Branch between jobs. Also documents the separate Watling Post Office (1911-1928). Identifies Aunt Tine MacKenzie as likely running the post office at Jessie MacDonald house between first husband Tom Adams' death (1902) and second marriage to John MacKenzie (1907).
content_preview:
Little Branch Post Office




The Archives has a database, searchable through the Internet, on post offices and postmasters. In checking the Little Branch Post Office, I found the following:

Postmaster		Dates				Cause of vacancy

Alexander Cameron	1871-11-01   to 1876-03-30	Resignation

John MacNaughton	1876-08-01 to 1883-08-20	Resignation, closed

Alexander Cameron	1884-11-01  to 1887-03-22	Resignation

           (Re-opened)

George Fowlie		1887-09-01 to 1899-10-02	Death

Mrs. Marjorie Fowlie	1900-02-01 to 1903-09	Change in site

Jubal Watling		1903-12-01 to 1910-12-02	Resignation

A.E. MacDonald	1911-03-01  to 1914-08-10	Resignation

Elmer Glendenning	1914-11-01  to 1916-08-01	Resignation

Donald MacNaughton	1916-09-01 to 1928-10-31	Closed




Although Jubal Watling was the Postmaster, I believe that Aunt Tine MacKenzie ran the Post Office in the Jessie MacDonald house. (Where Norman Glendenning now lives).  This would be, as I understand it, between 1902 when her first husband, Tom Adams, died and 1907 when she married John MacKenzie 




I always thought that Dad and Mum ran the Post Office but didn=t have any proof.  The above information confirms my understanding.  The dates are interesting because we know that Mum and Dad were in Tennessee prior to this (1911 to 1912 or more likely until 1913) The next dates we have are New Haven, Conn. in 1917 where Lillian was born on January 8.  It looks as though they may have returned to Little Branch between jobs.  







Watling Post Office




There was Post Office named Watling which opened in 1911 and closed in 1928.  The Postmasters were Donald Watling, A. H. McKay and A. D. Watling

title: Marson, Margaret Glendenning
summary: Boothbay Register obituary from December 27, 1956 of Mrs. Margaret Glendenning Marsen, age 63, wife of Lucas Marsen of Boothbay Harbour and Wauchula, Florida. Born Canobie, New Brunswick; graduate of Sisters' Hospital Lewiston as registered nurse. Served overseas in WWI with Harvard Unit and re-enlisted with Canadian Medical Unit. District health worker in Portland for years. Survived by husband Lucas and brother Guy Glendenning of Bowling Green, Florida, plus numerous nephews/nieces. Body entombed at Ocean View Cemetery pending spring services. Extended family.
content_preview:
The Boothbay Register carried the following on December 27, 1956

 

Mrs. Lucas Marsen

 

Mrs. Margaret Glendenning Marsen, 63, wife of Lucas Marsen, Oven's Mouth, Boothbay Harbour and Wauchula, Fla. Died at Memorial Hospital, Lakeland, Fla., Wednesday, December 19, following surgical treatment.

Mrs. Marsen, a graduate of Sisters' Hospital, Lewiston, as a registered nurse, was born in Canobie, New Brunswick.  She went overseas in World War I with the Harvard Unit and re enlisted on her return with the Canadian Medical Unit.   For a number of years she served as district health worker in Portland.

 

She is survived by her husband, Lucas, of Florida and a brother Guy Glendenning of Bowling Green, Fla., also numerous nephews and nieces.

 

The body was returned here and entombed at Ocean View Cemetery to await services and burial in the spring.

title: Mary - postmaster's desk
summary: Don writes to Mary about an antique postmaster's desk from Hexham, New Brunswick with family/community connections. He traces the desk's history through Bob and Ira MacDougall and suggests it be preserved as local history, offering to help contact the NB Archives. This anecdote reveals Don's attention to family and community heritage.
content_preview:
April11, 2009
















Happy Easter




Great to talk with you the other night and to know that you are on the mend.  It won’t be long now until you’ll be thinking of opening your cottage although the snow in the forecast is not very spring-like.




I’ve been intending to mention the old postmasters desk in your garage but forgot each time I visited so decided to send this note.  Since I am mailing this to your Black River address, I will also send a copy to Jeannie in case you are still in Moncton.




One time I was with John when he stopped at Ira MacDougall’s place in Loggieville to purchase something.  Did Ira sell farm equipment of supplies?  While looking around waiting for John, I spotted an old desk in the shed.   When I asked Ira about it, it turned out to be, as I recall, the old postmaster’s desk used in Hexham by Bob and Bioney – and maybe others before them. (Bob and Ira were brothers, I think) 




As we drove home, we talked about it and the fact that it was a genuine antique.  I was not particularly interested in it myself but thought it should be saved.  On a return visit John got the desk from Ira, I am not sure if he paid for it or Ira simply gave it to him.




The last time I saw the desk, it was along the side of the garage next the road and was used for storing nuts and bolts.




I thought that I should let you know, Mary, so that it can be kept.  While it does not have a family connection, it is part of our Black River history.  I am sure that the NB Archives would be interested if your family isn’t.  I searched the internet, and am enclosing what I found about Hexham post offices.




Just thought that you should know




Regards to all the family

title: McKenzie Settlement
summary: Brief genealogical note on the naming and land settlement of McKenzie Settlement. Don speculates that the settlement was named after John and Roderick MacKenzie, who received land grants in 1871 and 1873 respectively. Questions whether Roderick was the Roderick MacKenzie who married his great-grandfather's sister Annabelle MacDonald. Notes John K. MacKenzie received lot #163 (100 acres) in 1907, possibly the "Aunt Tine's second husband" mentioned elsewhere. Records that Mary Anderson received 300 acres at the Little Branch end of the McKenzie Road in 1909.
content_preview: McKenzie Settlement was likely named after John and Roderick MacKenzie who were each granted 100 acres there in 1871 and 1873.  (Could this have been the Roderick MacKenzie who married my Great Grandfather=s sister, Annabelle MacDonald?  John K. MacKenzie gas granted lot #163 (100 acres) in 1907.  Would this have been Aunt Tine= second husband?  In 1909 Mary Anderson was granted 300 acres of land at the Little Branch end of the McKenzie Road

title: Meadows to Little Branch
summary: A historical narrative of Don's grandparents' transition from the Meadows to Little Branch. Documents the November 13, 1901 agreement wherein Jubal and Grace Watling (with their four sons George, John, James, and Ernest as parties) took possession of John MacDonald's property at Little Branch, assuming lifelong support obligations for Elspeth (Jardine) MacDonald and her son James. Notes Elspeth's death on September 12, 1907, and James's death on April 1, 1923. Clarifies that the agreement did not include the Jessie McDonald property where Norman Glendenning later lived. Shows the family's legal and caregiving relationships within the community.
content_preview:
Meadows to Little Branch




Our Grandfather, Jubal Watling, lived at the Meadows; he married Grace MacDonald who lived at Little Branch – where Neil Watling now lives.  Grandmother’s father, John, died in 1900, I think, and her mother, Elspeth, was not well.  In addition, James, Grandmother’s brother had inherited the farm when his father died, was not married, was living at home but was not able to operate the farm.  As best I can interpret, the land did not include the Jessie McDonald property where Norman Glendenning now lives.




On November 13, 1901, James entered into an agreement with his sister, Grace and her husband, Jubal.  As parties to the agreement also were Jubal and Grace’s four sons, George, John, James and Ernest.  A copy of this agreement can be found in the Northumberland County Registrar’s office.  




All the land and buildings are to be turned over to the Watlings.  In return, the Watlings will “keep support, maintain and provide the said James J. McDonald and his mother, Mrs. John D. McDonald, each of them and the survivor of them during the respective terms of their natural lives with good and sufficient house, room, meat, drink, washing, clothing, bedding, fire, light, medicine, medical attendance, personal expenses and all such necessaries as persons of their ages and conditions in life usually require and are accustomed to.”  The Watlings were also to provide a “decent Christian burial” paying all funeral expenses.




Elspeth (Jardine) MacDonald died September 12, 1907 and James died April 1, 1923.

title: Meadows
summary: Genealogical and land settlement documentation of "The Meadows" area (mother's birthplace, though post office was Black River). Provides detailed land grant records starting from Route 11 on the south side of river moving west (1833-1883), including grants to Terrence Cook, Patrick Smith, Richard Hutchison, Gardiner Archibald, Jubal Watling Jr., Donald Cameron, and Donald McBeath. Lists north-side properties granted to J. Edge (1842) and multiple McNaughtons (Alexander, John, Malcolm with 200+ acres each, granted 1822-1828). Notes conflicting information about Don's own lot (#4 on Meadow Brook). Concludes with observations that land grants were made later and more gradually at Meadows than at Little Branch, and that poorer south-side land presumably explains the settlement's eventual disappearance.

title: Memory
summary: Humorous story about two elderly people (widower and widow) meeting at a community supper in a Florida mobile home park. After the widower proposes and the widow says yes, he cannot remember her response the next morning and must call to confirm. She had also forgotten who asked her. A charming tale celebrating memory loss, romance, and humor in later years. Found in Family Tree Maker folder (possibly misfiled), suggesting this sentimental story may have resonated personally with Don during his own later years. Likely represents either creative writing or a favorite story Don wanted to preserve.
content_preview:
This is a story of two elderly people living in a mobile home park  

in Florida.  He was a widower and she was a widow.  They had known  

one another for a number of years.



One evening there was a community supper in the Club House, and the  

widower and widow made a foursome with two other singles.



They had a wonderful evening and spirits were high.  The widower  

sent a few admiring glances across the table, and the widow smiled  

coyly back at him.



Finally, he plucked up his courage to ask her,  " Will you marry me? "



After about six seconds of careful consideration, she answered,  

"Yes. Yes, I will. "



The meal ended with a few more pleasant exchanges and they went to  

their respective homes.



The next morning, the widower was troubled.



Did she say 'Yes' or did she say 'No'? He couldn't remember. Try as  

he would, he just could not recall.



He went over the conversation of the previous evening, but his mind  

was blank.  He remembered asking the question, but for the life of  

him he could not recall her response.



With fear and trepidation, ! he picked up the phone and called her.



First, he explained that he didn't remember as well as he used to.   

Then he reviewed the lovely evening past.



As he gained a little more courage he then inquired of her,  " When  

I asked if you would marry me, did you say 'Yes' or did you say 'No'?"



"Why, you silly man, I said 'Yes.  Yes I will.'  And I meant it with  

all my heart. "



The widower was delighted. He felt his heart skip a beat.



Then she continued,  " And I am so glad you called because I  

couldn't remember who asked me.

title: Mills-1
summary: Letter from Art (family correspondent) to Don about Miramichi Regional High School history, early bus services, babbit bearing manufacture by cousin Alexander Mills, and MRHS athletic patches from 1949-1950. Reflects Don's role as family historian receiving genealogical contributions.
content_preview:
Hi Don;

You have had  a busy winter,111,112 and 113 very interesting,especially info,re Miramichi Regional High Busses etc.Sister Marg attended in those early days .She boarded one winter in Bayside then moved to Chatham,and lived with Uncle Douglas McLeod for the remainder .I was amazed to read The Godfrey busses only began in 1944,this was certainly a great service to the Comunities of Miramichi Bay.

BABBET-now  here is something I know about in spite of my non-mechanical mind .My Dear Father did explain the bacics of the small gas motors to me and a few things sank in.The small marine motor(Atlantic by name) 10 HP two cylinder which was the Power in THE M.H.L.(my dads old boat).This old motor had 4 of these bearings.The pouring of these bearings was a very delicate exercise,and required the expert hands of Cousin  Alexander Mills (Son of Andrew of BayDuVin beach,)These bearings were made of Babbet.The bearinga were poured then filed to smoth the surface ,it took days.Even Enid the old farmer had not herd of Babbet.

By the way among my treasures I found some MRHS patches for the Hockey team1950-Softball team 1949,this would be in Raymond Legers years.

Thanks for the memories,best wishes to you and Carol

Art

title: Nancy Harter-2020
summary: A warm family letter from Don to his niece Nancy Harter, recounting family news, Carol's recent health challenges (pneumonia), updates on their children and grandchildren, and reflecting on shared memories. The letter shows Don's family bonds and concern for younger generations, including his first great-grandchild Astrid.
content_preview:
October 11, 2020




Dear Nancy:




Thanks for your newsy note.

Great to hear from you

Thought of sending an Email but not sure that I have your correct address – (katybug1997@att.net - ?)  Let me know if this is correct, please let me know and we’ll keep in touch via Email.  Mine is more complicated – dglend@pei.sympatico.ca




We are doing ok; Carol was had pneumonia with complications last summer; almost did not make it. Is home now; can look after herself but tires easily and rests a lot.  She is on air, not oxygen, at night. Able to be out but needs a steadying hand. We were able to spend time at the cottage this summer. Have any great memories of your Mum and dad, in fact of the family and remember  your visits both to New Brunswick and Christmas in Ottawa. A lot of water over the dam or under the bridge since then




Our offspring  are well; Janet lives in Ottawa; we talk with her every Sunday.  Brian lives in New Mexico.  Granddaughter Laura lives in Maryland; Granddaughter Lisa is married and lives in Seattle.  Our big news is our first Great granddaughter Astrid born, I think, on April 28.  In fact, Brian and Marie are visiting Lisa in Seattle these days.




Hard to believe that your Mum and Dad are gone and at a relatively young age.  Yes, I remember Howard;  Carol  and I visited Howard once in that beautiful Senior’s home.  Carol and I had dinner with you and Dennis in Peoria; thought that you were living somewhere near Henry.




Your Dad was a man of faith, I remember how important his church was in his life and his daily practice.  Thanks for the book by CS Lewis; I look forward to spending time with him this winter.

Also glad to hear about your children and family.

 

I have quite a bit of information about Carol’s side of the family.  If interested, I would be glad to share.  I did send a copy to the Henry Library a number of years ago. 




Nancy, you’ll never know how much I appreciate your letter. Thank you

All the best to you and your f...

title: New Watling Information
summary: Don's genealogical research on the Watling family, comparing census data with family records. Discusses Jubal Watling (husband of Susan Leach) from the 1841 PEI census and variations in available information, particularly noting the difference between two different Jubals and determining that Susan may have died and Jubal remarried to Louisa. The analysis compares Jubal's age, occupation (mason), and landholdings to piece together family history. Written by Don as genealogical research notes.
content_preview:
New Watling Information




Janet Watling shows Jubal and Susan with two additional children – John and Susannah.  Any further information? Dates?




Prince Edward Island Archives show a Jubal Watling living in Lot No. 52 at the time of the 1841 census.  Lot 52 is at the Eastern end of PEI near but not including Montague and Cardigan.




According to the 1841 census, Jubal Watling was between 45 and 60 years of age, head of the family, his trade or occupation was that of a mason, he had 100 acres of land but one cannot tell if he rented or owned the land.  The household consisted of Jubal as head, one female between the ages of 45 and 60 presumably his wife, and 4 males under the age of 16.  Four members of the household were born in England and two were natives of the Island.




Other information in the PEI archives shows Jubal Watling married Louisa on 14 July 1831 and that they came from Norfolk County, England.




An examination of the two sets of data shows that:




One Jubal came from Norfolk and the other came from Suffolk.

The PEI Jubal has a different spouse; Susan Leach may have died and Jubal remarried.

The age brackets fit Jubal and Susan.

While my notes show only Jubal and Emily actually born in England, it is likely that the older children would have been born there also.   

Why would the girls not have been

title: Notes2
summary: Don's genealogical research documenting postmasters of Little Branch Post Office (1871-1928), including his ancestors Elmer Glendenning (1914-1916) and Jubal Watling (1903-1910). Don notes that his parents Elmer and Jeannie likely ran the post office but had relocated to Tennessee (1911-1912) and then Connecticut before returning briefly to New Brunswick. Includes records of the separate Watling Post Office (1911-1928) with its postmasters.
content_preview:
Little Branch Post Office




The Archives has a database, searchable through the Internet, on post offices and postmasters. In checking the Little Branch Post Office, I found the following:

Postmaster		Dates				Cause of vacancy

Alexander Cameron	1871-11-01   to 1876-03-30	Resignation

John MacNaughton	1876-08-01 to 1883-08-20	Resignation, closed

Alexander Cameron	1884-11-01  to 1887-03-22	Resignation

           (Re-opened)

George Fowlie		1887-09-01 to 1899-10-02	Death

Mrs. Marjorie Fowlie	1900-02-01 to 1903-09	Change in site

Jubal Watling		1903-12-01 to 1910-12-02	Resignation

A.E. MacDonald	1911-03-01  to 1914-08-10	Resignation

Elmer Glendenning	1914-11-01  to 1916-08-01	Resignation

Donald MacNaughton	1916-09-01 to 1928-10-31	Closed




Although Jubal Watling was the Postmaster, I believe that Aunt Tine MacKenzie ran the Post Office in the Jessie MacDonald house. (Where Norman Glendenning now lives).  This would be, as I understand it, between 1902 when her first husband, Tom Adams, died and 1907 when she married John MacKenzie 




I always thought that Dad and Mum ran the Post Office but didn=t have any proof.  The above information confirms my understanding.  The dates are interesting because we know that Mum and Dad were in Tennessee prior to this (1911 to 1912 or more likely until 1913) The next dates we have are New Haven, Conn. in 1917 where Lillian was born on January 8.  It looks as though they may have returned to Little Branch between jobs.  







Watling Post Office




There was Post Office named Watling which opened in 1911 and closed in 1928.  The Postmasters were Donald Watling, A. H. McKay and A. D. Watling
