title: Publications 2015@2015-09-29T13;03;27
summary: A catalog of Don's genealogical and historical publications including Glendenning Roots, Family Chronicles volumes, The Neighbourhood, and Presbyterians in Black River. These extensively documented works (totaling approximately 800+ pages) represent Don's lifelong commitment to preserving family history and the cultural heritage of Black River, New Brunswick, his ancestral home.
content_preview:
PUBLICATIONS




BLACK RIVER HISTORY AND GENEALOGY 










Publications:




1	Glendenning Roots - Background and photos on the life and times of Elmer and Jane (Watling) Glendenning with a focus on their years in the USA.  It also lists ancestors for each as well as their descendants.  (Approximately 200 pages bound.)




Carol Louise (Chesney) Glendenning - Background information and photos of Carol Chesney, her family and friends in Illinois.  (Approximately 100 pp bound)




Family Chronicles; Volumes 1 and 2 – Copies of an informal newsletter intended to share with siblings the latest findings about relatives and ancestors.  Later Chronicles morphed into recollections of life and times of the author growing up in Black River, New Brunswick, especially in the period preceding WW2.  Each newsletter was two pages; each volume includes 100 newsletters.  Newsletters are also available on line at   HYPERLINK "http://www.glendenning.net/don" www.glendenning.net/don.  (Approximately 200 pp each volume, bound)  




The Neighbourhood - At the beginning of WW2, there were about 120 households along the Black River in Northumberland County, New Brunswick.  This volume identifies heads of households and their offspring; children are identified even though many had married and left home.  The volume also provides ancestor charts, where known, for many of the heads of households.  (Approximately 325 pages bound)




Presbyterians in Black River – starting with the early church history from the book, Black River and Its Early Settlers by A. W. MacDougall, (used with permission of the family), this book describes the worship of Presbyterians after Church Union in 1925.  (Approximately 60 pages bound)




Other – I have nearly 6,000 names in my database.  Although not adding new information at the moment, I would be pleased to share whatever other information especially about Black River or Canobie families that interests you.

























Don Glendenning

title: Re_ The Island Register - Adams File-2
summary: Email correspondence (August 11, 2006) between Jane Adams and Don Glendenning discussing WWI military service of William Adams. Personally written by Jane. Analyzes census and obituary data to identify which William Adams served in WWI, narrowing down possibilities between two candidates born 1877 and 1896. Includes Annie Pardon Adams's obituary noting her meeting husband William during WWI and service in British Red Cross. Shows Don's detailed genealogical research methods and family network documentation work.
content_preview:
From: "Jane Adams" <wadams@golden.net>
To: "Don Glendenning" <dglende@auracom.com>
Subject: Re: The Island Register - Adams File
Date: August 11, 2006 12:38 AM

I don't have any information to confirm whether the William Adams b. August 1877 had served in WWI.  However, my husband's grandfather was a William Adams b. Jan 1896 - I believe he served in WWI as he met his wife during this war when he was in England (wife's obituary below).  Given that WWI was circa 1914 - 1919, this would make the William Adams b. 1877 about 40 years old whereas William Adams b. 1896 would have been in his early 20's - a more likely age for military service.  Both these William Adams are from New Brunswick, however, my husband's grandfather moved west to Saskatchewan (Moose Jaw).  

Let me know what you think....I would love a copy of the photo if possible (do you have it in digital format / pdf ?)

Kind regards,
Jane (Anning) Adams

>From Annie Pardon's Obituary:

Born at Mundseley-on-the-Sea, England, she met her husband William A. Adams during World War 1.  They came to Canada in 1921.  Annie was presented an award in recognition of her valuable services rendered during the War 1914-1919 for her involvement in the British Red Cross Society.  Her involvement continued in Canada as the church group knitted sweaters and socks, etc. for soldiers who needed a home away from home.  She was an active member of St. Andrew's United Church.  During her years of good health, she looked forward to their annual vacations to the East and West coasts.  She enjoyed the outdoors especially her yard and garden.  Predeceased by her husband William in 1977; a daughter Bessie in 1966, and two sisters, Lottie and Alice; she will be sadly missed by two daughters; Joyce (Ferdy) Gaudette of Montreal; Kay (Alfred) Iverson of Surrey, B.C., one son, Fred (Betty) of Moose Jaw and a special granddaughter, Judy Maisonneuve of Moose Jaw, and twelve other grandchildren and several great-grandchildren.

title: Roots
summary: Comprehensive genealogical work by Don on the Watling surname origins, tracing it to Sussex, England and linking it to the Roman Watling Street. Documents the Watling coat of arms, discusses notable historical Watlings including Thomas Watling (an 1792 landscape painter in Australia) and pirate Captain George Watling. Traces Don's direct ancestor Jubal Watling (married Susan Leach in 1814 in Suffolk) and explores family origins in Norfolk/Suffolk, England. Essential genealogical reference authored by Don showing his meticulous historical research and family pride.
content_preview:
WATLING ROOTS




Origin of Name




The first record of the name was found in Sussex, England somewhere between London and Dover.  It is likely that the name arises from Wartling which was a hamlet in the area but others believe that it was associated with Watling Road, the great Roman Road, which started near Dover, passed through Canterbury, turned north at London and went as far as St Albans     It is thought, furthermore, that the Watlings were Vikings who landed in Northern Scotland in 870 AD, invaded northern France in 910 AD and then came to England with William the Conqueror in 1066.  The name is found in the Domesday Book which was a census taken in England in 1086.




By the time of Richard 1 the Watling name had spread north to Watlingford in Oxfordshire, Watlington in Norfolk, Essex and Hertfordshire.  Many Norman families moved north to Scotland in the 12th century and this might have included some Watlings.




Watling is thought to share the same roots as Whatling, Watlington, Watlingtone, Whatlington, Whatlingtone, Wadling, and Wadlingdon.  Over time, the name spread into the northern parts of England and to Scotland as well.




Kinsmen of the family Watling who came to North America include Ffrances Watling who settled in Virginia in 1660, John Watling who landed in America in 1753, James Watling settled in Philadelphia in 1842 and Mary Watlington who settled in Antigua in 1679.  Some Watlings moved to Canada after the American Revolution.

.

The Roger Watling Website includes the following comkments about the origin of the Watlings:




“In the 5th/6th century a band of people crossed the North Sea from Europe to the British Isles, we do not know if it was one or more boats, but as a yachtsman sailing these waters I would suppose the latter, there being safety in numbers.  They knew where they were going as trading was and had taken place long before, also they would have had oral stories from their forebearers who might have served in the Roma...

title: Russell, Cameron
summary: Moncton Times clipping reporting death of D. Cameron Russell, age 72, of Point au Carr, Northumberland County, died on arrival at Hotel Dieu Hospital Chatham. Born Point au Carr, son of Ernest and Burgess Cameron Russell; worked as farmer, fisherman, carpenter. Member St. Paul's Presbyterian Church Black River (elder, active in church activities). Miramichi Highland Society member. Wife was former Venetia G. (Don's sister). Survived by wife, one daughter (Donna), two sons (Leonard PEI, Glenn Newcastle), two sisters, one brother, and four grandchildren. Important family connection.
content_preview:
A clipping, believed to come from the Moncton times reports:

"D.C. Russell		POINT AU CARR (Special) - The death of D. Cameron Russell of Point au Carr, Northumberland County, occurred on arrival Wednesday at Hotel Dieu Hospital, Chatham.  He was 72.

Born at Point au Carr, he was a son of the late Ernest and Burgess (Cameron) Russell, and was a farmer, fisherman and carpenter.

He was a member of St. Paul's Presbyterian church, Black river, and an elder of the church.  He took an active part in all church activities throughout his life.

He was a member of the Miramichi Highland Society.

He is survived by his wife, the former Venetia G; a daughter, Mrs. Vernon Goodfellow, (Donna) of South Esk; two sons, Leonard of St. Eleanors, PEI., and Glenn Russell of Newcastle; two sisters, Mrs. Gordon MacDiarmid (Betty) of Centre Napan and Mrs. Hugh Berry (Aldine) of Averill Park, N.Y.; ,a brother, Howard Russell of Point au Carr, and by four grandchildren.

The body is resting at his home at Point au Carr.

Services will be held at 3:30 p.m. Saturday at St. Paul's Presbyterian Church, Black River, with interment in the church cemetery."

title: School Cameron School
summary: Don documents the Cameron School at Middle Black River, built around 1845 when the original school district was divided. The school was named after the many Cameron families in the immediate area. By 1939, it became one of seven schools in the newly-created Miramichi Rural High School district, continuing to offer grades 1-6 while the high school provided grades 7-11. This reflects the educational consolidation Don witnessed in the late 1930s.
content_preview:
Cameron
School














Cameron
School courtesy of Elby and Shirley Donnelly











About
1845, the district was divided with one school being build at Middle
Black River and another at Bayside (now Miramichi).  The school at
Middle Black River, the Cameron School, was so named because of all
of the Camerons found in the community.






In
1939, the Cameron School became one of seven schools in the
newly-created Miramichi Rural High School district in 1939.  When the
MRHS opened, grades one to six continued at the local school; the new
high school offered instruction in Grades seven through eleven.

title: School Victoria School
summary: Don traces Victoria School's history from early Black River instruction in Archibald Cameron Sr.'s barn, followed by home-based teaching. A formal school was erected in 1825 near the lane now leading to St. Stephen's Church. Around 1845, the district divided with Cameron School at Middle Black River and another at Bayside. Victoria School's construction date is unknown. The original Victoria School burned in the late 1940s and was replaced; the latter building later served as Mrs. Louise MacDougall's residence. In 1939, Victoria School became one of seven schools in the Miramichi Rural High School district, offering grades 1-6. This documents educational infrastructure evolution across more than a century.
content_preview:
Victoria School









    
Photo
courtesy of Richard MacDougall






Most
of the early settlers in Black River spoke Gaelic.  Based on the work
of A. W. McDougall, Black
River and its First Settlers,
the first instruction in Black River was provided in a barn belonging
to Archibald Cameron, Sr.  Following this, teachers provided
instruction in their own homes.  In 1825, residents petitioned
successfully for a school which, as I understand it, was erected near
the lane now leading to St. Stephen's Church.   This school appears
to have served all of Black River and as far east as Bay du Vin
although I do not know if students from the north side of the river
were included  







About
1845, the district was divided with one, the Cameron School, being
built at Middle Black River and another at Bayside (now Miramichi). 
A few years later a school was erected at Little Branch; I do not
know when the first Victoria school was erected. 







The
Victoria School, date of construction unknown, became one of seven
schools in the newly created Miramichi Rural High School district in
1939.  When the MRHS opened, grades one to six continued at the each
of the small schools; the new high school offered instruction in
Grades seven through eleven.  The original Victoria School burned,
probably in the late 1940’s, but was soon replaced.  The latter
school serves as the residence of Mrs. Louise MacDougall

title: Shuttle Grandma's
summary: An expanded, more detailed version of the shuttle narrative (FILE 13), dated March 14, 2016, providing deeper historical context. Includes information about William Harley in Courtmacsherry, County Cork, Ireland, and the family's 1820s migration. Describes the weaving trade in pioneer Canobie, where John Glendinning operated one of the first looms. Provides technical description of the shuttle (12 x 1 1/8 x 7/8 inches, walnut wood, with tapered pirn). Traces object's path through Venetia (in Maine/Florida) to Cornelia to Don. Deeper genealogical and material culture documentation than FILE 13.
content_preview:
Grandma’s
Shuttle
















Shuttle:
The vehicle used to traverse the weft from selvedge to selvedge –
S. C. Lutton







Today,
March 14, 2016, my first cousin, Cornelia (Glendenning) Traetta
presented me with a shuttle that belonged to our Great Grandmother,
Margaret (Harley) Glendinning; this is my understanding of the story.






My
Great Great Grandfather, William Harley was born in Worcester,
England but moved to Courtmacsherry, County Cork, Ireland, before the
turn of the century where William was believed to have been a school
master.  All five children (2 boys and 3 girls) came to New Brunswick
in the 1820’s; one daughter, Margaret (1803-1895), married John
Glendinning in 1833 settling first at Salmon Beach and later in
Canobie.  (The change from Glendinning to Glendenning came, I
believe, with the granting of lots to John and Walter Glendenning
about 1856).   Pioneer Settlers,
a history of Canobie, tells us that early settlers had sheep,  spun
their own wool and wove cloth; it also tells us that John Glendinning
had one of the first “weaving machines” (looms) in Canobie and
the Glendinnings taught many in  the community to weave. 







Weaving
involves the use of a loom to interlace threads at right angles to
each other.  The threads running the length of the cloth form the
warp; the threads running across the warp are known as the weft.  The
weft thread is carried back and forth across the warp by a shuttle
holding a bobbin or on a small rod called a pirn.  Grandma’s
shuttle measures 12 x 11/8 x7/8, in excellent condition and is made
of a dark wood believed to be walnut. It has a tapered, “threaded”
pirn, and a hole through one side for the thread to unravel.







The shuttle was brought to Canada from Ireland
by my Great Grandmother, Margaret (Harley) Glendenning in the
1820’s.; it may have been given as a gift or may even have been
given to the youngest daughter on leaving the family nest as a family
heirloom.  The shuttle passed to Margaret...

title: St. Paul's
summary: History of St. Paul's Presbyterian Church in Black River Bridge, opened July 21, 1930, after 1925 Church Union. Succeeds earlier St. Stephen's Presbyterian (1836). Documents Don's local religious heritage.
content_preview:
St. Paul’s Presbyterian Church













































Prior
to 1836, residents of Black River traveled to Bay du Vin to attend
church which, although nominally Presbyterian, was used by other
denominations as well.  In 1836 a new church, St Stephen’s
Presbyterian, was opened in Black River and was situated within the
bounds of what is now the Black River/St Stephen’s cemetery.  The
original church building was replaced in 1906.






Following
Church Union in 1925, St. Stephens Presbyterian Church became St.
Stephens United Church and continuing Presbyterians built a new
Presbyterian Church, St. Paul’s, shown in the photo above.  St.
Paul’s Presbyterian Church was opened on July 21, 1930.  In 1939,
the church was served by a student minister, Rev. David C. MacLelland
who boarded in the community.

title: St Pauls Annivrsary
summary: Don's personal recollection dated July 5, 2025, reflecting on his life at St. Paul's Presbyterian Church in Black River Bridge, New Brunswick. He participated in the church's official opening on July 20, 1930 (one year after his birth September 8, 1929). Details family's central role: father's involvement in construction, mother as active member, siblings' contributions, and his own marriage ceremony at the church. Describes the church's welcoming atmosphere, shared ministers serving multiple communities, and formative youth experiences including Bible school, vacation school, and church camps. Mentions key family members Aunt Kate and Uncle Jim Watling. Reflects warmly on Black River as a good community to grow up in.
content_preview:
Memories of 

St. Paul’s Presbyterian Church

Black River Bridge, NB

July 05, 2025

On this anniversary occasion, I am pleased to provide a few recollections about my life and times in St. Paul’s Presbyterian Church in Black River Bridge, New Brunswick. Although I actually participated in the official opening on July 20, 1930, my memories of the event are a bit hazy.  I understand,furthermore, that older siblings were actually at a church event when I arrived at Little Branch on a Sunday evening a  year earlier.

St. Paul’s played a significant role in our family. My father was involved in its construction; my Mother was an active member, siblings played a variety of roles, nephews and nieces continued the tradition; and is the church whre I was married. . I might also add that many summer Ministers boarded at our home and shared meals and events with our family; their presence was one of my connections to the world beyond Black River.

S Pauls had a tradition o sharing ministers. Sunday services were held at on Sunday orn, afternoon or evening which allow the Miniser to serve Chatham, Sunny Corner and Kouchibouguac as well.  

My church experiences were positive; St. Paul’s was a welcoming church. Sunday services were always warm and friendly (most members were related); there was a positive but muted conversation before the service got under way. men gathered outside for conversation (and perhaps another smoke) prior to the commencement of the service; 

I recall sunny Sundays travelling to and from church with Mother and my siblings in the large “express wagon”; wagon travel was leisurely and allowed for conversation about the just completed service as well as family and community news of the day.  With the arrival of a 1939 half ton Ford truck in 1942, rothers Normand and John  provided transportation to other church members as well. 

Services were simple, clear and timely. Music by choir and congregation were always highlights of any service and who could for...

title: Taylor, Earl
summary: Newspaper obituary for Earl Taylor (age 53, died by accident at Black River), husband of Elinor Glendenning. Third-party document. Important family document: Earl was David Taylor's father and married into the Glendenning family. Lists multiple children including daughter Sandra (Mrs. Eugene Shea) and details of extended family connections in the Miramichi area.
content_preview:
A clipping, believed to be from the Moncton times, reports the following:




Funeral For Victim of Road Mishap

BLACK RIVER (Special) - The funeral of a black river man who died in hospital Tuesday of injuries received when hit by a car, will be held today at 2:30 p.m. from St. Pau's Presbyterian Church here.

Earl Taylor, 53, was struck by a car in front of his home just after he steeped from a friend's vehicle, Newcastle RCMO said.  The mishap occurred at 6:15 pm. and Mr. Taylor died in Miramichi Hospital, Newcastle, three hours later.

Driver of the vehicle that struck Mr. Taylor was Willard MacDougall, also of Black river. Coroner Dr. J. P. Losier has ordered an autopsy and inquest unnecessary.  Black River is about 8 miles east of Chatham.

Born at Napan Bay, Mr. Taylor was a son of the late Ernest and Roberta (McInnis) Taylor.  He was a tradesman's helper at CFB St. Magaret's.  He was a second World War veteran and attended St. Paul's Presbyterian Church.

He is survived by his wife, the former Elinor Glendenning; two daughters, gene Shea (Sandra) of Ferry Road and Mrs. Benson Harris (Ginny) of Simcoe, Ontario; five sons, Gerald of Beechwood, Robert Toronto, David of Moncton, Frank and Kenneth at home; six sisters, Mrs. Harold Ryan of Fredericton, Mrs. Harvey Williston of Chatham, Mrs. John Williston of Bay du vin, Mrs. George MacDonald of Black River, Mrs. Edward Roach and Mrs Wilfred Turbide, both of Seven Islands; six brothers, Ronald of Redbank, Linwood of Chatham, Bud and Leo, both of Seven Islands, Alvin of Napan Bay, and Melvin of Lincoln, and seven grandchildren.

The Body is resting at his hoe where prayers will be said at 11:00 am today.  The body will be taken to St. Paul's Presbyterian Church where the funeral will be held at 2:30 pm today.  Interment will be in the Black river cemetery.

title: Telephone
summary: Describes telephone service in Black River during Don's childhood, contrasting the New Brunswick Telephone Company serving Black River with the 'Government line' serving areas down river to Escuminac. Details party line communication (exchange 1900, ring 4), battery-powered phones, and community dynamics of shared phone service. Recounts anecdotes including neighbors using their phone for emergencies, people eavesdropping for news, and a notable story of a neighbor who tied the receiver to her rocking chair. Reflects early 20th-century rural communication infrastructure.
content_preview:
Telephone Service




Black River was served primarily by the New Brunswick Telephone Company; on the other side of the Little Branch River and all the way to Escuminac, phone service was provided by the “Government line”.  




The Government Line always seemed to be out of order.  That meant that people from down river frequently came to our house to use the phone; that also meant that emergency phone calls often came to our place with a request that they be delivered.  I cannot ever remember delivery being refused.  In fact, I remember delivering a phone message to someone up Bay du Vin River over very wet, muddy and rutted spring roads.




Ours was a party line; our number was 1900-4 – nineteen hundred ring four.  Nineteen hundred was the exchange; 4 was the ring.  When the phone rang four short rings, we knew to pick it up.  Double-digit numbers were rung by dialing long and short rings.  Number twenty-four, for example, would be two long rings and four short rings.




The phone itself was a box about 10 inches wide, 20 inches high and six inches deep.  The receiver hung on a y-hook; you lifted the receiver off the hook and held it to your ear.  The phone was battery powered – two C batteries as I recall. Once or twice a year, telephone maintenance men changed the batteries.




When the phone rang, it was possible to pick up the phone and listen to both sides of the conversation.  This was a great way to catch up on the news and prevented secrets in the community.  In case of an emergency, such as a fire, a continuous ring would be heard to alert the neighbours.




The story is told of a neighbour who tied the receiver to her rocking chair each time she sat down to rest.  The Telephone Company threatened to disconnect a phone if someone listened in on a conversation although I never heard of that happening except in the above instance.

title: Together in USA
summary: Comprehensive historical narrative of Glendenning and Watling families' migration to USA and establishment in Tennessee during 1910-1913. Opens with post-WW2 context of Maritimer emigration patterns (woods work in Maine/New Hampshire initially, then year-round settlement). Describes Portland's historical significance as Atlantic & St. Lawrence Railroad terminus ("Canada's winter port"), industrial development (locomotives, docks, construction jobs), 1866 fire (1500 buildings destroyed, 12,000 homeless), Promenade grand homes. Chronicles Glendenning family's Portland settlement with siblings' roles and occupations. Extensively documents Elmer and Frank's cartage business (Glendenning Bros. & Co., 24 Hammond Street, ice delivery, general team work). Details Elmer's work progression in woods (Maine/New Hampshire near Skowhegan, Millinocket, Berlin; lumbering with horses; record lumber cut). Parallels with Jane Watling's Portland arrival (January 24, 1908, City Hall fire day), employment as nanny/housekeeper with Jennison family. Covers marriage ceremony (October 18, 1910 at Little Branch home of parents by Rev. George Grant), honeymoon in Montreal, residence in Bonny Eagle, Maine. Describes Jane's household journal/purchase record (January 1911 entries documenting domestic economy). Extensive section on Parksville, Tennessee: geographic/historic context (Polk County, Ocoee River, southeast of Chattanooga); technical details on dam construction (Ocoee No. 1 and No. 2 developments, Tennessee Power Authority documents); construction timeline (August 1910 commencement, February 1911 concrete placement, January 27, 1912 plant start); employment scale (1500+ workers); infrastructure (constructed town with waterworks, stores, hospital, police); concrete placement rates (12-15 hundred cubic yards daily). Details relocation from Ocoee No. 1 to Ocoee No. 2 (Caney Creek, May-October 1912). Contains repeated sections (FILE 8 duplicates FILE 5 and FILE 6 content). TRUNCATED in extraction (original ~6345 words).
content_preview:
SOJOURN
IN THE USA













For
years, Maritimers flocked to the USA to find work; this trend did not
really change until after WW2 when Maritimers travelled west, first
to work in the plants in Ontario but later to work in the oilfields
of Alberta.  The Glendenning and Watling families were no exception. 
I am told three times a day, trains left Prince Edward Island and
made connections with trains to the ABoston
States.@







Many
Maritimers found their first jobs in the woods of Maine and New
Hampshire, initially in winter only.  Many returned home to fish or
farm in the summer; later many found year-round work and eventually
became permanent residents.  Young women, including my Mother and,
later, my two sisters went to Portland or Boston and found work with
families looking for a nanny, a cook, a housekeeper or a Ajill
of all trades.@








In
the late 1800's, Portland was the terminus of the Atlantic and St.
Lawrence Railroad (Grand Trunk), a line to Montreal which "made
Portland into Canada's winter port".  Other heavy industry was
to be found in that area of Portland including the building of
locomotives and the construction of docks to accommodate
transatlantic passenger vessels.  Street names St. Lawrence, Quebec
and Montreal for example further reflect the Canadian connection.








Some
1500 buildings were destroyed and 12 000 people left homeless in the
great fire of 1866.  New and presumably better housing was
constructed and it appears that lighter industry began to locate in
that area.  Around the turn of the century a few grand homes began to
appear on the Promenade which provided a sweeping view of the water. 
Construction provided many jobs and it is likely that Dad worked in
the construction trade field.  In fact, Walter recalled a trip to
Portland with Dad and a visit to a construction site to see some
friends.








In
the context of all the industrial activity and development, it is not
surprising that Portland  attracted Maritimer...

title: Tombstone Margaret Virginia
summary: Correspondence (Nov 2011) between Don and St. John's Cemetery administrator regarding restoration of his sister Margaret Virginia's gravestone in Hampton, Virginia, buried 1918. Shows family care and connection to diaspora.
content_preview:
November 12, 2011 




My father and mother, Elmer and Jane Glendenning, lived in Hampton, Virginia during the construction of the Langley Field and, in fact, had a daughter, Margaret Virginia buried in St. John’s Episcopal Cemetery. A number of family members, including myself, have visited the cemetery over the years. 

My remaining siblings are wondering if the stone still exists, what kind of shape it is in and if it could benefit from restoration.

Is it possible to arrange for someone to look at it and provide an estimate of the cost of cleaning and/or restoration.

Thanks is advance for any assistance that you can provide.

Sincerely

Don Glendenning







November 14, 2011

Dear Mr. Glendenning, My name is David Bishop and I am the administrator of

St. John's Cemetery. I will look into this matter for you and report back

to you within a week or so. (I doubt if I'll be over at the cemetery sooner

than this coming Sunday.) / David Bishop




November 20, 2011

----- Original Message ----- 

> From: "Dave Bishop" <davebishopuva@mac.com>

> To: <dglend@pei.sympatico.ca>

> Sent: Sunday, November 20, 2011 3:54 PM

> Subject: Gravestone for Margaret Virginia Glendenning

>

>

>> Dear Mr. Glendenning, I visited the gravesite today. There is indeed a

>> gravestone there but it is almost impossible to read. For your 

>> information,

>> the gravesite is Lot 353 site a. Four infants are buried in that 

>> lot--all

>> died in 1918. Only your sister has a gravestone. I am going to refer 

>> you

>> to Suffolk Monument Company (Randy Maust) (757-539-6845) to obtain a

>> professional opinion on the extent to which the gravestone can be 

>> restored.

>> Randy has a map of our cemetery and he will be able to locate the 

>> gravesite

>> with the lot number. If I may be of additional service to you, please 

>> let

>> me know. /David Bishop

title: Transferred black River
summary: Email correspondence (2004-2005) with Janet Watling and Ron Robichaud about historical Black River/Miramichi bridges, early sawmills, and genealogical photo collection. Reflects Don's role as local historian and family network coordinator.
content_preview:
From: "Janet Watling" <jewatling@yahoo.com>

title: Transferred Genealogy
summary: Email exchange with genealogist Ian Glendinning (Oct 2005) about William Glendinning ancestry in Scotland and Alice Carey Saulnier regarding genealogical research. Don receiving and sharing specialized genealogical findings from other researchers.
content_preview:
From: "Ian Glendinning" <ian@glendinning.name>

To: "Donald Glendenning" <dglende@auracom.com>

Subject: William Glendinning

Date: October 24, 2005 11:47 AM




Hi Don,

A bit more about William Glendinning son of John Glendinning and Mary Rae.

The entry in your father's family bible ties in very nicely with other information I have, to confirm it is the same person.

In 1855 a daughter Jane Glendinning was born on 9 Sep 1855 to William Glendinning and Grace Marshall.  The place of birth was given as Little Skellyholm, St Mungo Parish, Dumfriesshire.  The birth record noted that this couple had one previous child, a son who was still living.

In the 1851 census for St Mungo is the family of William Glendinning aged 32 a farm labourer born Middlebie, his wife Grace aged 36 born Hoddam, and a son John aged 11 a farm labourer born St Mungo.  So that would make John born about 1839 or 40.  In fact the OPR has a baptism for this John on 23 Feb 1841 at Middlebie.  The two facts could be consistent as he might have been born in St Mungo the previous year and baptised when he was a few months old, back in his father's old church.

The bible entry for William pointed me towards the Statutory Index of deaths and this confirms William died in St Mungo in 1874 aged 56.  I do not have the full record of this.

But I do have the full record of his daughter Jane as she died in Langholm and this town is of particular relevance for my family so I have most of the Glendinning records for that town.  You can see her record at http://www.glendinning.name/ancestry/records/dcert839.htm#1876_41  You will see she was unmarried and both her parents were deceased.  Her father William was listed as a Grocer.

I think that is all I have of this family.  Hope it is of interest.

Ian

title: US Relatives
summary: Documents information about Glendenning and Watling relatives who emigrated to or settled in the United States. Traces family connections including those in Maine, Massachusetts, and other eastern states. Provides genealogical context for the American branch of the family.
content_preview:
USA Migration




We know the precise date that my mother landed in Portland (January 24,1908); we cannot say the same for my father.  We know, however, that he and one or more of his brothers ran a cartage business in Portland prior to 1910.  We also know that some of his first cousins by the name of Henry had moved to the Portland area prior to 1870 and that their mother, his Great Aunt Mary Anne (Harley) Henry moved there after her husband died (1970).  Dad also had first cousins by the name of Knowles living in the US but I do not know the time period.  I believe that Lillian stayed with them when she went to Boston in 1933.










Earth Quakes




According to my sister, Lillian, an earthquake was felt in Black river in 1925.  There was a more recent one but I do not recall the year.  Ken was visiting at John’s and John went into the barn for something.  While he was in the barn, the quake was felt.  The metal siding on the barn banged as though someone was striking it with a piece of two by four.

title: Victoria Bridge
summary: Email exchange (January 2006) between Richard MacDougall (a professional at the Canadian Hydrographic Service) and Dorothy & Bryan about nostalgic memories of Victoria Bridge near Black River. MacDougall recalls childhood adventures: playing in the bridge, fishing, climbing girders, and later removing roadblocks in 1969-70 during closure attempts. Memories include encounters with bootleggers and the physical characteristics of the wooden bridge. Shows Don's connection to local landmarks and community memories.
content_preview:
From: MacDougall, Richard [MacDougallR@mar.dfo-mpo.gc.ca]
Sent: Saturday, January 14, 2006 12:02 PM
To: 'brydor@shaw.ca'
Subject: Re: Victoria Bridge

Hi Dorothy
That bridge brings back lots of memories for me too. 

We played in it - climbed the girders - went under the floor - fished from
the pier or the causeway or the wharf and peeked through the holes where
boards were missing.

The floor boards "flapped" when a car went over and made a great din. The
sounding the horses hooves and the iron rims of the waggon added to it. 

I remember them gravelling the road - about 1960 or 1961 and the trucks
hauling across it from McGraw's pit. Bert Mills was hired to drive the
spikes back down because they worked their way up as the planks flapped.
Bert had very poor eye sight ( might have been legally blind) so he pounded
spikes - spots of tar - spots of oil, anything darker than the planks. Then
another truck would cross and more spikes would rise up. 

Walking through at night was interesting. If someone had hidden and jumped
out at me I'd have been over the side I am sure. It was get your eyes
accustomed to the dark - focus on that rectangle of lighter sky at the far
end and try and walk down the centre of the roadway. Those missing boards
let in some light so were welcomed. This likely was good training for
driving - look far ahead and not at the lines on either side of you. 

We parked in it - drank beer from the boot leggers there because we were too
young to go to the liquor store - etc. 

The first time they closed it - about easter 1969 or 70  I think - they put
in 2 posts and put a guard rail across them and dumped a load of gravel to
boot. I got the guard rail off easily with an old crescent wrench but it
took me most of Good Friday to shovel enough off that pile of gravel to
drive across.  They left it open for quite awhile - we did petitions +n 69
but to no available. 

Enough of the past. Marion is home from work so I'd better see to feeding
her. 

Dick from ...

title: Watling, Donald Ernest
summary: Newspaper obituary for D. Ernest Watling Sr. (age 81) of Loggieville, died at Hotel Dieu Hospital after long illness. Third-party document. Born in Black River Bridge; son of Jubal and Grace MacDonald Watling. WWI veteran (26th Battalion) and WWII security guard at CFB Chatham. Survived by wife Alice MacLean and three sons including Ernest of Buffalo, NY. Key figure in extended Glendenning family genealogy.
content_preview:
The following clipping was in the local newspaper:




"The death of D. Ernest Watling Sr. of Manse Lane, Loggieville, occurred Sunday at Hotel Dieu, here, following a long illness.  He was 81.  Born at Black River Bridge, he was the son of the late Jubal and Grace (MacDonald) Watling.

He attended Knox United Church, Loggieville, and was a veteran of the First Worls War, serving overseas with the 26th Battallion.  During the Second World War he was a security guard at CFB Chatham.  He was a member of the Chatham Branch Royal Canadian Legion.  For a number of years the family resided in Niagara Falls and, following their return to the Miramichi, he worked for W S Loggie Company Limited here until his retirement some years ago.

He is survived by his wife, the former Alice MacLean of Black River Bridge; one daughter, Mrs Everett Wishart (Joyce) of Bathurst; three sons, Clifton (Kip) of Campbellton, Ernest of Buffalo, NY, Gilbert of Newcastle; one sister, Mrs. John r. Godfrey (Janet) of Black River Bridge; one brother, James A Watling also of Black River Bridge, and by 16 grandchildren.  The body is resting at his home in Loggieville.

The Funeral will be held at 2:30 pm Tuesday at Knox United Church, Loggieville, with entombment in Black River Memorial Vault to await burial in the spring.

title: Watling Genealogy
summary: Email from Judy Watling (Apr 2008) sharing extensive Watling family research, photos, and obituaries from 1917, responding to Don's Family Chronicle publications. Demonstrates impact of his genealogical work on broader family research community.
content_preview:
From: "Judy Watling" <watlingj@nbnet.nb.ca>
To: <don@glendenning.net>
Subject: Watling Genealogy
Date: April 26, 2008 6:36 PM

Hello : 

I am a great-granddaughter of Alexander MacNaughton Watling (son of Jubal Watling and Susan Leach) and his wife Catherine Kelly.  I am descended from their son John Gordon Watling and his wife Myrtle Dempsey (my grandparents).

I have been following your "Family Chronicle" issues with great interest for several years now and was thrilled to see your last few issues on Watling roots. I thought I would drop you a line and let you know that if you are interested, I have quite extensive research on the descendants of Alexander and Catherine , including photos of all their children.

Alexander and Catherine were married June 18, 1874 and had 12 children, 9 of whom survived to adulthood. I have attached to this email 2 photos of Alexander and Catherine, their obits  and the obit of Catherine's father Peter Kelly (1800-Dec. 17,1894). I have the actual issue of "The Gazette" published in Chatham N.B. June 6,1917 which contains Alexander's obituary. The paper is a little weathered of course, but still in great shape considering it's almost 91 years old !

If you would like any further info on my line of the family ,I am more then willing to share - please don't hesitate to contact me. Thanks for sharing your data in  "The Family Chronicle".

Bye for now 
Judy Watling�
